WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Baldwin's-place
. On the 29th of August I made an application to the parish for my wife, who was sick, and they sent me the prisoner as a nurse - I know these articles to be mine.

JOSEPH SMITH
. I am the prosecutor's son. I saw the prisoner on the Tuesday after the Saturday she left us - I asked her what she had done with my trousers, which I had missed on the Sunday; she said she did not like to see my father - I asked her for the duplicate; she gave me ten duplicates, all of Mr. Nicholls'; I gave them to my uncle, who was coming by.

SAMUEL HEMPSTEAD
. I am servant to Mr. Nicholls, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned seven of these articles at different dates; 1 lent 5s. 11d. on them.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am a constable, and took the prisoner; she said she had pawned the things to buy the children bread.

Prisoner's Defence. He never gave me any money, and I took the things to provide the family with necessaries - from the 20th of July to the 23d of August, I had not common necessaries; I was to have 1s. 6d. per week, and I never received but two eighteen pences.

WILLIAM SMITH
re-examined. She had eighteen pence a week of me; I was at home to every meal - the place was never without food; there were different articles which I took from her lodging; she was with me seven or eight weeks.
GUILTY . Aged 57.
Confined Three Months .

1732.
FRANCIS DUFF
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 1 coat, value 4l., and 1 pair of trousers, value 30s. , the goods of
Richard Eddes
, his master.

BRICE TAMIESON
. I am foreman to Mr.
Richard Eddes
, a tailor , of Christ Church-passage
; the prisoner was his journeyman . On the 8th of August, about eight o'clock at night, I gave him a black coat and a pair of trousers to deliver to Mr. Rose, No. 4, Acton-street, Gray's Inn-road; he returned for his wages in about an hour, and said he had delivered them safe.

JAMES HOPPER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Waller-street. This coat was pawned with me by the prisoner, on Tuesday, the 11th of August.

GEORGE WEBB
. I am a pawnbroker. These trousers were pawned with me by the prisoner, on the 10th of August.

ROBERT PAYNE
. I took up the prisoner on the 11thof August; he told me the duplicates were under the seat of the privy.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor, before I was taken, and likewise afterwards, sent my brother to say if I would confess what was done with the things, he would not prosecute me.

WILLIAM DUFF
. I am the prisoner's brother. On the Tuesday morning the prosecutor came and informed me these things were missing; I went to look after the prisoner by his direction - he said all he wanted was to recover the goods; he thought he had been misled by keeping bad company, and if I would go and get him to give and account of them he would be satisfied; I went - he said he would go and explain to his master; instead of that the foreman came and took part in the affair, and gave him into custody; when he was taken to the Police-office, his master said if he would give up the goods, he would carry the case no further, and upon that assurance, I induced him to give evidence against himself.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Weeks .

1733.
ELIZABETH JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August
, 52 pairs of shoes, value 4l.; 1 shawl, value 1s. 6d.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 2 rows of beads, value 6d.; 1 yard measure, value 2d.; 1 key, value 3d., and 6 books, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas Wasp
, the elder, and
Thomas Wasp
, the younger, her masters ; and
SARAH O'LEARY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the said goods, she well knowing the same to have been stolen .

THOMAS WASP
. I am a bootmaker
, and live in Holborn
. I am in partnership with my father,
Thomas Wasp
- the prisoner Johnson was in our service. On the 29th of August, in consequence of suspicion, I went to eight or nine pawnbrokers, and found some shoes, six books, and a variety of other things - these shoes I can swear to, as they had been trimmed by the prisoner the night before we missed them; the books had been in a book-case in my bed-room - she had been in our service about two years, and we had no reason to suspect her; she had to go from our house to Islington every day, and property was found at every pawnbroker's between our house and there.

SAMUEL HAMPSTEAD
. I am a shopman to Mr. Nicholl's. I have some shoes, books, and other things; the greater part were pawned by
Mary Ann O'Leary
.

GEORGE UNDERWOOD
. I am a shopman to Mr. Nicholl's. I have some shoes pawned by
Mary Ann O'Leary
, at different times.

RICHARD ROPE
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Liquorpond-street. I have some shoes pawned with me by
Mary Ann O'Leary
- I do not recollect the prisoner pawning any thing.

JOSEPH GODDARD
. I am a shopman to Mr.
Robert Beecham
. I have two pairs of shoes pawned by Mary
Ann O'Leary
.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shawl, pawned on the 25th of August, a table-cloth, and a pair of shoes, pawned by Johnson - and a shirt pawned, I believe, by one of the O'Leary's, but I cannot say which.

ROBERT BERRY
. I have a pair of shoes pawned, I believe by O'Leary, on the 29th of August - she was in the shop at the time.

JOHN HUTHILL
. I am shopman to Mr. Loveday, a pawnbroker. I have two pairs of shoes pawned, I believe, by O'Leary, in the name of Brown.

MATTHEW GLOVER
. I am a patrol. I produce a pair of shoes and some other articles, some lead and a key, the duplicate of a shawl pawned at Mr. Smith's, and a great number of shoes, which were given up before the Magistrate; Mary
Ann O'Leary
said she pawned some.

JOHN HENRY BILLINGS
. I am an officer. I produce a necklace which I found in a small box belonging to Johnson, who was not present - Mrs. Wasp swore to the necklace, at the office; as I was taking Johnson to the office, she said if I would not take her before a Magistrate she would confess - but she owned she pawned two pairs.

MARY ANN O'LEARY
. I took some of these things to pawn, but not near so many as are brought against me -I took some of the shoes; I cannot say which - I have known Johnson about four months; I live opposite her mother - she has given me ladies shoes to pawn; I pawned some of them at the corner of Hare-street-hill, and some at Mr. Nicholl's - I gave the money to Johnson; I often pawned for her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
O'Leary's Defence. I appeal to the Court if it is likely I should pawn property so near my own house, when detection was sure to follow.

JOHNSON -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

O'LEARY -
NOT GUILTY .

1734.
JOHN HANCOCK
was
indicted for embezzlement; and that he, at the Delivery of the King's Gaol of Newgate, holden on the 4th of December, in the 9th Year of his Majesty's Reign, was convicted of felony .

WILLIAM HARDING
. I am a baker , and live at Bethnal-green
. The prisoner was in my employ, and used to receive money for me, every morning he went out with his bread; he was to account for the money he received when he returned - he never accounted to me for 2s. 7 1/2d. received on the 27th of July, nor for 9 1/2d. received on the 28th - I found from the customers that they had paid him; and he afterwards acknowledged it.

CHRISTOPHER WREN
. On the 27th of July I paid the prisoner 2s. 7 1/2d. for his master - he did not give me any receipt.

SARAH DERBY
. I am servant to Mr. Bushell. I paid the prisoner, on the 28th of July, 9 1/2d. for his master - I gave him a shilling, and he gave me 2 1/2d. out.
THOMAS BRIDGES. I am a constable. I took the prisoner on the 29th of July, at his master's shop - he said he had lost the money.

WILLIAM HARDING
re-examined. The prisoner came home on the 27th - I booked his bread; I asked if any of his bills had been paid - he said No; I did the same on the 28th, and he gave me the same answer.

JOHN WILLIAM WINTLE
. I produce the certificate of the conviction of the prisoner, last December Session, for stealing a basket of bread - I know he is the person.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life .

1735.
JAMES COSTER
was
indicted for embezzlement .

JAMES GILES
. The prisoner was in my employ as a stove grate maker , in Cow cross-street - he had only been with me three days before the 14th of August; I told him that day to take a stove, fender, and fire-irous, to the Dolphin, Dolphin-court, Ludgate-hill
- he never returned, but was taken the next day.

JANE
SARAH OXFORD
. I keep the Dolphin. I purchased this stove, fender, and fire-irons - I paid the prisoner 12s. for them; he brought no bill, and I had no receipt.

RICHARD MILLAR
. I took the prisoner on the Saturday. I found 3s. and two or three halfpence on him - he said he had spent the remainder.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Three Months .

1736.
HENRY HUGHES
was
indicted for embezzlement .

ANN BREEDON
. I am the wife of
Thomas Breedon
- he is a carman . The prisoner was in his employ on the 15th of July - he received money to pay charges for Kennel coal, at the Docks; I gave him 2l. 5s. 6d. first, and then he sent home for 3l. more, which I sent him - he did not return; he was found by the officer about a month afterwards - he had been about seven or eight months in our employ.

JOSEPH HUGHES
. The prisoner sent me from the London Docks
to get 3l. more - I got it, and took it to him; he said he wanted 5l. 1s. 8 1/2d. to pay the charges, and he had not enough.

ROBERT LOCK
. I took up the prisoner in Chequer-alley, on the 20th of August. I told him I wanted him for Mr. Breedon's account - he said he was very sorry, he could not help it, some he had spent, and some he lost.

ANN BREEDON
re-examined. He paid part of this money at the Docks, the balance he kept - he sent me a note of what he had paid.
The prisoner delivered in a written defence, stating that he had lost the money, and was afraid to return to his mistress.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1737.
THOMAS NIBBS
was
indicted for embezzlement .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM SHIRLEY
. I am a publican and horse dealer , and live at Staines. I had a stallion, called "The Farmer's Glory;" the prisoner was in my employ for two seasons, to take the horse round to the different farmers, and to different markets - I engaged to give him 5l. for the season, 1s. for every mare that was covered, and he received 3l. 10s. every Monday morning to pay his expences, when he came back at the end of the week he was to give an account of what he had spent; if he had any left he was to return it - if he had spent more it was paid him; when he returned on the Sunday I used to ask him what he received - he said, "None at all," which was the case every Sunday this season; he never paid me any; any money that he received, it was his duty to bring to me; I think he returned me that answer for fourteen or fifteen weeks - the last time I paid him was on the 6th of July, when he left me with the 3l. 10s., and never returned; I received my horse back, I think, on the 17th, with a note in his hand-writing- I waited till the following Sunday, and then sent a person into the country; on the Friday I went to Banbury, where I found the prisoner in custody, and brought him to London; the constable had taken a letter from him, and a book, before I saw him; he afterwards gave me a statement of some sums, which he had never paid me, but I have only a copy of it here.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were the stallions yours or not? A. Yes, I purchased them; I had three of them; the first I bought was a year ago - this is a bill which I had printed; the prisoner was to lead "The Wanderer" and "The Farmer's Glory;" I was a bankrupt since I bought them - I have got my certificate; my effects were sold in May last - it was in March I sent the prisoner out with the stallion; the stallion was bought in by my friends for me; it was sold by auction, and the assignees got the proceeds of it; my friends have no partnership in these stallions - I had settled with the prisoner at the termination of last season; there was no running account - we settled every week: sometimes there were expences of shoeing and physic for which he paid a shilling or two, which I paid him - he did pay Mr. Coleman 1l. 5s., but he always had money in advance - what he paid out of his pocket he was repaid the next week; he behaved very well the first season, or I should not have employed him again. I have read over this book to my sorrow, which the prisoner kept; the names are down here; these sums are entered as not having been paid; they are entered that the parties might be called upon who had not paid - if he received any money he ought to have paid me, but if he had not I was to call on them; if he had not put down those names I should have beard of it, as those gentlemen were often sending their mares.

MR. BODKIN. Q. What do you understand by this entry of the name of Murrell? A. That he had not paid - there was no account between the prisoner and me but the 5l. which I was to pay him at the end of the season, and he had 3l. of that.

JOHN MURRELL
. I live at Walton on Thames. I paid the prisoner 2l. 10s. on the 29th of June, for Mr. Shirley - it was for covering two mares, one on the 17th of April, and one on the 3rd of May.

- STRUBLE. I live at East Moulden
. I paid the prisoner 1l. 17s. on the 29th of June, for his master.

WILLIAM SHIRLEY
re-examined. The names of Mr. Murrell and Mr. Struble appear in this book - the money has never been paid to me.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you not see that book, with Mr. Murrell's name in it, after the 17th of April? A. Yes: I saw it every week, but he did not tell me he had received the money; it is usual to call several times for the money- he was to pay me if he received it.

Prisoner's Defence. When I sent my horses home my box was in London, and my book was in it; when I went to London my book was gone to Banbury, and I had to go there for it; master sent a man after me, and I could not return as soon as I should, as my mistress was out, and I could not get the key of my box.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1738.
WILLIAM GOODWIN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 7th of July , of a certain evil-disposed person, 10 pieces of silk, containg 1000 yards, value 80l., the goods of
William Comber
, which had lately before been stolen by the said evil-disposed person, he, the said
William Goodwin
, well knowing the same to have been stolen .
The same evidence was given in this case as last Session, when the prisoner was indicted as a principal. (See Sixth Session, page 705.)

1739.
REBECCA CHITTY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 23rd of July , of a certain evil-disposed person, 2 pairs of seales, value 3ls. and 9 weights, value 4s., the goods of
William Gayton
, which had then been lately before stolen, well knowing the same to have been stolen .

WILLIAM GAYTON. I am a surgeon . I lost a pair of seales from my shop in Church-street, Bethnal-green, on the 23rd of July, at twelve o'clock; I saw them at the prisoner's house; these are them; I value them at a guinea and a half - they cost me near 3l.

THOMAS WATERS
. I went with a search-warrant to the prisoner's house; I asked if she was the mistress of the house; she said Yes - I asked if she had any doctor's scales; she paused, and said, "Yes, up stairs;" I went up, and found them under the bed, covered with some dirty linen; she said she hoped we would be merciful to her, she was a poor widow woman - I asked for her book; she said she could not write herself; she gave me a book, which had not got them in; I took her to the office, and afterwards a little girl, whom she called her daughter, came and brought a book, which had got the scales down at 2s., which she before said she gave for them - she did not say from whom she purchased them, nor did she say that she had not them for sale, as they were intended for a friend; I did not hear her say so at the office.

Cross-examined by MR. MILLER. Q. Was not a boy examined at the office? A. Yes, but he was put in the workhouse to be kept, and ran away; he was here on Saturday, but I could not find him to-day; he said he saw two boys go in with them, and they gave him 2d. to say nothing - it was through him the search-warrant was granted; his name is Driscoll.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The officer came to my house, and asked if I had a pair of scales; I said, "What sort of scales?" he said, "Doctor's scales;" my reason for asking was, I had bought several pairs for the shop - I said, "I hope I have not done wrong in buying them;" I did not know where my little girl had put them, as she had put them away up stairs, as she had been cleaning - I stood for some minutes; my little girl came up, went to the box, and took them out; the officer did not take them; the lad I bought them of was by himself; he had a very decent appearance: I questioned him, and he said they were his father's, who was ill - I had bought two or three things the week before of him.
NOT GUILTY .

1740.
REBECCA CHITTY
was again indicted for
receiving, on the 23rd of July , of a certain evil-disposed person, 4 milk-pails, value 11s., the goods of
Ebenezer Blayney
, she knowing the same to have been stolen .

EBENEZER BLAYNEY
. I am a milkman . On the 23rd of July I lost four milk-pails from my garden, in Queen-street, Hackney; I had seen them on the garden pails the night before - these are mine; I know nothing of the prisoner.

THOMAS WATERS
. I am a Police-officer. On the 25th of July I went to the prisoner's house with a search-warrant; she is a kind of marine-store dealer, in Hackney-road; I found these pails up stairs; she said she bought them - I asked her for her book of the entry; she gave me one book, and I said, "It is not in this;" she said, "I have another, which my brother puts down things in, as I can't write myself:" I took her to the office, and soon after another book was brought, which had them entered; she said she had bought them some time, but she did not say of whom; she did not tell me the price, nor whether she bought them of a man, woman, or child.

Prisoner's Defence. I told the officer I bought them in an honourable way, gave 7s. for them, and exposed them at my door; one of the witnesses came and bought them, and gave me a deposit of a shilling, which induced me to take them in.

JOHN BAILEY
. I am a chair-bottomer. I went into the prisoner's house to ask if she had any chairs to mend - I cannot tell the month, but it was on a Tuesday; I saw her give 7s. for these pails - she bought them of a tall man, in a drab coat; she gave him two half-crowns and two shillings - she called me to do some chairs, and offered me ninepence a piece to do them; I said I could not do them under a shilling.
NOT GUILTY .

1741.
ESTHER WELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 1 bed, value 10s.; 1 blanket, value 2s.; 1 half blanket, value 1s.; 1 pillow, value 1s., and 2 rugs. value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Brown
.

THOMAS BROWN
. I lost this property from a backroom, on the ground floor, No. 3, Angel-gardens, Shadwell
; the prisoner did not lodge in my house; I got up that day a little before twelve o'clock, as I am a patrol I left a little girl asleep, and went out for an errand; as I was coming back a woman came running round the corner to me, and said, "That woman has come out of your house with a bed, there she goes;" I went, and took her with these articles.

ELIZABETH TAYLOR
. I am a neighbour of the prosecutor's. I saw the prisoner come out of the house with the bed on her shoulder.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I got into conversation with a person, who said her name was Brown, but I had no knowledge of her; I said I was very destitute - she said if I would go to this person's house, and get the things out, she would give me a shilling, and she would wait for me in King David-lane.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 37.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1742.
WILLIAM SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 117lbs. of lead, value 16s. , the goods of
William Hollinshed
.

WILLIAM HOLLINSHED
. I am a cabinet-maker , in King-street, Seven-dials
. On the 28th of July we had been pulling down part of our premises; this lead was packed up, and laid in a stable - I had seen it safe the day before, and remarked that somebody had been moving it; this piece of lead fits the place it came from exactly.

GEORGE MOGFORD
. I am servant to Mr. Hollinshed. There was lead in the stable - I met the prisoner that morning with a bundle, and watched him into an old ironshop; I went and told the prosecutor; we went to the house, and asked what he had brought; the man said it was lead - I did not know what it was; I thought it was a bundle of tiles - it was wrapped up in a bundle; when I saw him first he was not above ten yards from the stable; he was in the back yard, with the bundle on his shoulder; it was about a quarter before nine o'clock in the morning - I found the bag that the lead had been in at the old ironshop, but the lead was out, and the bag laid upon it - it was about a quarter of an hour after I saw the prisoner that I saw the lead again at the shop; he is a bricklayer's labourer, and had been at work there some time.

DANIEL DURALL
. I live at the iron-shop. The prisoner came and asked if we bought lead; I said we did not; I said, "Very likely you have not got it in an honest manner;" he said, "Will you let it be here a few minutes;" I made him no answer; but he pushed me aside, put it down, and in a few minutes after the prosecutor came in - he had the same lead.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw some rubbish and some shavings; I kicked the shavings aside, and took up this lead; I took it to the shop, and was coming back to tell the boy if any body came who owned the lead, I would give it up.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

1748.
GEORGE WINGROVE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of June , 2 hearth-rugs, value 60s. , the goods of
Samuel Hollingsworth
.
MR. PRENDERGAST conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS BEESTON
. I have an hearth-rug pawned at Mr. Jones, Broad-street, Bloomsbury, on the 1st of June, I have every reason to believe by the prisoner - he answers the description of the person.

JOSEPH LYALL
. I am shopman to Mr. Aldridge, pawnbroker. I have an hearth-rug pawned for 9s., on the 1st of June, to the best of my recollection, by the prisoner.

GEORGE HEDWORTH
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner at Petersham, near Kingston, on the 2nd of September.

ANN HEATH
. The prisoner and his wife lodged near me in Paine-street, White Conduit-fields; I do not recollect when I saw him last, but his wife came to me one day, the officer came the same day, and I saw the prisoner come from his own house, and go to the bottom of the street; it was some time in August, the day we appeared at Hatton-garden.

SAMUEL HOLLINGSWORTH
. The prisoner lived as a porter with me, at No. 6, Bedford-street, Bedford-row
- he left me about the end of April; his wife was taken on the 30th of July - these two rugs are mine, and were part of my stock; I never sold any thing to him.

Prisoner. Q. Were there not other persons in your employ about my height, who used to frequent your shop when you were out? A. I never heard of any person coming to my shop in my absence, except you and your wife.

Prisoner's Defence. I am entirely innocent of taking the rugs, nor did I ever pawn them. (See the case of
Thomas Hollingsworth
, page 826.)
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Transported for Seven Years .

1744.
RICHARD HARMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 1 chair and stand, value 12s , the goods of
William Redfarn
.

WILLIAM REDFARN
. I am a chair-maker , and live in Bethnal-green
. On the 9th of September I missed a child's chair, which was tied to a stove outside my door - it was safe about eight o'clock in the morning; I went in search of it, and found it in Wilson-street, Moorfields, at a broker's shop.

GEORGE MATTHEW MILLER
. I keep a broker's shop in Wilson-street. On the 9th of September, about ten o'clock in the morning, I bought this chair of the priprisoner, for 10s.

JOSEPH WALTON
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Shoreditch on that morning - a young man came and told me to go and ask 11s. for it, and they would not give it - then he told me to go on further, and I went to this house - he gave me 10s. for it - we changed half a sovereign and had half a pint of beer; I told them to go there, but I do not know whether they went or not.

GEORGE MATTHEW MILLER
. I offered him 10s. - he went home with me, I gave him half a sovereign - he said he understood it was half a guinea - he went away, and came again and said it was a great sacrifice, but he would let me have it.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Judgment Respited .

1745.
ELEANOR FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 1 half sieve, value 6d., and one peck of pears, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Ellis
.

SAMUEL ELLIS
. I am a salesman in Covent-garden
. On the 10th of September I lost a half sieve and about a peck of pears in it - I knew the prisoner, and found the pears on her; she had just got out of the market, within twenty rods of my stand.

WILLIAM COOPER
. I saw a woman take the sieve of pears from the stand, but I cannot say it was the prisoner - we found the prisoner in about ten minutes; she is like the woman.

Prisoner's Defence. I can safely take my oath I bought them - I gave 2s. for the pears, and 6d. for the half sieve; I did not run away with them, nor hide them- I said, "I will take you to the man;" when I got there the countryman was gone.

WILLIAM COOPER
. I told Sir
Richard Birnie
I did not think that was the woman, but she was very muchlike her - she took us to the place where she said she purchased them.
NOT GUILTY .

1746.
ELIZABETH DUGGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 1 ring, value 14s. , the goods of
Edward Storr
.

The witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1747.
HENRY COOKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
Arthur Graham
.

ARTHUR GRAHAM
. I lost a sheet on the 1st of September from off the bed which the prisoner slept on at my house, the Northumberland's Head; I found it the same morning at Mr. Sowerby's - the prisoner stated he was in great distress, and I believe he was so.

WILLIAM EDWARDS
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce a sheet, pawned by the prisoner on the 1st of September, about eight o'clock in the morning.

THOMAS HART
. I took up the prisoner, and found this duplicate on him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 22. (See page 763.)

1748.
JOHN BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 axe, value 3s. , the goods of
William Hamling
.

ROBERT FANCOURT
. I took up the prisoner about eight o'clock in the morning of the 28th of August, with this axe.

RICHARD BLATCHFORD
. The prisoner had been working with me and
William Hamling
. On the evening of the 26th of August I saw Hamling using this axe - on the morning of the 27th it was missed; suspicion fell on the prisoner - I took him the day following with the axe under his arm; I told him what I charged him with, and he said it was an old axe he had picked up in a stable - he took it out of a bag and said, "Is this it?" I said Yes.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Two Months .

1749.
HANNAH ALLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 gold pin, value 7s.; two rows of beads, value 2s.; 1 silver stopper, value 2s.; 1 pair of ear-rings. value 2s.; 2 pockets, value 2s., and 20 half-crowns, the property of Marry Allen, widow ; and 1 bonnet, value 25s., the goods of
Matilda Jones
.

MARY ALLEN
. The prisoner is my daughter - I live in the Edgware-road
; she has not been in my house, to my knowledge, for sixteen or seventeen months - I do not know who took these things, but I missed them on Monday, the 27th of July.

MATILDA JONES
. I am the prosecutrix's niece, and live with her - I found the bureau was ransacked, the things turned out, and the articles stated missing.

SARAH PRATT
. I am the wife of
Thomas Pratt
- we live in Windmill-street, Tottenham-court-road; the prisoner lodged with me, and was taken on Monday, the 10th of August - her box was found in my house, which had been brought there with her.

HANNAH MUNDAY
. I am the wife of Jacob Munday - we live in Burn's-place, Edgware-road; I can see from my bed-room into Mrs. Allen's house. I saw the prisoner on Mrs. Allen's fence on the 27th of July - the fence broke, and she went over into another garden - she then stood upon the fence some time - I called to her, but she did not answer me; she then went into Mr. Burke's wash-house, got on the files, and into the loft of Mrs. Allen's house - I waited about an hour and a half; she did not come out - I then went to bed; I told Mrs. Allen of it on the Friday evening.

MARY ALLEN
. On the Sunday night, the 26th, I tried a little room by the side of my bed-room, and found it locked - I thought my niece had taken the key; in the morning, when she came, I said, "Why did you lock that door?" she said. I did not;" she opened the door, we went in, and missed her bonnet, a cornelian necklace, a pair of ear-rings, two brooches, a silver knife, two shirt-pins, and a great many other things, which I have never seen since - I had seen them safe on the Saturday or Sunday, in the bureau; I know the bureau was fast on the Sunday - whoever took the things must have secreted themselves in the house; the bureau was wrenched all to pieces - the prisoner knew the bureau; and in her father's life time, if we had a little money, it was always put there - I went to Mrs. Pratt's house, and saw the box which my daughter had brought there; I saw a great many things of mine there, and a great number of duplicates - the officer took her; I do not recollect that she said any thing.
Prisoner. I leave it to the mercy of the Court and my mother.

JURY to MRS. ALLEN Q. Did you turn your daughter out of doors? A. No; she has been robbing me these five years successively - I have seen her but once since her father's death, and then she was in a situation.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Seven Days .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1750.
WILLIAM SPONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 1 pair of boots, value 20s.; 1 pair of boot-legs, value 7s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 3s.; 3 sets of two shillings; 1 gown, value 6s.; 4 shirts, value 30s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; 1 table-cloth, value 4s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the property of
James Dawe
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1751.
THOMAS TAYLOR
was indicted for that
he, on the 17th of July , 20 pieces of false and counterfeit milled money and coin, each and every of them made and counterfeited to the likeness and similitude of a piece of good, lawful, and current money and silver coin of this realm, called a shilling, the same not being then cut in pieces, unlawfully and feloniously did put off to one
John Lane
, at a lower rate and value than the same, did by their denomination import and were counterfeited for, (i. e.) for the sum of 5s. ; against the Statute, &c.
MESSRS. BOLLAND, and SCARLETT conducted the prosecution.

JOHN LANE
. I am a watchman of St. Pancras , and have been so for nearly three years - previous to that I was in different places of service, taking care of horses and chaises. About the 8th of July I received directions fromLimbrick to assist in detecting a man named Taylor - he told me he wanted me to go to the Barley Mow, in Blue Anchor-alley
, and buy some money of him; I went there with Ellis and saw the prisoner; Ellis spoke to him, and said I was the man he might trust in selling the money to; the prisoner asked what I wanted; I said not much - he said he had some half conters, which are had half-sovereigns; I said they would not do for me - he then said he would bring some bulls, meaning crowns; he went out, and was out about a quarter of an hour - I took six of him; I think I did not say how many I would take before he went out - I gave 5s. for them; the prisoner set the price; we then had something to drink and I went away; when I got back to Limbrick I told him what had taken place - I saw the prisoner a day or two afterwards at the Barley Mow, I then bought three crowns and a half for 3s. 6d. - I had several subsequent meetings with him, previous to each of which I had communication with Limbrick; what I did was under his direction. On the 17th day of July, in the evening, I met Hall, Reynolds, and Limbrick, at the Jack of Newbury, the corner of Bun-hill-row - I was searched by them and had nothing about me - they then gave me 5s. to purchase some money and 1s. to spend; I did not know whether it was marked -I went to the Barley Mow alone, and saw the prisoner sitting in one of the boxes with other company; I went and asked if he had got any thing for me; he said Yes; but whispered that there were persons there he did not wish to give it me before - we went out to Graham's-buildings, which is a short distance, and he told me he had a score of bobs, which meant bad shillings; he pulled them out of his pocket in a small silk bag - I gave him 5s. for them; he had a bad crown-piece at the time, he wished me to have that - I said I would have that another day; we went back to the Barley Mow - I tossed for some beer, and lost two pots; Hall, Limbrick, and Reynolds then came in - Limbrick advanced up to me, and said, "Ah! old one, I had you twenty years ago;" that is not true, he never had me in his life - I was taken into custody, and searched by Reynolds, who took the silk bag, containing the bobs, out of my right-hand waistcoat pocket; he put it on the table, and asked where I got it; I said, "From that man," pointing to the prisoner; he said, "Me, Sir?" I said Yes; he was then taken and searched, and the 5s. which I had given him found on him.
Prisoner. He is speaking very falsely to say he had them from me; the man he had them from had been gone about ten minutes.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. In consequence of information I employed Lane, and gave him 5s. each time he made the purchases - the first time he brought me these five crowns; on the 9th he brought me these three crowns and a half, on the 11th, I instructed him in the same manner, and on the 17th, Hall, Reynolds, and I went to the Jack of Newbury, where I searched Lane, and found he had nothing - I then gave him five marked shillings, and 1s. to get something to drink, and directed him to go to the Barley Mow; after a certain time I went there, and saw him and the prisoner sitting there together; Lane was searched, and we found on him a score of had shillings, which Reynolds has; I asked where he had them from - he said from Taylor; Taylor was searched, and had four marked shillings, a sixpence, some halfpence, (they were four of the shillings which I had given to Lane,) and a bad crown; he was then taken to Hatton-garden.

WILLIAM REYNOLDS
. I am an officer of St. James', Clerkenwell. I went with Limbrick and Hall to the Barley Mow, on the 17th of July; I received the prisoner from Limbrick; Hall had searched him; these four shillings, a sixpence, and halfpence, and this bad half-crown, were found upon him.

WILLIAM HALL
. I am an officer. I went with Limbrick and Reynolds. This money was found on the prisoner; these four shillings are four which I had seen Limbrick mark, and which had been given to Lane at the Jack of Newbury, about five o'clock in the evening.

MR.
JOHN FIELD
. I am inspector of counterfeit money- these are all counterfeit crowns, and these shillings are all counterfeit.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. These four good shillings are four which I marked and gave to Lane.
Prisoner. He had them of another man, called "the Doctor," whom I have seen in his company several times.

JOHN LANE
. No, I had them of him.

Prisoner's Defence. It is false; he, the doctor, and I were there together, and had a good deal of beer - he and the doctor were in conversation for some time, and he had the bad money of him, I am sure; I had lent him 5s. the day before.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1752.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 4th of August , from a certain evil-disposed person, a variety of stamped papers and parchments, value 1379l. 13s., the goods of our Lord the
King
, well knowing the same to have been stolen ; against the Statute.
MESSRS. BOLLAND and BRODRICK conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS ALLEN
. I am a warehouse-keeper at the Stamp-office. Mr. Crutwell is a stamp distributor at Bath- I received from him two requisitions for stamps, one dated the 21st of July, and the other the 22nd; the one of the 21st contained a requisition for a great number of stamps, and the one of the 22nd for one single stamp: I examined them previous to their being put up by
William Woodyer
, and saw the parcels after they were put up - they were numbered 1020 and 1028; the parcel numbered 1020 contained the large number of stamps - an invoice was put into the first parcel, which was very nearly according to the requisition; they were addressed to
William Crutwell
, Esq., stamp-office, Bath; they were delivered to James Read, Mr. Sherman's porter, to go by the Bath coach; one of them was a square parcel, and the other a long one. I have seen a list which has been produced by Ruthven.

WILLIAM WOODYER
. I am a packer at the Stamp-office. I put up the stamps which Mr. Allen has been speaking of, and delivered them to James Read, the porter.

JOHN CLEMENT
. I am a clerk at the Stamp-office. I made out an invoice, which I gave to Mr. Allen.

JAMES READ
. I am a porter in the employ of Mr. Sherman, a coach-proprietor. I took the two parcels from the Stamp-office to the Saracen's Head, Snow-hill; I do not know what coach they were to go by - I saw the bookkeeper, but I do not know his name; they were directed to Mr. Crutwell, of Bath - one was larger than the other, but having so many, I cannot say particularly about the size- I think it was the 24th of July; it was on a Friday night.

THOMAS HILLDRUP
. I am book-keeper at the Saracen's Head. I received the two parcels from Read on the 24th of July - I entered them to go by the Royal Blue Bath coach: I put them on the appropriate shelf belonging to that coach, and saw no more of them.

JOSEPH MOUNTAIN
. I am a book-keeper there. I handed the parcels to go into the coach; I remember two brown paper parcels, directed "Crutwell, Bath," and ticked them off in the book.

JAMES HODSON
. I am a porter. I put all the parcels that I received from Mountain into the coach - I have no recollection of them.

JOHN HILL
. I am clerk to Mr. Crutwell, of Bath - he is the distributor of stamps there; these requisitions came from our office: we received but one parcel, containing one skin of 130/., six skins of 10/., and six skins of 20l.; the parcel that did come was numbered 1028 - we received no other parcel.

THOMAS CHESTER
. I am book-keeper at the Grey Hound inn, Bath; the Royal Blue coach comes to our house - I remember the arrival of it on the 25th; it came about six o'clock in the morning - all the parcels that came by it were sent out to the respective persons to whom they were directed; I called over the parcels by the way-billone parcel was missing; on the way-bill was inserted two parcels for Crutwell - one parcel could not be found; the porter searched the coach a second and a third time, but it could not be found.

WILLIAM BOND
. I am porter at the Grey Hound, Bath. There was one parcel missing on this day.

EDWARD KING BALCH
. I am a bookseller. My shop is at No. 3, Great Ormond-street - my father is the principal turnkey at Giltspur-street Compter, and has been there eighteen years; I have had my shop in Great Ormond-street about three months, but I sleep at my sister's, No. 40, Great Alie-street. I first saw the prisoner about seven years ago, in the Giltspur-street Compter - I was living there at that time; when he got out I lost sight of him for some time, but saw him again three or four years ago - I saw him again about three months ago; his wife spoke to me about some books, and I saw him on my calling at his house - on Tuesday, the 4th of August, I met him against the dead wall in the King's-road; he asked if I could purchase any stamps - he took off his hat, and produced some stamps on parchment; I took them in my hand, and saw three 30l. stamps, and some that I concluded to be 10l., and some others at 10s. - they laid in my hand like a pack of cards, one over the head of the other; and the way they laid I was prevented from seeing them completely, but the three thirtys were at the top; I said I could not purchase them myself, but I would see some person about them - he said there were about 1400l. or 1500l. worth: that there were two of 140/. each, and the lot would he sold for 300/.; he said he was going to see a party about them, but they would not be gone by the next morning, if I would call at his house - we parted at that time, and I called at his house the next morning; he was not at home - I left word that I would call again at two o'clock; I went at that time and saw him - I had previously looked into the Times, and several other papers, to see if I could see any account of the stamps, as I concluded they were stolen from some law-stationer's; I saw an advertisement in the Times paper - I went to his house at two o'clock, and saw a list of the stamps which he said were to be sold; he then told me they were prigged, by which I understood they were stolen - having seen the list, I found it corresponded with the advertisement; what made me think it was the same, was the two of 140l. - he again told me the price would be 300/.; I left him and went to dinner, and then went to the Stamp-office - I received some directions there what to do, and went to the prisoner's house about nine o'clock in the evening; I left word I should want a copy of the list - he said if I could call in the morning I should have a copy of it; he then said the price would be reduced, and would be from 200l. to 250l., because a portion of the stamps, amounting to 280l., were not to be sold, and he added, that he should expect something for himself; I told him of course he would have something - I told him I had seen the party, and they would not give more than 170/., or there about - I treated him with a pint of porter; we then parted for the evening, and I agreed to see him again the next morning - I called again between ten and eleven o'clock the next morning; he showed me the list which he had shown me previously, but the stamps at the top were struck out; I made a copy of the list, omitting those which were struck out, by his direction, as he said they would not be included in the purchase - this is the list I made out; I believe it nearly tallies with the list he showed me, with the exception of those struck out at top- I of course cannot swear that it does correspond; he told me that the carriage-plate and pawnbroker's licenses were of no use without they were signed by a magistrate, and that made a reduction of 433/. 5s. - after I had taken the copy we parted; I never, on any occasion, asked to see the stamps - they were shown voluntarily; after I had taken the copy; I went again to his house, after that, because an alteration was made in the list - a nought was struck out in 140, and I went for the purpose of adding that; but in the mean time I had seen Ellis and Ruthven, who were then in the neighbourhood, and they had made some arrangements - I saw the prisoner when I went the last time; I said I wished to see the list again, to rectify an error - he allowed me to see it, and I made the alteration; he then placed it on a table, under the window, under some books or a tea-caddy - I then gave the officers information, but did not go to the house again; I brought the list away that I made, and gave it up to the solicitor of the stamps - I had made some figures on the list that I took this copy from.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. In his, or whose hand-writing was that list? A. I do not know; my father was a turnkey of Giltspur-street Compter, seventeen or eighteen years - I lived there seven or eight years; I cannot say how old I was when I left - I might be about eighteen: I am now twenty-five - I made no particular acquaintance with the prisoner while he was there; they do take in thieves and persons of that description, but my father's apartments are quite separate - I saw theprisoner after he left, but had no particular acquaintance with him till this transaction with the books; it was after he showed them me that I looked into the times - I am quite sure I did not show them to him, and ask if he could get rid of them; I concluded, of course, that they were stolen, and of course I knew there was some danger in possessing them - I have been a bookseller, perhaps, about three months, but I was brought up to the profession of the law; I was with Mr. Forrett, the barrister, as his clerk - that was in 1821, 1822, 1823, and part of 1824; I was not clerk to him as a barrister - I have been with his brother since, Mr. Robert Forrett; I have since then been with Mr. Norton and partner, in the Insolvent Debtors' Court - I am also a painter, and deal in pictures and minerals; the reward stated in the advertisement was 50l. - I never, except on that occasion, saw a single stamp in his possession; I cannot tell whether the paper which was left by the books or tea-caddy, was found by the officers - I was placed, for a short time, to the business of herald engraving, and engaged as a manufacturer of chess, backgammon-tables, and dice-boxes, with a person named Parker, in Plummer-street, City-road; I was with him nine or ten months - we parted on amicable terms; he made no complaint against me, except that I spoiled the work - I do not know Saunders, an attorney; I was never in his employ - after I had been to the solicitor of stamps I went to Ruthven and Ellis.

Q. Did it never occur to you, and did none of them, advise you to bring in some one as a purchaser? A. It was proposed, but it was thought better not; I cannot say who proposed it - there were four or five persons; it might be the solicitor - it was not proposed that I should take some other person to see the same thing, and to confirm what I said; but it was proposed that I should return and look at the list, and then take the person - I recollect Mr. Ruthven proposing that I should take some person as a purchaser, if I did not wish to appear; no one stamp has been found - the prisoner lived on Back-hill, which was in the way from my shop to Great Alie-street: I could not be accommodated with any thing more than the shop at Great Ormond-street - I was going to dine with my father at the Compter, the day I first met him - of course I did not choose to be present when this man was taken up; it was Tuesday when I first saw him, and he was taken on the Thursday.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. When you had seen the stamps, your notion was that they had been stolen from some stationer? A. Yes - it was the advertisement led me to the Stamp-office; in the list I made there were stamps of 140l., and stamps of 30l. - I lived with Mr. Forrett,(now the barrister) three years and a half, and after with Mr. Robert Forrett, who is an attorney.

GEORGE THOMAS JOSEPH RUTHVEN
. I am an officer. I was employed by the Stamp-office to detect this robbery; Ellis was first applied to, and he told me about it -I saw Balch, but I think not on the first occasion; Ellis and I took the prisoner - I think on Thursday. the 6th of August; I found this paper in a hat, with a handkerchief upon it - I do not recollect any proposition being made as to the mode in which the discovery should be carried on; we were puzzled how to go on with it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How many minutes elapsed from the witness coming out of his house and you going in? A. I should think not three - he passed by him, and I went in and searched the prisoner's person; I expected to find the list on his person, but did not - I have seen the writing of law-stationers very much like the writing on this paper; I have seen Balch's writing - it is not like this, according to my view; Balch told me he made the figures at the corner - I have been to the shop in Great Ormond-street, but did not search there.

COURT. Q. When you went into the house you left Balch outside, and expected to find the list on the prisoner's person, but found nothing? A. Yes; the hat on which the paper was found belonged to the prisoner - he put the hat on his head, and the handkerchief I believe he put into his pocket.

JAMES ELLIS
. I was sent for by a person from the Stamp-office; I was directed to apply to another person, and I applied to Ruthven; I was with him when the prisoner was taken - I was securing the prisoner at the time he found the paper.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you remember suggesting the propriety of sending some one with Balch, in order to confirm him a little? A. I am not quite certain - I do not recollect that such a proposition was made; I had several interviews with Balch, chiefly in the solicitor's office.

JOSEPH TIMMS
. I am solicitor to the Board of Stamps. Balch made a communication on the 5th of August, and Ellis and Ruthven, I believe, were sent to; a consultation was held between them, myself, and Balch, as to the best mode of taking the prisoner with the stamps in his possession - I do not recollect any proposition being made about sending any person with Balch.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You have said you do not recollect that there was any such proposition? A. I do not remember it - I have heard Balch say there was - he may be right; I cannot contradict it; it did not strike me that there was any thing very singular in what Balch told us - he explained how he became acquainted with the prisoner - it is better to have two witnesses to a fact where you can have them, and perhaps such a proposition might have been made - I do not recollect any meeting at which it was mentioned; if it had been made, I think I should have recollected it.

MR. BRODRICK to
JOHN CLEMENT
. Q. Did I understand you right that you made an invoice of the stamps from the requisition? A. There was an alteration - to the best of my recollection the medicine labels are put first, and I generally put them last - this list, I apprehended, is the same as the invoice - probates and administration stamps have blanks to fill up; the whole amount of them was 1,545l. 10s.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent. On the day he says I shewed him the stamps I never saw him - how that paper came into my house I do not know.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT.
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 15.
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1753.
JOHN HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , at Little Stanmore, 1 gelding, price 4l. , the property of
John Ballard
.

JOHN BALLARD
. I am a labourer and a green-grocer , and live at Brockley-hill, Little Stanmore
. On the 21st of August, in the afternoon, I turned my gelding out on Brockley-hill, within a quarter of a mile of my house, on a waste - I saw him still grazing there a little after eight o'clock that evening, I went to look for him between four and five next morning, Saturday, and he was gone - I searched for him on Saturday and Sunday, and found him on Monday, about twelve, at Monk's stables, near Whitechapel; it was mine - I have seen the prisoner once or twice in different parts of the neighbourhood, but not to know him - I live about twelve miles from town.

CHARLES RICH
. I am clerk to
William Monk
, a horse-slaughterer, in Whitechapel-road, opposite the London-hospital. On Saturday, the 22nd of August, about half-past nine o'clock in the morning, a horse was brought to me by the prisoner; another man, whom I have known in the neighbourhood for fifteen years, was with him - the man who came with him said I was to give this man 30s. for the horse, and 1s. to him, for shewing him the slaughtering-house; I put a sovereign and a half into the prisoner's hand; I had scarcely done that, before I said to the other man."Why, do you know this man who has brought the horse?" he said he did not; I then said to the prisoner, "Give me my money back again, I have strong donbts on my mind that this is not right;" he immediately gave me back the money - I told him I should detain the horse and money - Mr. Monk was standing in the shed close by; he took him into the counting-house, and questioned him; he was perfectly satisfied that it was not correct, and told me to take him to the office; as we went along, he made a start, and attempted to escape; I, however secured him, and told him it was a folly to put himself in jeopardy for so trifling a thing; he said he had taken the horse from Mr. Wright, of King's Langley, who was a wealthy man, and could well afford to lose it - I took him to Lambeth-street; he said he was a poor man, and had taken the horse out of the field - we wrote that evening to Wright, of King's Langley, but got no answer - it is near Hemel Hempstead.
Prisoner. I told him no such thing; I said I was afraid it was a stolen horse, not that I had stolen it.

JOHN BALLARD
. King's Langley is below Watford; a great many miles from me.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been down at harvest-work, and as I came back on Saturday morning, I met a man in the road with this horse; he asked if I wished to buy it; I said, "I don't care, what do you ask for it?" he asked 35s.; I said, "I have 28s.;" he agreed to take it. I have witnesses who saw me buy the horse, and pay the money, if I had an opportunity of bringing them here.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 58.
There was another indictment against the prisoner for a like offence.

1734.
MARGARET BARRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 9 sovereigns, and 3 shillings, the monies of
Edward Maggs
, in the dwelling-house of
Andrew Clark
.

EDWARD MAGGS
. I was clerk to Mr. Woolmer, of Milk-street, but have left him about twelve months, and have since been with my brother-in-law, who is a cheesemonger. On the 1st of July, between ten and eleven o'clock, I was in Holborn - the prisoner, who was quite a stranger, accosted me; I was fool enough to go home with her - she took me to a house in Bell-court, Gray's Inn-lane
, to a room on the ground floor; I had had a glass or two of ale, but was not at all intoxicated - I am married, but have separated from my wife for nine months; I gave the prisoner 5s. before I went to bed; I had sixteen sovereigns and a half in my right-hand breeches pocket, 4s. or 5s. in silver, and a 5l. Bank note in a pocket-book in my coat pocket; I put my trousers between the bed and sacking; I went to sleep, and awoke a little before twelve o'clock - the prisoner was then out of bed - I heard money rattling; I immediately jumped out of bed, searched for my trousers, and they were gone; I immediately accused her of taking my money, and asked where my trousers were; she said,"Here are your trousers;" and gave them to me immediately; she was standing in a different part of the room, and must have had them in her hand when she spoke - I gave an alarm in the house - the watchman came and took her; she was dressing herself when this happened; she had got on her under clothes and stays - I do not know whether her gown was on; she had partly undressed when she came to bed - I believe her stays were off; when I first gave the alarm I said I had lost sixteen or seventeen sovereigns, but when I put my hand into my pocket I found seven and a half left, nine had been abstracted; on our way to the watch-house we met a constable, who asked the watchman if he had searched her; he said No; he took her into a public-house - I found nine sovereigns, 1ls., and 7 1/4d. on her; I had lost nine whole sovereigns.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not meet me and ask how I did? A. I said I did not know you; you asked me how I did - that is the truth; we were both in bed, and you got out from me.

FRANCIS BENNETT
. I am a watchman. I was called into the house and found the prisoner quite dressed; the prosecutor accused her of robbing him of sixteen sovereigns; he appeared to have his senses about him; the constable met us on the road to the watch-house - we took her into a public-house, and found nine sovereigns, 1ls., and 7 3/4d. on her; she said she had got the money in service.

CHRISTOPHER HINDLEY
. I am a constable. I met the prosecutor, and went with the prisoner - we searched her, and found nine sovereigns, 1ls., and 7 3/4d. on her; she said she got them in service.

The prisoner delivered in a long written Defence, stating that the prosecutor had met her and persuaded her to go to the house in question, and offered her any sum to consent to his wishes - that he got out of bed to feel for his money, and let some sovereigns fall, then he accused her of stealing them.

EDWARD MAGGS
. There is no truth in this; I was asleep - I awoke, and found her out of bed; she took me to the house - I did not know it was in existence.
GUILTY (of stealing only) . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1755.
WILLIAM NEWITT
,
ROBERT DENNINGTON
, and
WILLIAM WILLIAMS
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , at St. Mary, Islington, 30 sheep, price 50l. , the property of
John Thompson
.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM GORDON
. I am in the service of Mr.
John Thompson
; I am the gate-keeper - he is proprietor of the cattle-layers , in Liverpool-road, Islington
; they are used for the reception of cattle going to Smithfield-market. On Sunday, the 2nd of August, I received a flock of sheep on account of Mr. Neal - the flock consisted of seventy-one sheep of the Leicestershire breed; there was one black one among them - I saw them last about half-past twelve o'clock at night; I them moved them out of one pen into another and counted them twice; there were seventy-one - I fastened the pen and left it; I went again next morning, about half-past seven o'clock, they were all gone then, they had been fetched away; thirty sheep were worth between 50l. and 60l.; I have since had twenty-seven sheep skins from Howell, on the 5th of August, from the watch-house by the Regent's-park; I delivered twenty-one to Mr. Griffith, a skin sales-man, and have the other six here; I gave them to Limbrick, the officer - I received the sheep into my possession on account of my master, Mr. Thompson.

RICHARD LEE
. I am in the employ of Mr. Robinson. On Sunday afternoon I saw these seventy-one sheep in Thompson's layer; on Monday, the 3rd of August, I was directed by Swingler, Mr. Neal's man, to go up to the layer at five o'clock; I found forty-one sheep there - thirty were gone; I had noticed a black one there on the Sunday - that was gone among the thirty.

JOHN HOLLOWAY
. I am a butcher, and live at No. 6, Tower-street, Newport-market; I know the prisoner Newitt. On Monday morning, the 3rd of August, about five minutes before six o'clock, he came and knocked at my door; I was not up - my wife let him in; he asked me if I could work - I told him my feet were very bad, I did not know that I could; but he wished me to go very much, and said he would satisfy me for my trouble if I would go - he told me he had sent some things to Mr. Johnson, No. 92, Edgware-road.

Q. Come, Sir, was there a black sheep? A. There was a kind of blackish cast sheep; I cannot say it was a black one - I believe Newitt stuck one or two of them himself; but I was engaged in dressing them and took no notice particularly. Newitt said he wished to get them dead soon that they might get stiff, as he wanted to send them to market; we got done between five and six o'clock I think, but cannot exactly say the time: Newitt did not stay till we had done; he left in the morning: I did not see him again till about six, when I saw him at the public-house next door to Johnson's - Wincott and Poultice were there, and Newitt, I believe, paid them for their work; he paid them 3s. or 3s. 6d., I believe, but I cannot exactly say, as I did not count the money. I saw Newitt again that evening, in a cart near the Hop-pole public-house, Edgware-road; it might be between six and seven - a person named Clark was in the cart with him and a little girl; I got into the cart: there was a sack in it containing some substance, but I did not look inside it - I believe it was fat, but cannot say; I believe there were some skins in the cart; they were sheep or lamb skins - we went down to Clare-market in the cart, to Mr. Sadler's; the sack was taken out and delivered into Sadler's - I cannot exactly say whether Clark or Newitt took it out - next day, Tuesday, about six or seven o'clock in the evening, I was at the Green Man public-house, Coal-yard, Drury-lane, and saw Newitt there; other people were in the house - I cannot exactly say who; Newitt then paid me for my trouble.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. About six in the morning you saw somebody drive the sheep into this place? A. Yes, it was broad day-light. I said at the office that my belief was that neither Williams nor Dennington were the men; I believe neither of them are the men I saw.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you known Newitt long? A. Some years; there was no concealment in the transaction; it all took place in open daylight - I cannot tell how far Newitt's house is from Islington, but I suppose about three miles and a half; I havealways understood that he was labouring under dropsy, and he has been rather lumpy, like other butchers; he cannot walk very fast - I did not notice the sheep skins so as to know them again, and cannot speak to them; my business was to dress the sheep.

GEORGE CLARK
. I live in Little Grove-street, Lisson-grove; and am a porter, and keep a horse and cart - I have known Newitt many years. On Sunday evening, the 2nd of August, I saw him at my house - two of the Johnsons' were at my house at the time - Newitt said to Johnson, that as he was out of business, he must do something for a livelihood, and he would buy a few sheep, if he could have a place to carcase them: Johnson told him if he did buy any, to send them to his house and he would kill them for him - he said nothing about killing them at my place, I believe: I might say I had no place that would do - I went to Johnson's next evening with my yokes and pails to fetch some offal for my pigs; I had my pails full of offal and was coming away, when I saw Newitt - he said he wished me to go home with the offal, and then to bring my horse and cart to take away the fat and skins; I took my horse and cart there: my little boy was in it - the fat and skins were put in by some of the men who had been employed; I did not count the skins - they threw them in any how; Newitt was there: they said there was a certain number - I cannot say whether Newitt was there then.

COURT. Q. Did they mention any number, and if so was it in Newitt's presence? A. I do not think he was there - I saw the skins put in, but did not count them; I never had such things in my cart before, and do not know how many there were - there were above twenty, I am confident; I think there were about twenty, or above - there were above twenty; Newitt told me I was to go first to Clare-market with the fat, and the skins were to go to the foot of Blackfriars-bridge; Newitt and my boy went in the cart with me - we took Holloway up at the Hop-pole, in Edgware-road, and got to Sadler's fat house in Clare-market, about seven o'clock; we had all the fat taken out - I went up into the loft to see it weighed - it weighed 30st. 1 lb., I think; while I was there I saw three sovereigns given, I think by young Mr. Sadler, to Newitt in part payment - I had left the skins in the cart at the door; while I was in the house my little boy, who was standing at the door, sang out, "Father, father, somebody has taken our Peggy away;" that is the name of our horse - Newitt was at that time down below, just where the boy was; I went down, and the horse and cart were gone - I found Newitt there, and asked why he took the horse and cart away without my consent or knowledge; he said why did I bring my little boy with me for, I would not do to go with the cart - I abused him very much for taking the cart away; he said, "Never mind, it will be all right bye and bye when the cart will meet us in Holborn" - I went to a public-house in the market with him and Sadler's man; I and my boy then walked with Newitt to the White Horse, Holborn - he said the horse and cart would meet us at that public-house; it came after we got there - I suppose that was about an hour and a half after it had been taken from Clare-market; I cannot positively say who the person was who got out of the cart when it returned, whether it was one or two, but I saw a party go across the road - there were no skins in the cart then; I parted with Newitt directly I got my cart, and went away - Newitt told me to be sure to be in time at Johnson's next morning for the sheep, to take them to Newgate-market; I went there next morning, about half-past five o'clock - I was to have been there at five; twenty sheep were put into my cart there to go to Newgate-market; fourteen were taken to Mr. Pocklinton's, and six to Chandler's, both in Newgate-market - they were left there in Newitt's name.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you make any particular observation of the skins? A. No, not to know them again.
COURT. Q. When you came down stairs, after weighing the fat, was the cart gone out of sight? A. Yes; I cannot say who went in it.

JOHN HOLLOWAY
re-examined. Q. When you came to Clare-market, and the fat was taken out, what became of you? A. I went up to the White Horse, Holborn, as Newitt told me if I would go there he would give me something to drink, and pay me for my work - I left the cart standing in the market, and do not know what became of it.

JURY. Q. Is it not usual to be paid at so much a head for dressing sheep? A. Yes; my work was 1 1/4d. a head, but I had to go backward and forward for a man to assist and he gave me 5s. for my trouble, without mentioning the number of sheep, and I did not count them.

JOHN ODDWELL
. I am in the service of Clark. I took twenty sheep from Johnson's, in Edgware-road; on the Tuesday morning, and after I returned I took three more to Mr. Basson's, St. Ann's-court - I left them there for Newitt.

JOSEPH JOHNSON
. I am in the employ of my brother, who is a butcher in Edgware-road. On Sunday evening, I was at Clark's house; Newitt was there - I got up next morning about a quarter to eight o'clock, and found some sheep at the house - my brother called me; there were thirty sheep, but I never counted them - one of the drovers, I think, told me there were thirty; I saw the prisoner Dennington as one of the drovers of the sheep that morning - there were three men with the sheep when I got up; Holloway was one - I cannot speak to the person of the third; there was one which we term a black sheep - it had a black face, and was black in the neck - I considered them Leicestershire sheep; one of the men said, "Poke that black b-r in, and that will frighten all the rest." Dennington was there then, but whether it was him used that expression, I cannot say; the sheep were got in - I was not there while they were being killed - I met Newitt by St. Giles's pound about ten o'clock, in a cart, as I was going to Smithfield with my brother; he was going in a direction to my brother's house - he got out, and I said to him, "You have been as good as your word, you have sent thirty sheep home;" he said, Yes -I asked him who he traded with; he told me he bought them of Ebb - I know a person of that name who deals in sheep; I said, "How did you come on?" meaning, how did he buy them - he said he thought he had bought them rather too dear, but he did not know how they would turn out; we had something to drink together at thepound, and parted - I went on to market, and he to my brother's; I saw him again about seven o'clock in the evening at my brother's - the sheep had been killed then, and all hung out of doors in public view; he did not say what he meant to do with them - he asked if I would buy any; I agreed that I should have a couple at whatever he might sell the others at market - he had told Clark to come for the offal; I was to buy two sheep for whatever the others fetched at market - it was not said in my presence what was to be done with the rest; I know Mr. Nicholl, and saw him at my brother's next morning -Newitt was there, and sold him two sheep; I remember some of the sheep were double-lined, as we term them - it is customary for butchers in general to put a mark of their own on them; I do not consider that these had any butcher's mark.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you take any particular notice of the skins? A. No, I should not like to swear to them. I have known Newitt seventeen or eighteen years; I am certain he was not the third person who drove the sheep in.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. At what time did you first see the sheep? A. About a quarter to eight; my brother's name is William - he had been up before me, and came up to call me; his daughter was up before him, and she called him - they had a better opportunity of seeing the sheep and the men than I did; I had not been acquainted with Dennington - I have seen him at work at Smithfield before among a variety of drovers, but never spoke to him; I conceived it to be a fair and open transaction - there was no concealment about it; I was not desired to say nothing about it - the sheep were exposed as publicly as possible when dressed.
MR. BODKIN. Q. How far are Thompson's layers from Johnson's? A. Nearly three miles, I should think; I have no doubt of Dennington being one of the men.

FREDERICK FRY
. I am sometimes called Poultice - I am a butcher and porter, and live in Newgate-market. I know Holloway, and remember going with him to Johnson's, in Edgeware-road, on a Monday in August to kill some sheep - thirty were killed; I assisted - I cannot say what breed they were; Wincott was there - he skinned them; I legged them all but two; I have since been shewn twenty-seven skins by Limbrick - I examined them, but cannot say whether they are the skins of the sheep which were killed that morning, but they were in the same way as I generally leg sheep; there was one black sheep, and there was the skin of a black sheep among those shewn to me, and only one.

Q. On your oath, I ask what your belief is as to to their being the skins of the sheep you killed? A. I do not know them any more than by legging them, and there was a black sheep among them, but I do not know by the legging whether they are the skins or not - I cannot say whether they are or are not the same: I believe they are the skins, but the only reason I have is that they are legged as I leg them, and there was a black one.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What do you mean by legging? A. Skinning the fore and hind quarters; other persons may leg them in the same way.

HENRY WINCOTT
. I am a butcher. On Monday, the 3rd of August, I went with Holloway and Poultice to kill some sheep at Johnson's, in Edgware-road; we killed thirty - there was a black one among them; Newitt is the person who paid me for killing them - he was there part of the time I was killing them.

GEORGE FRACKELTON
. I am clerk to Mr. Pocklington, a salesman. I paid the prisoner Newitt 23l. 1s. 5d. for fourteen sheep, sold for him on the 14th of August.

WILLIAM FRANCIS JOHNSON
. I am a butcher, and live in the Edgware-road. I remember thirty sheep being brought to my house on the 3rd of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning; they were Leicestershire sheep: one was a black one: two men accompanied them- Williams was one of them; Newitt came to my house that day - I advised him to kill only ten, and send the others out to field; he said he thought he should kill about fifteen, but when I came home they were all killed; it being hot whether I thought it not right to kill them all- when they came Williams said he had brought some sheep for Mr. Newitt.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How often were you examined at the office? A. Twice, or, I believe, three times; I said at the two first examinations, that I could not swear to Williams, but said at the third examination I could.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You were up before your brother that morning? A. Yes; my little girl called me - I did not take particular notice of the sheep - it did not strike me that there was any thing wrong.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Explain how it is you can swear to Williams? A. The first time I was examined I saw his full face, and said I could not positively swear to his being the man; at the second examination I was not asked any thing about him, but when I came out of the office, having seen his side face, I told Limbrick I was satisfied he was the man; I have not the least doubt of him now.

FRANCES JOHNSON
. I am Johnson's daughter. I remember thirty sheep coming to my father's house, about seven o'clock in the morning; I opened the door - Dennington was there (pointing to him) - the sheep were not there then; Dennington said was that Mr. Johnson's - I said Yes; he said the sheep were a little higher up, and he would go and fetch them - I saw them brought in; there was a black one among them: I went and told my father.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you no doubt about Dennington? A. No; I did not know him before - he was not pointed out to me at the office; I pointed him out - the Magistrate told me his name; my uncle pointed over to Dennington just now, while I was looking about; I have always told the same story about this - I have said it was on a Friday that the sheep came, and I say so now; I have no more doubt of that than I have of Dennington's person.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Whether it was Friday or not, was it the same day as the sheep were killed? A. Yes; I saw Mr. Newitt there.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How soon afterwards did you see the man? A. He was about half an hour gone for the sheep - I saw the same man again on a Tuesday, not the next Tuesday; it was a fortnight or more after - I had never seen Dennington before; I only saw one person come with the sheep myself - I was standing on the stairs when they drove them in; my uncle and father were presentwhen I saw Dennington in the shop - I am quite sure it was Friday.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Was when you were before the Magistrate the first time you saw Dennington after that? A. Yes - the Magistrate pointed him out then; I had pointed him out myself before the Magistrate told me his name - the Magistrate then said his name was Dennington - there were four people at the office when I pointed him out; there were no more prisoners there - he stood at the end of the bar; there were other people standing at the end of the bar; I was not told the people who had been at our house were standing there - only one person besides him stood at the end of the bar; nobody had told me he was the man.

COURT. Q. You opened the door to Dennington - did you continue in the shop, or go up stairs? A. I stood on the stairs, about an hour, while they were driving them in; the door opens into the shop - I could see the shop from the stairs; my uncle and father came into the shop; I called them while he was gone for the sheep - when they were driven in Dennington came into the shop, so did my uncle and father; I saw no other man came in, nor did I see any body outside; I stood on the stairs till they were driven in- I never saw thirty sheep come into my father's at any other time.

JOHN LEGGATT
. I keep the Green Man, Coal-yard, Drury-lane. I know the three prisoners. On Tuesday afternoon, the 4th of August, I saw the three prisoners and Holloway in company at my house; I changed a 5l. note for Newitt - he asked me to take four sovereigns to go out, and return, pretending I had been out to borrow it for him- he gave me no reason for that; he said he did not wish the men to know he had any more money; they were at my house four or five hours together, in company - I did not receive the reckoning, and do not know who paid; he told me to pretend I had borrowed the sovereigns of a man named Bonington, the landlord of the house he lives in; I went into the shop, came out, and carried four sovereigns to him in the tap-room.

COURT. Q. When he gave you the 5l. note, where was he? A. In front of the bar; Williams and Dennington were in the tap-room. and could not hear or see any thing of it; when I brought the four sovereigns he was in the tap-room, sitting with them, and I gave them to him there- he asked me after I changed the 5l. note if I would take care of a good deal of money for him - I spoke to my wife, and she would have nothing to do with it; he had a good deal of money, and put it into his fob - he had between 100l. and 200l. about him, for he asked me if I would take care of between 100l. and 200l. for him.

ANN KING
. I am Leggatt's niece. On Monday, the 3rd of August, between one and two o'clock, Dennington and Williams came in together, and had beef-steaks at our house; they staid rather better than half an hour; I do not remember who paid - I never saw them before; I saw them again on Tuesday - Newitt and Williams were with them then; I do not know at what time they came on Tuesday.

JESSY SURBY
. I am a painter, and live at Mr. Bonington's Coal-yard, Drury-lane. Newitt lodged in the second floor back room, and I live in the first floor back room. On Monday, the 3rd of August, at three o'clock in the morning, there was a knocking at the door; I looked out of window and saw two persons - they were Williams and Dennington; they asked me if Mr. Newitt was at home - I think it was Williams spoke; I said I believed he was - I went up and called him; he came down, and went out about five minutes after I called him, but I cannot say whether they all went together - I went to hed again - I saw Newitt again, at home, about twelve o'clock that day; I saw him next day at the Green Man, Coal-yard, with Williams, Dennington, and Holloway - they were all drinking together that afternoon; I had seen Dennington and Williams before that morning, and had spoken to them five or six times before.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Newitt lived at the house? A. Yes; he is married. I saw Williams and Dennington go away when I gave them the answer at the window; I did not see Newitt go out - I saw him at his bed-room door when I called him; he appeared as if he had just got of bed - I did not stay at the window above a minute; I only gave the answer to each person - I cannot say whether Dennington and Williams came back and talked with Newitt at the street-door; I have heard Newitt complain of dropsy before this happened - he was very much swollen; I have not observed it affect him so as to prevent him making any great exertion - I heard him go up again, and dress himself afterwards, and go down again in five minutes; he was up stairs long enough to dress, and he went out - I did not see him go out, but I heard the street-door shut directly after he went down; I heard him go down when I called him, heard him go up again, and then down, and never heard him go up again.
