Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. There can be no mistake about time? A. No - I heard the clock strike during the time I was out of bed; I do not suppose I was out of bed three minutes altogether - I do not burn a light; it was not very dark - the moon was -

Q. Will you swear it was a moonlight morning? A. It was moonlight and daylight together, so that I could distinguish - I will not swear it was moonlight; I cannot say there was a moon - it was not clear daylight at the time.

Q. Why did you say there was a moon? A. Because I could not recollect whether it was daylight or not; I did not see the moon, and will not swear there was one - it was so far daylight that I can swear to the prisoner's if you put them among 20,000 men; it was both daylight and moonlight together - it was not raining then; I did not look to see if the ground was et - one man stood answering me, and the other a little distance off; I only looked at the mens' faces, their appearance and dress - I took particular notice of them; I do not know whether there was a moon or not - I did not see it; it was between daylight and moonlight, because I know it was about the time the moon was up - my recollection is furnished by a knowledge of the state of the moon and the night; it was the third quarter - I am sure of that; I do not know when the moon was new - I calculate from the last time of the new moon, that it was the third quarter; I do not know when it was new, only from seeing it full on Sunday or Saturday night last - I will not swear it was the third quarter; I swear I have not sworn it was.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Had you any expectation of beingexamined on the state of the weather? A. No - there was light enough for me to distinguish their persons, and I am certain of them; I told them Newitt would be down directly, and then they went away from the door - they came to the door; I did not hear the street-door open the first time Newitt went down - he came up in about two minutes, or two minutes and a half, and I heard him go down again in about two minutes and a half; I then heard the door shut, and did not hear him return up.

COURT. Q. The moment they came to the door they asked if Newitt was at home? A. Yes - I said I believed he was; they asked me to call him - I went up and told him two men at the door wanted to speak to him; he came, opened his door, and told me to tell them he would be down directly - I told them so, and did not see any more of them; I heard him come down stairs directly -I did not hear him open the door or speak to them; I heard him come up again - I heard him moving about in his room over head, and go down in about two minutes and a half, and heard the front door shut; I had not heard it opened - I think it was possible for him to dress and come down in the two minutes and a half he was up stairs.
JURY. Q. Did you know the two prisoners before? A. Yes - I had seen them four or five different times, and have spoken to them in the street.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When had you last a job of painting? A. The last job I did was for Mr. Leggatt, the witness, at a house in West-street, Walworth - he paid me for the job; I began it on the 5th of August - it took six days; I came here to day with Leggatt - we did not go before the Magistrate together; I was summoned there - I had told Bonington, the landlord, and Leggatt, what I knew; Mrs. Bonington told Limbrick I was the person who answered them from the window.

WILLIAM GORDEN
. The layers at Islington are about two miles from the middle of Drury-lane.

GEORGE GRIFFITH HOWELL
. I am keeper of the watch-house in Albany-street, Regent's-park. On the 3rd of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, a man, who is not here, brought in a sheep skin, and about five next morning, a watchman, who is not here, brought in another - I kept them both, and went on the Tuesday morning, between seven and eight o'clock, to take a walk by the Regent's-canal, and found a parcel of sheep skins in a heap: I was with my horsepatrol, and in the evening be fetched them to the watch-house - there were twenty-five; there was one black skin among them - I gave the twenty-seven skins to William Gordon; Clare-market is about two miles from that spot - none of the skins were entirely in the water, but on the bank; one of them hung on the butment of the bridge - they appeared to have been thrown over carelessly.

JOHN HOPKINS
. I am a horse-patrol. On the morning of the 4th of August, I was with Howell, when the skins were found in the canal; I took possession of them in the afternoon - there were twenty-five; I delivered them at the green-yard belonging to the watch-house -Howell was there; I did not find them exactly in the same situation as in the morning - the day-watchman had turned them over; I knew they were the same - I just turned them over in the morning; there was one black one.

JOHN SWINGLER
. I am in the employ of Mr. Neal. On Sunday night, the 3rd of August I took a flock of seventy-one sheep, by his direction, to Mr. Thompson's layer - they were Leicestershire breed; I noticed the marks on the skins - I saw six skins in Limbrick's possession at the office, and can take upon myself to say they are the skins of six of these sheep - there was a black one in the flock, and a black skin among those.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. It was on Sunday night; do you remember whether it was a rainy night? A. I think not; it would be neither light nor dark at three o'clock in the morning - it would be break of day.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. I apprehended Williams in Drury-lane, on Saturday the 29th of August - Hall was with me; I received twenty-seven sheep skins from Gordon, and have preserved six of them; I showed them to Swingler - I have been to Thompson's layers - I suppose it is full a mile or a mile and a quarter from the Coal-yard - it may be two miles.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you recollect what weather it was about the beginning of August? A. I cannot say; I do not suppose it would be quite dark at three o'clock.

WILLIAM BOND
. I am a constable. On Friday, the 28th of August, I apprehended Newitt at the Wellington, Wellington-street, Pentonville; he said he was not sorry he was apprehended; he intended to give himself up - this was nearly a month after the robbery - Pentonville joins Islington.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you ask why he was about to give himself up? A. No.

Q. Did he not tell you that whatever he knew of the business, he was not concerned in stealing the sheep? A. I cannot say that he did - I will not swear he did not - he had no conversation with Limbrick that I know of; he appeared very infirm, and swollen with dropsy much more than he is now - I should think it would be difficult for him to walk five miles together.

MR. PHILLIPS to
JOHN LIMBRICK
. Q. I believe you saw Newitt some time after he was apprehended; did he not appear in such a state of bodily infirmity that any great exertion would be fatal? A. I conceive so.

JOHN BASHAM
. I am a butcher. On the 3rd of August I was going down Holborn, towards Newgate-market, and saw Newitt - I had had some dealings with him about sheep - he accompanied me down Holborn towards Newgate-market, and I saw him several times in the market; he was walking about there, attending to his business.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you observe the state in which his body was? A. Yes, I observed it very big; he walked feeble and infirmly.

JURY to
JESSY SURBY
. Q. Was there any gas-light near the house, so that you could distinguish the party? A. There was a gas-light at our door attached to the house, close to the front door.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you ever at Marlborough-street Office? A. Yes, once - I was not charged with doing any thing - there was no accusation made against me of stealing a watch; I had a ticket of a watch in my possession which had been stolen, not knowing it to bestolen - I gave it up to the officer, and got nothing for it; I was discharged directly.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you mean to mix the gaslight with the day and moonlight? A. No; it did assist me to see the prisoners - I did not mention it, because I was not asked - I have not said there was "daylight" enough; the daylight assisted the gaslight - I lived in Smart's-buildings when I had the duplicate - I have lived three years in that house.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Why did you leave there? A. Because the woman who lived there went into the almshouse - a Mr. Cave took it, and ordered all the lodgers out; I went from there to where I now live; it was twelve months ago last February, and have lived there ever since.
NEWITT'S Defence. I can prove that from six o'clock in the morning till ten in the day what became of me - I did not go out of the house till six o'clock in the morning of the 3rd of August.
Dennington's Defence. Respecting Johnson saying he never spoke to me, I have spoken to him several times in his brother's shop, near Ray-street.

Williams' Defence. At the time I was apprehended Johnson said he never knew me; he said it was a dark, short, swarthy man, and I was not the man at all. On the day of my apprehension, Waddington came and said I was wanted; I said directly, "Shall I come now?" he said No, he did not want me now, by and bye would do; I said I would go directly, or wait at home for him at my mother's; I waited there for about an hour; he never came: I went out to sell my plums, and then Limbrick came - I told him I was just coming to him to know what he wanted of me, as I had just done my plums.

ANN JOHNSON
. In August last I lived in the same house with the prisoner Newitt; Surby lives in the back room first floor, and I in the front room on the same floor. On Monday morning, the 3rd of August, I heard three knocks at the street door - Surby went up to Newitt's room, and I heard Newitt go down stairs - I heard Newitt go up again and shut his room door (but I did not hear the street door shut) - I did not hear him go down again.

HANNAH BONINGTON
. I am landlady of the house Newitt and Surby lived in in August last. On Monday, the 3rd of August, I saw Newitt at three o'clock in the morning, and I saw him again about six - I then met him in the passage of the house going into the yard, where there is a privy - he appeared as if he had just got up in a hurry, with his stockings down, and the knees of his breeches not tied; he appeared to be going to the water-closet; he had been infirm and dropsical for some time before.

MR. BODKIN. Q. How long had he lived at your house? A. About ten days before, but I had known him about twelve months - he had kept a butcher's shop; I was not particularly intimate with him; I used not to walk out with him - I cannot swear I never went out with him, as he came to my house on a Saturday, and I went out with him on Sunday; at least I and my husband met him, and he said he was going to Lisson-grove, we went with him; I have not been out with him since, to my knowledge - I do not know the Castle in Holborn; I have not been to a public-house in Holborn with him since the robbery, to my knowledge; I am not bound to swear what I am not convinced of; I have not been out with him since the robbery to my knowledge; I do not know the other two prisoners - I cannot swear to them; I cannot swear I never saw them at my house - to the best of my knowledge I have not; I do not undertake to swear any thing of the kind - the officer came to my house a great many times; Newitt was not in my house when Limbrick came - I never saw any officer but him there; I was at home three or four times when he came - Hall came with Limbrick afterwards; Newitt was not in the house at any time when the officer came, that I will swear.

Q. The first time you saw Newitt was about three o'clock? A. Yes; I was up then, for my husband, when he gets liquor (which is not very often) is like a madman, and I am afraid to go to bed with him, and sit up - he was at home and in bed at this time; I was up and dressed, and about three o'clock Newitt came down stairs; I heard Surby call him - my door was shut, it is close to the street door; my room is on the ground floor - my door continued shut all the time; I saw Newitt going up stairs; I did not consider that he had shut the street door after he had answered somebody, and I opened my door; I went out to see if it was shut and fastened, and it was fastened - I turned towards the staircase and saw Newitt going up stairs; he had nothing on but a pair of dark or black trousers; I had not heard him speak to any body at the door - I did not go to bed at all; I did not hear him come down again, to the best of my knowledge; I do not think he ever went out of the house; I have had some conversation with Surby - I told him I considered he was telling very great falsehoods in saying the man went out, for I did not go to bed, and was certain he did not go out.

Q. On your oath, did you not say to Surby that you recollected seeing Newitt come in the morning, at a quarter to eight o'clock, with his shoes all over dust? A. I take my oath I never did, nor any thing of the sort; I saw Newitt again about six o'clock - our men knock at the door about six, some of them came rather before six - it was not about five or ten minutes after that I saw him; it was shortly after six, for our men are very punctual - I was giving the key of the street door when I met Newitt, just as if he had come from his bed; it was not above five or ten minutes after six - he was partly undressed; my house is five or ten minutes walk from Newport-market.
Q. Then he could not be out and dressed, calling on a man in Newport-market, before six o'clock? A. I cannot say; that is the time I saw him.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What is your husband? A. A coach-smith; Newitt's wife lived with him at our house - he never took any liberties with me; I was awake from three to six o'clock: I do not consider that I closed my eyes a moment - I sat not exceeding two yards from the street door; and from three to six o'clock heard nobody leave the house, nor any one come down stairs.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you not, on the 3rd of August, the day of the robbery, go with Newitt to the Castle in Holborn? A. I could not attempt to swear such a thing; I have drank with him on several occasions, when he lived in Rose-street and Turnstile - I have not told Mr. Oldershaw that I went on the 3rd of August with Newitt to the Castle; he asked me that question this morning: I told him I was not bound to answer such questions - I did not say I was there.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did Mr. Oldershaw ask you questions? A. Yes, two or three; I told him I was a witness for the prisoner; he and another gentleman questioned me outside.

JESSY SURBY re-examined. I have had some conversation with Mrs. Bouington about the robbery; she told me she heard Newitt go out of the door about five minutes past three o'clock on the Monday morning, and come in about a quarter to eight that morning with his shoes all over dust - I cannot say what day she stated this.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was any body present? A. Her sister; she told me that I was correct in my statement about his going out soon after three o'clock, and that he came in again about a quarter to eight with his shoes all over dust; she did not say I was a liar for stating what I had, nor any thing to that effect - I had been to Hatton-garden at the time of this conversation; I did not state this to any body - I did not mean to do it, till I heard she was going to appear against me, to try and transport me; I then thought I would peach her, and repeat every thing I knew - I have no spite towards her, nor ill feeling; I have a good will towards her, for I know she cannot transport me - she told me she heard Newitt speak to Dennington and Williams; I told Mr. Oldershaw, the attorney, so last Thursday - I do not know that peaching is a cant word; I know nothing about cant words - I have heard it several times; I heard it both before and after I got the watch ticket.

JURY. Q. Was it from a back room you answered the men? A. I sleep in the one pair back room - the knocking was at the front door; I went to the staircase window to answer them - there was a single knock first, and then a double one came, like a postman.

JOSEPH JOHNSON
. I should think it was about a quarter-past ten o'clock on Monday morning that I met Newitt - he told me he had bought the sheep of Mr. Ebb, who is a salesman of Smithfield-market; he has just gone down the steps of the Court - he is in the market regularly twice a week now.

WILLIAM EBB
. I am a sheep salesman, of Smithfield-market - I know no other salesman of my name in London; I have been a salesman more than twenty-five years- I know Newitt; I did not sell him any sheep in August last.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. To how many persons in August may you have sold sheep? A. I cannot state, probably within thirty of the number of persons, but I could tell within one whose names I have sold to on one particular day in August - I cannot tell within fifty of the persons I sold sheep to in August, not as to the number, but I can tell their names within one; I have no foreman, or any body who sells sheep for me - persons do sell for me when I am absent, but I was not absent in August during the hours for the sale of sheep; I will swear nobody sold sheep for me - I swear I was never absent for an hour during the hours of sale; my knowledge of persons to whom I sell is chiefly derived from my transactions with them- I could not identify every person I sold to; I cannot swear nobody bought sheep of me on Newitt's behalf, but I swear they did not buy in his name - if a man buys of me I give an account of them in the name of the buyer, and, in some instances, in the name who he should use; it is common for persons to buy for others - the name they buy for are entered, and if that name is not given to me I enter them in the name of the purchaser; I have sworn there is no other William Ebb in London, a salesman - I cannot say there is no other William Ebb; I do not know such a salesman, and will swear there is not one- no person can be a public salesman without my knowing it; there are a great many other public markets for the sale of sheep, but only one for the sale of live sheep in London - I know nothing about dead sheep; I do not mean to say live sheep may not be sold without my knowledge, but there is no other market for live animals - sheep may be sold in a lane; there is not a sheep salesman named
William Ebb
; there is no other market where salesmen attend for the sale of live sheep.

COURT. Q. How many market days are there in a week? A. Two, Monday and Friday; I recollect very well that I was in Smithfield on Monday, the 3rd of August; I did not sell thirty sheep to Newitt that day, nor any - I did not speak to him that day, to my knowledge; I have known him for five or six years - he has dealt with me; he formerly was a butcher; I do not know how long he has ceased to keep a shop, but I have not sold him any sheep this year; I did not sell thirty sheep to him, nor to any body in his name, on the 3d of August - it is both a ready money and credit market; the market hours are from four o'clock in the morning till three in the afternoon, or twenty minutes after; I attend generally within twenty minutes under or over five - no sales of sheep take place before I get there; I have been at Smithfield-market every Monday, for the last twenty years, and every lot of sheep, amounting to twenty-five, I have sold myself on all those Mondays - no agent or person has been deputed to act for me on a Monday; each buyer who pays for sheep, goes and enters his name in the money taker's office - so many sheep, such a price; I sell sheep on commission for any body who sends them - I never sold sheep for Newitt, except half a dozen once because he was absent; he is a salesman himself.

RICHARD LEE
. I went to take the sheep to market - thirty were missing; I took the rest to Smithfield - Mr. Neal was there to sell them himself.
Ten witness gave Newitt a good character, two deposed to that of Dennington, and one to that of Williams.

NEWITT - GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 36.

DENNINGTON - GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21.

WILLIAMS - GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury, on account of their characters .
Second Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Baron Vaughan.

1756.
THOMAS HOLLINGSWORTH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , 2 tray-stands, value 16s.; 1 piece of carpet, value 35s.; and 5 hearthrugs, value 7l.; the goods of
Samuel Hollingsworth
, in his dwelling-house .

SAMUEL HOLLINGSWORTH
. I live in Bedford-street, Bedford-row
, and am an upholder . The prisoner is my son, and assisted in the business; he absconded from my house on the 13th of June.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. How many more sons have you? A. Five. He is my second son; I have five daughters also - the eldest went out to a situation amonth or two before the prisoner absconded; the others are mere children - I did not pay the prisoner wages; I provided him with food and clothing.

Q. Is it true that you allowed him and your daughter one shilling a day for their support? A. It is not true; they fared with me - I maintained the prisoner; at the time he absconded I missed property to a large amount and a cheque for 34l., in fact, property of every description: they robbed me of every thing.
COURT. Q. You say "they," as if others were concerned? A. I only say that from a letter written to me by my son - I had no reason to suspect he was going to leave me till he went.

RICHARD ROSS
. I am shopman to Mr. Tunis, a pawnbroker, of Liquor-pond-street. Here are five hearth-rugs, pawned by the prisoner, between the 2nd and 23rd of May - he came alone; I advanced 10s. on some, and less on others.
Cross-examined. Q. This is more than three months ago? A. Yes, I am certain he is the man.

SAMUEL HOLLINGSWORTH
. I have no doubt of these being my property - I never sold them.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you not a large stock of such articles? A. Yes - my porter has been convicted of stealing articles of this description; I have not sold rugs of exactly this pattern.
COURT. Q. Have you any recollection of seeing that property about, shortly before May? A. Yes: it is a particular pattern, which I do not suppose could be got.

MR. BARRY. Q. Do you manufacture them? A. No- it is an old pattern, which has been out of work many years; it was made expressly for me - I have not sold any of this pattern for years, and had but this one; these rugs had a shop-ticket on them.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner up on the 9th of July; he said he was very sorry, and that the porter and his wife had brought him into this trouble; this was on his being charged with stealing carpet and rugs.

Cross-examined. Q. Was his father present? A. He was; I made him no promise or threat; the father had no private interview with him to my knowledge - he told me this at No. 50, Baldwin's-gardens: he was in a wretched plight when I took him - I do not know of his being married.
Prisoner's Defence. I was forced to do it, for my father kept me short on Saturday, during his absence.
GUILTY (of stealing to the value of 99s. only.) Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Year .
First London Jury - Before Mr. Recorder.

1757.
JOHN EDMONDS
. was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 bag, value 18d.; 1 coat, value 5l.; 3 waistcoats, value 3l. 3s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 2l. 5s., and 1 pair of braces, value 2s., the goods of
Philip McKenzie
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 14.(See page 781.)

1758.
ALEXANDER GUYON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 11 handkerchiefs, value 27s. , the goods of
Robert Plant
.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1759.
MARY FITZGERALD
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .
MESSRS. BOLLAND, and SCARLETT conducted the prosecution.

ANN CRAMPTON
. I am niece to
Joseph Pullen
, who keeps the Blue Last public-house, in Broadway, Blackfriars
. On the 16th of July the prisoner came in, and had a glass of porter, which came to 1 1/2d. - she gave me a shilling; I saw it was counterfeit, and laid it on a shelf over the engine, by itself - she came again in about half an hour, had another glass of porter, and paid me a shilling; I laid that by the other, as I suspected it, but being alone in the bar, and my uncle not at home, I could not detain her - he came in in half an hour, and I gave him both the shillings; he laid them on the same shelf again, apart from any others; they laid there till the 27th of July, when the prisoner came again, about a quarter to ten o'clock at night, in company, and asked for a glass of porter and a glass of gin; she paid for both with a shilling - I told her it was counterfeit, and it made four counterfeit shillings which she had passed at our house; she said it was quite unknown to her if they were counterfeit - I gave Mr. Pullen that shilling; a constable was sent for, and took her in charge; I marked that shilling directly I took it - I gave the constable three shillings, only one of them was what she had paid me before; the other had been mislaid - one of those I gave the constable I had from Mrs. Pullen.
Prisoner. I did not know they were bad; I said if it was bad I was willing to change it. Witness. She said so at the watch-house, but not before.

SARAH PULLEN
. I am the wife of Mr. Pullen. On the 27th of July, at a quarter-past nine o'clock at night, the prisoner came in alone, and had a glass of porter - she paid me a shilling; I gave her 10 1/2d., and she left - I put the shilling by itself, and gave it to Camplin.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not put it into a drawer? A. I put it into a part of the till where there was no silver whatever.

JOSEPH PULLEN
. My niece gave me two shillings which she had received; I put them in the bar, and gave them to her again.

SAMUEL DOWDNEY
. I am a constable. I was sent for on the 27th of July, and took the prisoner; I received from Crampton three counterfeit shillings, which I produce- I have kept them separate ever since; I diligently searched the prisoner in the watch-house, and found on her 3s. 6d. in good silver, and 1s. worth of copper.

WILLIAM CRAMPTON
. These are the shillings; I know them by the marks I put on them.

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of coin at His Majesty's Mint. These shillings are all counterfeit, and are cast, two from one mould, and one from another.
The prisoner delivered in a written Defence, declaring she was not conscious of the money being counterfeit, and that she had received them in the street, where she sold thread and tape.

JURY to MRS. PULLEN. Q. What was your reason for putting the shilling in the till? A. I thought she was the person who had passed bad money before, and I put it there separate from any other; I took it out as soon as she went out, which was in a moment.
GUILTY . Aged 29.

Confined One Year , and
to find Sureties .

1760.
GILBERT WITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , at St. Ann, Blackfriars, 60 sovereigns, 30 half-sovereigns, 112 shillings, 4 half-crowns, 1 crown, 1 sixpence, 1 order for payment of and value 28l. 15s., and one 40l. Bank note, the property of
George
Le Boutillier
, in the dwelling-house of
Robert John Banyon
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE LE BOUTILLIER
. I am a clerk in the Norwich Union Life and Fire Insurance office, and an agent at Islington
- the business is carried on in Bridge-street, Blackfriars
; I receive money as an agent for Islington. On the 13th of July I had in my possession a sum of money which I had received - I put it into a tin cash-box; there was a 40l. Bank-note, a cheque for 28l. 15s., 75l. in sovereigns and half-sovereigns, more sovereigns than halves, 6l. 7s. 6d. in silver, two bills of exchange for 22l. 17s. 6d. and 17l. 16s, an I. O. U. for 5l., and this memorandum on a piece of paper, "Pleas 8s. 6d., and 3s. 6d. coach;" both these items were on one piece of paper written with my own hand, and it was in the box- the prisoner was on trial in the office as clerk - I was at the office at Bridge-street, and at four o'clock I handed the box to Mr. Tolkein in the office, who I saw deposit it in the iron safe - he locked it, and put the key in his pocket in my presence; there are inner and outer doors to the safe - only the inner doors were locked; I went out immediately, and did not go to the office any more that night; the sovereigns had been marked some time before the 13th by Mr. Howell, our surveyor - I saw some of them marked; they had been in the box above a month - I had not delivered out any of the marked sovereigns; I did not return to the office till ten o'clock next morning - Mr. Tolkein then went to the safe in my presence to take the cash-boxes out - he took the key out of his pocket, put it to the lock, and found the doors had been opened - my money-box was gone; it was a tin one - the money was in a kind of false bottom in the box -Mr. Marriott came, and examined the lock of the chest; I have seen some of the sovereigns since, and am certain they are some of the same as I had seen marked - I am positive they are the same; I have also seen the memorandum of the 8s. 6d. and 3s. 6d. - they were shown to me at the Mansion-house on the Monday following (the 13th was Monday) I never had a doubt of their being mine - Mr. Cope had been employed.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. How long had this lad been employed in the office? A. I suppose from five to six months - he continued to come there after the property was lost, and was taken into custody on the Saturday, at his father's house; I think the iron safe belongs to the Company; the different clerks deposit money there - I did not collect this money as a clerk, but as an agent myself; I did not deposit it there on account of the Company - I pay it over perhaps five or six months after; the marked sovereigns had been there more than a month - nobody but myself took money from that box; I took the key of the box away in my pocket - Mr. Tolkein had the key of the safe; Tolkein put the box into the safe after I had locked it.

Q. Did the cash-box belong to the Company or yourself? A. It had been lent to me by the secretary; it belonged to the Company - I had not accounted to the secretary for the money in the box; the secretary deposits money in the safe.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. When you deposited the money in the safe that night was it your intention to take it out in the morning, and go on with your business with it? A. To go on with my business with it; I had not accounted to the Company.

JOHN BENJAMIN TOLKEIN
. I am chief clerk at the Norwich Union office. I remember putting Mr. Boutillier's cash-box into the safe on the 13th of July - I locked it up with two boxes which I am in the habit of depositing there every evening; I believe the prisoner was there at the time - he was there till four o'clock; I left Mr. Boutillier, the prisoner, and another clerk in the office - Mr. Pleas, I believe, was likewise present; on the following morning, as soon as I put the key to the safe, the folding doors opened of themselves - I found it was unlocked; I sent for Mr. Marriott, who examined the lock in my presence - I found my two boxes there, but Mr. Boutillier's was gone.

Cross-examined. Q. When you locked the safe you put the key into your pocket? A. Yes - it was a small key, and had never been out of my possession; it was the key of the inner door - the outer doors were left open; the inside is fitted up with iron doors, and the upper part is fitted up for books: the junior clerks have access to the books, and we consider it not necessary to lock the outer doors - the key of the outer door is kept in a drawer; I believe Mr. Pleas had that key - I did not tell him he might have it; I believe the secretary had told him so - that key was deposited in a drawer next the iron safe; the secretary residing on the premises takes care of that key - the outer door was not locked before I left the office; I left Mr. Pleas there, and believe he had that key - my box remained.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Was Mr. Boutillier's cash box locked up in the same place as yours? A. Yes, and the key of the inner door was never out of my possession; the cash boxes were locked up as safe as if there had been no outer door - the key of the outer door would not open the inner.

MR. MARRIOTT. I am an ironmonger, and live in Fleet-street. I was sent for to the office immediately on this robbery being discovered; I examined the locks of the inner safe - the doors were put too, and I was asked to look at them to form an opinion by what means they had been opened - I examined with a candle, and said there were marks of some instrument I found they opened; I took the lock off, and found part of the lock broken off, and marks where an instrument had been employed - it could not have been done with the proper key.

MR.
ROBERT JOHN BUNYON
. I am secretary of the Norwich Union Fire-office, and live in the house, in Bridge-street, it is in the parish of St. Ann, Blackfriars; nobody but myself, my family, and my servants occupy it.

Cross-examined. Q. You live there as secretary of the office? A. Yes; I pay no rent nor taxes - the prisoner was my servant about six months; he had left school very lately, and is the son of a very respectable tradesman - he was there without salary, merely on trial; he continued to attend after this discovery, and when he was sent for about eleven o'clock at night, his father brought him to the office.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Was that before his father's househad been searched? A. Yes; he was there without a salary, at the request of his father.

GEORGE ROBERT PLEAS
. I am in the employ of the Norwich Union Fire-office. On Monday evening, the 13th of July, I left the office at five o'clock; the prisoner staid longer than any of the clerks, except myself - I went out between four and five, and left him alone in the office; I was not out above a quarter of an hour, and as I returned I met the prisoner coming down Union-street, as I stood at the private door of the office; I asked him why he left the office while I was absent - he said he thought I was gone backwards - that passed without further notice, and we both went into the office together; he went to his book immediately - he was copying a policy; he stopped in the office about a quarter of an hour, and went out again, as he said with letters; I said nothing about it as I was there - when he came in I went out again, and was not out ten minutes; he was in the office at his book: at five o'clock I saw all the books put into the safe, and I locked it; I did not take any notice of the inner doors - they were shut too; I locked the key up in my desk at the office - I hid it behind some books; the prisoner and I left the office together - I saw him out; I went back at a quarter-past nine o'clock in the morning - I went to my desk, and found the key of my safe where I had left it; I did not open the outer door of the safe - it was opened about ten, when I had gone out; I gave the key of the outer door to the prisoner to bring out the books - I had come to the office before him; the other clerks were in the office when I gave him the key - Mr. Tolkein was there.

Cross-examined. Q. The key of the outer door was left with you? A. Yes - the other clerks left at four o'clock; I went out for a short time, leaving the prisoner there - I believe he was at work at his books; I was certainly not out more than a quarter of an hour - I was waiting at the private door when I saw him, and we went in together; he went to copy a policy - I went away for a very short time again, and left him writing something in the office, and found him doing the same when I came back; I saw him out of the office when I left - he lives in Chenies-street, Tottenham-court-road; when I locked the outer doors of the safe the inner doors appeared locked.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What he had done at the time you were away, was it in your power to tell? A. No - I did not try the inner doors; there is no difference in the appearance of a locked door and a closed one.

CHARLES HOWELL
. I am a surveyor. I marked some sovereigns by desire of Mr. Boutillier, with a kind of awl - here is the instrument; it was about six weeks before this circumstance - I have seen some of them since, and am convinced they are the same as I marked; I have no doubt of it.

Cross-examined. Q. How many did you mark? A. I cannot tell - there were several sovereigns, some half-sovereigns, half-crowns, shillings and sixpences; I dare say I marked more than twenty gold coins, sovereigns and half-sovereigns - I did not see them afterwards, till they were produced, not for six weeks; I delivered them to Mr. Boutillier.

MR.
WILLIAM WADHAM COPE
. I am a City marshal. I went with Forrester to the prisoner's father's house, Chenies-street, Tottenham-court-road, on Monday, the 20th of July; I had apprehended the prisoner in Frances-street, Tottenham-court-road; I took him back to his father's house, and made search in a room which the father told me, in the prisoner's hearing, was his (the prisoner's) room - I found clothes and things in it which would suit the prisoner; I believe he was in the parlour when I searched - I found in his bed-room this piece of paper in a small box which belonged to him; I found in the cellar,(which is down three pairs of stairs from his room) twenty-nine sovereigns concealed under the stairs, behind the skirting board - he was not present when I found them; I produced them to him afterwards - he said he knew nothing about it, that some one else had done it - I was present when the cash-box was found down the privy, in the yard, by Daniel Forrester; the prisoner still said he knew nothing about it.
Cross-examined. Q. I suppose the family were in the house? A. Yes.

GEORGE ROBERT PLEAS
re-examined. Q. During the time he was clerk in the office, was his father, or any of the family, in the habit of calling to see him? A. His sister did - I do not know whether she was there on the day this happened; I cannot say whether she was there while I was - if she had come to the place the safe was in, while I was in the office, I think I must have seen her; I was absent about ten minutes.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I went with Mr. Cope and my brother to search this house in Chenies-street. I found twenty-nine sovereigns behind the skirting, on the stairs, and with a pitchfork, in the privy, I pulled up the bottom of the tin box, and then the top, but the interior was produced by another person - I apprehended the prisoner at Spittle's livery-stables, in Frances-street; he was standing there.
Cross-examined. Q. That was very near where his father lived? A. Yes.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I know no more than my brother has stated.

WILLIAM PAUL
. I am a performer at the theatre in Tottenham-street. I have a slight acquaintance with the prisoner - he overtook me in a gig at Pimlico, on the 13th of July, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening; I got into the gig and rode with him to the Red House at Battersea, and while there he offered to lend me 5l. or 10l. - he pulled a handful of sovereigns out of his waistcoat-pocket; he seemed to have about fifteen, and he produced the interior part of a cashbox from under the seat of the gig - it fell from the seat as he was sitting on it; it was empty - I said, "What have you got that for;" he said, "I have been to buy it, but it won't answer the purpose I want it for - if it is of any service to you you may have it" - I said it would answer many purposes I could put it to; we took it to the Red House - we had some stout, and as I was returning I was carrying it under my arm; he said I need not carry it in such a public place - I said, "I am not ashamed of it;" I carried it to my house, and produced it before the Magistrate.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he ever offer to lend you money before? A. Never - I had seen him but twice; I only intended to ride about one hundred yards withhim, but he got me to go over to the Red House - I did not take any money from him.

MR. LE BOUTILLIER. I have examined this cash-box; it is exactly the same as mine - this interior part is exactly like the one I lost; there is no mark on it - here are eight of the sovereigns which I am certain are the same as were marked for me by Howell; this paper is my hand-writing, and is the same as I left in the cashbox - (reads) "Coach 3s. 6d. Pleas 8s. 6d."
Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell what is the mark on the sovereigns without looking at them? A. A dot made with this instrument.
MR. HOWELL. These eight sovereigns are exactly like those I marked - I have no doubt about them myself; I identified them at Witt's house - at the time they were found.
Cross-examined. Q. They have the same dot on them? A. Exactly the same - they could only be marked the same by the same description of instrument; it was a broken instrument.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Have you that broken instrument here? A. Yes, it corresponds; if one was marked now with it, it would be exactly the same.

JURY. Q. Has that instrument been out of your possession since? A. Yes (here the witness marked a sovereign with it); I delivered to Mr. Boutillier the sovereigns I marked, and saw him put them in his box.

MR. LE BOUTILLIER. I had to use the cash-box every day, and continually kept the sovereigns at the bottom of it - I am certain there were marked sovereigns at the bottom of the box; I had seen Mr. Howell mark them - they had been there from the time they were marked; the box was deposited in the safe every night.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. Did you see them the day they were missed? A. Yes - I did not take them out, but saw they were there.

Prisoner's Defence. This paper, which is said to have been found in a box in my bed-room, is said to have been in the cash-box at the time of the robbery; now there is a drawer in the office at the left side of Mr. Boutillier's desk, which contains waste-paper - it was put there for wastepaper a month or three weeks before the robbery; I took it out of the drawer: it was larger than it is now - I made a memorandum on it, tore it in two, took the piece I made the memorandum on, and put the other into my pocket, and at night I make it a rule to lock up every thing I have in my box - if I had committed the robbery, is it likely I should have returned every day to the office and be cross-examined as I was twice - I solemnly declare, before every body here, I am as innocent as you are yourselves.

MR. LE BOUTILLIER. I am certain the memorandum was in the cash-box locked up with the cash at the time I put it in the safe on Monday evening; the memorandum was a recent thing - it might have been in existence about a fortnight before. I had a drawer in which I kept waste-paper about three months ago.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Was not the paper on which you made the memorandum larger than it is now? A. How can I say that; it is the very same paper and is the same size as it was then, I think - I will not swear I did not make the memorandum on half a sheet of paper - How can I tell?

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Is that paper in your hand writing? A. It is; the 3s. 6d. might have been laid out a fortnight before - Pleas had paid me some money and this was the balance; he had paid it me since Midsummer: it was about some rent - he might have paid it me a fortnight after Midsummer - I never wrote the memorandum on any other piece of paper, and it was in the box on the 13th of July; I used to keep my cash in the drawer near my seat, and from time to time I found a deficiency in that drawer - it was a drawer for general purposes and waste-paper; I never put the memorandum in that drawer - the drawer is there still.
JURY. Q. Was the box regularly replaced in the safe every night, or left at Islington? A. It was always in the safe; I kept it there not at Islington.

COURT to MR. TOLKEIN. Q. When the office hours are over, is that part of the office appropriated to the business locked up so as to prevent Mr. Bunyon from going into it? A. No; it is accessible to him or any of his family.
Eleven witnesses deposed to the prisoner's good character.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury, in consideration of his extreme youth and former good character.
Judgment Respited .

1761.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 2 spoons, value 12s. , the goods of
Christmas William Colls
.

ISAAC ARGENT
. I live at the Rainbow tavern, Fleet-street
;
Christopher William Colls
is the proprietor . On the 24th of July, between seven and eight o'clock the prisoner came into the coffee-house as a customer; I was serving - he called for a go of rum, which I gave him and a silver tea-spoon with it; a person afterwards came in who I had seen in his company the night before, when we had lost four spoons - his companion had a go of whiskey; we had other customers in the room - they staid till ten, had supper, and two more goes after, and had four spoons altogether - I missed two before they left the house; they had the tavern mark on them - they went out together; I followed them out, pretending to go to see the time - I came up with them, caught hold of the prisoner, and the watchman took hold of the other; I had given him information before they left - they wanted to know what charge I had against them; I said I would let them know when we got over to the watch-house - before we got there, one spoon was found with the tavern mark on it: I had seen the prisoner attempt to throw it away - only one has been found: the prisoner said he had taken it up with his handkerchief by mistake.

Prisoner. Q. When you brought the glass of liquor did you not observe my handkerchief on the table? A. I did not; I noticed his hat on the table and saw him playing with the spoon in his hand, while his hat was on the table - we were going to discharge all the servants on account of losing so much plate.

ROBERT NATHANIEL CRESWELL
, ESQ. I am a barrister. I was at the coffee-house, and in consequence of information from the last witness I followed the prisoner and the other out; and when we got about two yards into the street, they were stopped by Argent and the watchman - I happened to be about a yard behind the prisoner, and saw his right hand coming out of his coat pocket with a white handkerchief in it, and the end of the spoon peepingout of the handkerchief - I immediately collared him, caught his hand, and held it with the handkerchief in it; I said, "You will see the spoon here," and took it out of his hand - he held out his hand, and said, "Oh, I have got nothing."

Prisoner. Q. Do not you recollect saying at Guiddhall that when you took the spoon out of my hand that you said, "That is not it?" A. I did not say so - I marked the spoon with my initials, and gave it to the officer.

SAMUEL NEWBURY
. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house - Mr. Creswell delivered me this spoon - the Alderman discharged the other prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner, in his defence, stated that he had placed his handkerchief on the table to prevent his coat-sleeve from getting wet, and on replacing it in his pocket, he was unconscious of the spoon being there.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT, Fifth Day.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1762.
WILLIAM SNOW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July
, 9,500 needles, value 30s.; 8 ozs. weight of pins, value 1s. 6d.; 2 yards of ribbon, value 1s.; 2 ozs. weight of thread, value 6d.; 13 balls of worsted, value 3d.; 80 skeins of silk, value 7s.; 2 reels of cotton, value 5d.; 33 balls of cotton, value 1s. 3d.; 1 half-sovereign 1 crown, 2 half-crowns, and 2 shillings, the property of
William Rotherham
and another, his masters ; and
MARTHA SNOW
was indicted for
feloniously receiving part of the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen .

JOHN CAPEY
. I am in the employ of William Rotherham and
John Hill Grinsell
- the prisoner, William Snow, was in their employ for two months previous to the 30th of July, as a cashier , to sit at the desk, and give change - he slept with me. On the Thursday morning, before the 30th of July, he got up first, and went down stairs; I got up about seven o'clock, and saw a bundle hanging on a nail in my bed-room - some of our shop-twine was hanging through a hole in it; I took it down, and found some skeins of silk, some cotton, a purse, a half-sovereign, a crown, two half-crowns, and a quantity of my master's property - there was a cheque-book, a number of billheads, and some paper - I called a young man, and we showed them to Mr. Rotherham; in about an hour I was called into the counting-house, and found the prisoner -Mr. Rotherham said to me, "This boy denies these things, and says they don't belong to him;" I said to the prisoner,"It is of no use your denying it, it must be your's, and you took them;" Mr. Rotherham said it was of no use his denying it, he would bottom the affair, and he had better tell the truth; he then said he took them, and he had taken some cotton, needles, and worsted home, and they were in a school-box, in the back-parlour - the officer and I went to his mother's, after he was gone to Worship-street; when we got to the house, the officer asked Mrs. Snow whether she had a son in the employ of Rotherham and Grinsell; she said, Yes; he asked if she had any of their property in her house; she said, No; she then said,"His aunt has been here, and I have been looking into the school-box, and found these two parcels" - Attfield said, "Have you got any more?" she said No; he said,"We must look," and we found two more lots in the parlour, in different places, in boxes and drawers - here is cotton, needles, tape, and silk, such as they have in their shop; the whole amount, I should think, is about 3l.; the cottons have our name on the label, and the needles have our private mark on the paper.

Cross-exmained by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Who are your employers? A. William Rotherham and John Hill Grinsell - I have sold things out of the shop with these labels on them - I sometimes find needles and things about the shop, but these are done up in papers.

WILLIAM ATTFIELD
. I am an officer. I went to the house of the female prisoner, at No. 31, Gloucester-street, Commercial-road - it is about three quarters of a mile from the prosecutors' - she opened the door; I asked if her name was Snow; she said Yes; I asked if she had a son at Rotherham and Grinsell's; she said Yes; I asked if she had ever received any goods belonging to them - she said not to her knowledge - I took her into the back-parlour, and read the warrant - I asked if there were any goods there; she then opened the drawer, and gave out two parcels, which she said she had taken from the boy's box, and intended to take to the prosecutors' - I said, "Is this all;" "I believe it is," she said; I said I must search, and in different parts I found these papers of needles, cottons, and other things - this other parcel I got from Capey.

Cross-examined. Q. Is the husband of this woman living? A. Yes, and I believe he sleeps in the front-room, in consequence of this woman's mother being there, and sleeping with her - her husband is coachman to a gentleman in the City.
The prisoners received good characters.

WILLIAM SNOW
- GUILTY. Aged 13.

MARTHA SNOW
- GUILTY. Aged 44.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined 6 Months .

1763.
RALPH GEORGE MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 170 foreign dollars, value 35l., and 1 night-cap, value 6d. , the property of
Robert Willie Briggs
.

ROBERT WILLIE BRIGGS
. I am chief officer of the Catherine Stewart Forbes
. I left my dollars in a trunk in my cabin - I left it on the 4th of August, and the last thing I took five dollars out of the bag, and gave them to a doctor to take to a man who was going to the hospital; there was no one present; next morning one of the men was searching my box, and said, "Here are a great many wax candles;" I said Yes; he said, "We burn a great many in our lantern, I will take one;" I said, "Do;" the prisoner was second officer of the ship - he was on board when I left; I missed the dollars about half-past five o'clock, on the 5th - the prisoner had gone on shore that day about nine o'clock in the morning, and returned about three; I did not know then that I had lost them; he came on board the next day, and said, "Is it true you have lost the dollars?" I said, "It is too true;" he declared that he knew nothing about them; the next day he came on board againand went below - a person came to inquire for a package, and it was not found; in looking for it, I saw the prisoner in the larboard after-cabin, stooping down; I asked him if he knew any thing of the package; he said No; I was then coming up again - he said, "Look here;" he pointed down, and lifted up a night-cap with fifty-eight dollars in it; it was under his couch; I desired him to let it he till I had called one of the Dock clerks - he appeared as if he had accidentally hit upon it; he said he was looking for his shoe, and found the night-cap under the coach; the whole crew on board the ship, were thirty-seven or thirty-eight, but they had all left the ship except some boys.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not you bring a prostitute on board to sleep with you in your cabin? A. Not in my cabin, in one of the other cabins; I did not say any thing against the prisoner - there was much said against him, but not by me; he came on board the ship from time to time; the Magistrate admitted him to bail; he never slept in the same cabin with me - he slept in the cabin in which the dollars were found; it was sometimes open and sometimes shut - there is a water-closet in it for the passengers; it is not open to all - the prisoner had gone on shore three times before he found the dollars, but I do not think he had an opportunity of taking them on shore; prostitutes are often thieves - I was not in her company the whole of the time she was on board, but I can swear she never left the cabin, because the door was kept locked; I had gone on deck, and while I was there I could not see the cabin door.

COURT. Q. When did that woman come on board? A. About half-past eleven or twelve o'clock at night, and staid till six the next day; the trunk was not kept locked, but the door of the cabin was; the prisoner had complained of the Custom-house officer going into that cabin to the water-closet - we had other passengers on board, but not in that cabin.

ALFRED FELL
. I am third officer on board this vessel. I was ill and on my couch in a cabin opposite the one the dollars were found in; about ten o'clock Briggs went on shore, and in about half an hour I heard a person, who I thought was the prisoner, come down the ladder with an immense quantity of dollars - he was emptying them out; and the next day I heard Mr. Briggs say he had lost a great number, unless Mr. Martin had taken care of them; I said he might make himself easy, for Mr. Martin had taken care of them; I did not speak to the prisoner at the time I heard him; I believe he slept in that cabin, because I heard a midshipman come and call him about ten o'clock the next morning - I heard a Custom-house officer come to that cabin; Martin said, "Who is that?" he said, "It is I;" and he told him to go on deck.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. What time did the witness bring the woman on board? A. I think about an hour after I heard the prisoner come down; I slept in the starboard after-cabin; I could not see the prisoner, but I heard him; if any person had asked me, I should have said it was Martin; I heard his foot, and heard him cough - I never said though I was not certain, yet I would swear to him; he was called at night and went on deck, and then came down again; it was a passenger's cabin, who had left at Dover - I did not suspect him; he came on board, and eat and drank with the prosecutor; they were on the closest intimacy the whole voyage; he has been appointed chief officer of the ship.

COURT. Q. I understand you said the dollars were safe because Martin had taken them? A. Yes; I thought he took them to take care of for Mr. Briggs, as they were so intimate; I told Mr. Briggs of it when he came on board, and he inquired of Mr. Martin when he came on board; the cabin in which the dollars had been was on the deck on the larboard side - I heard that door shut, as I suppose, and a person come down and go into the other cabin - he was afterwards called and went on deck; it was after that I heard the dollars taken, and some one come down from the awning after-cabin; I do not think I had been asleep for three nights.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Have you any reason to suppose that it was Martin that came down, otherwise than by supposing he had left the cabin? A. I supposed it was him; I expected he would have remained on deck, but I supposed he came down.
COURT. Q. Was it his duty to remain on deck? A. Yes; he was called to look out - there would have been no person on deck with him but the Custom-house officer.

ROBERT WILLIE BRIGGS
re-examined. Q. When Fell told you your money was safe as Martin had taken it, did you speak to Martin? A. Yes; when he came on board he said, "Is it true that you have lost your money?" I said it was too true; on the Saturday after I had been at the Thames Police, he said he had received an anonymous letter - he showed it to me, and asked if I knew any thing about it; I said No - but I suspected him, and there was evidence which I intended to have looked into as soon as I had time; he said he had not taken the money, and had not so much, or he would pay it me rather than have his name made public; when I went on shore that night, I told a boy to give Mr. Martin the key of my cabin - when I returned I got the key from him.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Where did you pay the woman from? A. From the desk, in dollars; after the letter had been received the prisoner left me, and on Monday I went to the Thames Police.

JAMES EVANS
. I am a surveyor of the Thames Police. I was required to go on board the ship on Monday, the 24th - I found the prisoner and the two witnesses in the cuddy: I was talking to Fell, and the prisoner came out - I called him, and said, "I understand there has been a robbery committed;" he said Yes - I said, "Do you know any thing about it?" he said No; I said,"There is some suspicion attaches to you, have you any objection to go before the Magistrate?" he said he had not; he said he could swear the money was safe in Mr. Briggs' trunk - the next day he went before the Magistrate, who admitted him to bail.
Witnesses for the Defence.

NICHOLAS GEORGE TERL
. I live in Trinity-square, Borough. On the 5th of August I was on board the
Catherine Stewart
Forbes; I found Mr. Fell sick in bed- Mr. Briggs told me the dollars were lost; I went down to Mr. Fell, and told him - he said he heard something like dollars, by the sound of them, in the next cabin; I said, "Who slept there?" he said Martin - I said it could not be Mr. Martin; he said "No, it could not be him, if it had been him I should have known him," and he said if it had been Martin he must have taken them tohide from Briggs; for, about an hour before Briggs went on shore, Martin said, "Are you not going to pay the men some of their dollars before you go on shore?" - he said, "No, I shall pay them at my pleasure."

MR. HUNGERFORD. I live in Newton-terrace, Kennington, and am a tide-surveyor of the Customs. On the 4th of August I was on board the vessel, and heard that Mr. Briggs had lost his property; some hints were thrown out that the Custom-house officers or searchers, had taken them - I said, "If you suspect any of them, let me know, and I will represent it to the Board of Customs;" he said,"Indeed, I may blame myself a great deal" - I said, "If you suspect any of my officers, let me have their names, and I will not let them go on duty;" I advised the prosecutor to go to the office, and the prisoner offered to go for him: I asked him if he suspected the prisoner - he said he did not; when it was said that a person had been jingling dollars in the cabin, Fell said it was not Martin, if it had been him he should have known him.
NOT GUILTY .

1764.
HENRY NORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 4 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign , the property of
James Picknell
.

JAMES PICKNELL
. I lodge at Mr. Featherstone's, in St. George's in the East
; the prisoner slept in the same bed for eight days - he was there before me. On the morning of the 8th of September I employed him to take my chest down to the Hull packet - it was locked, and I had the key of it; I took a bag, and another young man took a hammock - I opened my chest to get the money to pay the prisoner, and this money and the waistcoat were gone; the prisoner seemed quite unconcerned, and pressed me to go back and see if it was there - I went home and told the landlord - he seemed quite surprised; when I got back to the packet, the prisoner was gone - I did not see him again till eight o'clock in the evening, in Jewin-street, at the sign of the Woolpack; he had the waistcoat on, and 19s. 2d. in his hat - he said he had bought the waistcoat, with the other things he had on; I am certain it is mine - it has two gores under the arms to make it larger.
Prisoner. Q. When had you these pieces put in? A. The beginning of this summer - I had not worn it above three times; they were put in at Sunderland.

JOHN COVERLY
. I am landlord of the Woolpack. The prisoner came to my house on the 8th of September, about nine o'clock in the morning - he gave me a bundle to take care of; he came again in the evening - I gave the bundle to Repton.

ANTHONY REPTON
. I am an officer. I have the bundle, which Coverly gave me, and the waistcoat which the prisoner had on; the prosecutor described the pieces in the waistcoat before I took it off - these other things, which were in the bundle, appear to be new.

JAMES PICKNELL
. I went to the docks about seven o'clock - my chest was locked, and the key was in my hat by the side of the bed; I had seen the money safe the night before - the prisoner saw me put my clothes away, and take the money out.
Prisoner. There were eight other men in the room Witness. No, there were three or four.

Prisoner's Defence. Another young man slept in the same bed with us - there were three beds in the room, and three slept in each; in the morning he asked me to lend him a hand - we went down to the Dock, and he missed his money; I told him he had better go back and see if he had left it - I then went to a ship going to the Swan River, but it was not going off then; I went to my father, and then to Jewin-street, where I was taken in the evening.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1765.
GEORGE SAMUEL BALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of February , certain fixtures, (i.e.) 2 pairs of window sashes, value 30s., and 2 locks, value 3s., the goods of
Anthony Pratt
, and fixed to a certain building ; against the Statute, &c.

EMANUEL PLAYER
. I am a house agent for Mr. Anthony Pratt, who has a house in Raven's-buildings, Whitechapel
. On the 6th of February there were two sashes taken from the front parlour, and two from the back - I had seen them safe the evening before, and missed them at nine o'clock in the morning; I had opened the house the evening before, and put the other keys in the front parlour, and took the parlour and street door keys away - when I went in the morning the parlour door was open, and the sash frames gone; the officer showed me the frames the next day - I compared them with the window places; they fitted exactly, and I have no doubt they belonged there - two locks, which had been taken off, were fitted to their places.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Were not the sashes burnt? A. Yes, a little; but the tops and bottoms fitted exactly - there was sufficient left to fit in; it was not a common size - they had but six squares, and there were eight squares in the sashes of the other houses in that street - all frames, having the same number of squares, are not of the same size; I had seen them hundreds of times - a man named Bailey was transported for this very offence; I distinctly swear that I saw the frames the same day as I missed them.

THOMAS GREEALY
. One morning in February last, about seven o'clock, I saw a man opposite my door, in Parsey's-gardens, which is less than a quarter of a mile from where they were taken - he had two sashes, which laid up against the wall; I do not know who he was - in about a second I saw the prisoner going into a house in North-street with two sashes; I went on to my place of work, and saw the man I had first seen go into the same place as the prisoner did - it was the day the other man was taken up.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen the prisoner before? A. Yes, and knew him - he was just at the door, but I saw him quite sufficiently to know him.

THOMAS CARRANT
. I am an officer; I went with Vann to a house in North-street, which is kept by the prisoner's grandmother - we knocked some time before she let us in; we looked throught the window and saw a person go out at the back door, but I cannot say that it was the prisoner - when the street door was opened we went up stairs; we found some glass and some frames - I met Bailey coming out of the room and took him; he was tried - we took theprisoner from information - we fitted the frames and lines to the place they had been taken from.

JOHN VANN
. I went with this witness to the prisoner's grandmother's; I found a lot of sashes broken up and two locks in the lower room - I did not see any person leaving the premises; I only saw Bailey, who has been convicted.

THOMAS GREEALY
. I saw the house the officer went into; it is within one door of Parsey's-gardens - I saw the articles taken from the house that morning.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am an officer. On the 30th of July I was standing at the corner of Worship-street, Norton Falgate - I saw the prisoner go into a public-house, and he saw me, I suppose; I had been in search of him for some time - I waited a few minutes, and then went and looked in at the window; he was not there - I then saw him come out of a court and crossed towards him; he ran up Worship-street - I saw it was of no use to run after him, and turned up another street, which brought me into the Curtain-road - I saw the prisoner again; he saw me, and ran into a dust yard, which had no thoroughfare - I looked up a hole over some breeze and saw the prisoner's legs; I said, "George, come down" - he said, "Keys, I will come to you" - I said, I took him for some sashes, for which Bailey had been tried; he said, "It is all right, I don't care for that" - as we were going to the office he said,"Cannot you settle it with me; I have 14s. in my pocket which I will give you, if you will let me go?" I said, "That is not the way I do my business; keep the money, you will want it" - I knew of no other charge against him.
Cross-examined. Q. When was this? A. About six months after the robbery.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1766.
MARY JONES
was indicted for
stealing on the 30th of July , 1 watch, value 4l.; 1 watch-chain, value 1s.; 2 seals, value 8s.; and 1 watch-key, value 2s., the goods of
Robert Haywood
, from his person .

ROBERT HAYWOOD
. On the 30th of July, I was at the top of Grosvenor-place and met
Mary Allen
; I went home with her to Providence-row
- I had then four sovereigns and a half in my breeches pocket; I undressed, and put my breeches, with the money in them, upon the table - it was then about twelve o'clock; at about half-past two or a quarter before three, Allen went down stairs - I awoke, and asked where she was going; I waited some time, expecting her to return - I then got up and looked at my watch at the window; the prisoner Jones came in in a few minutes, and asked what I wanted there - I said I came in with Allen; she said it was her apartment, and her husband would soon come home; I asked her for a light, as I could not find one of my gaiters - she went down for a light and took my watch; I did not see her take it, but I had had it in my hand two minutes before and put it on the mantel-shelf - she then came up with the light, and I accused her of it; she denied it - I got my clothes on and went to the watchman, who came; we saw the two women leaving the house -I was sober.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. How long had you been walking with Mary Allen? A. It might be about two hours - we had one pot of beer to drink - I had been paying some bills, and might have taken a glass of porter before; I will not swear I had not taken any spirits - I was quite sober - the house has not a very respectable appearance; I had been asleep perhaps two hours and a half before Jones came - she did not come to the door, and ask for a light - when she came, I thought it was Allen -I had known Allen for two years; my watch was found in a pair of bellows, in another room - I missed it before the light was brought up; I was certain it was gone, for I had had it in my hand just before - there were no other persons but Allen and myself in the house - there is only one room in it - the watch was found at No. 6, another house.

COURT. Q. When the light came, you saw the watch was gone from the mantel-piece? A. Yes, but I had missed it before - a little light came from the window - it was beginning to be day-light; I had light enough to see the prisoner's person before the candle came - I am certain she is the person who came up, before she brought the light, both by her appearance and her voice.

GEORGE PALMER
. I am a watchman. I went with the witness to No. 2, Providence-place, where he said he had been robbed - I could get no admittance; but having seen a woman come out, and go to No. 6, I followed her -I got in at the window, and the constable found this watch in the bellows in the first-floor room; I found the prisoner in the same room, and took her.

Cross-examined. Q. What time did you go there? A. Twenty minutes after three o'clock - I suppose the prosesecutor had not been with me above five minutes before I went there - I had to get a light, which occasioned me to stop a few minutes - it is a bad place - some of the houses are open the greater part of the night; Mrs. Fulmer is the landlady of that house.

JOHN BUZZARD
. I am a patrol, and was with Palmer; what he has stated is correct.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY (of stealing only) Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1767.
MARY ALLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 purse, value 2d., and 4 sovereigns, the property of
Robert Haywood
, from his person .

ROBERT HAYWOOD
. I went home with the prisoner; when I awoke in the morning, she was going down stairs; I then missed four sovereigns, half a crown, and a purse, which had been in my right-hand breeches pocket; I did not know what she went down for - I got up, and went to the watchman - we saw the prisoner going into No. 6, with the last prisoner - the patrol got in at the window - there was one sovereign found within the lining of the prisoner's shoe.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Did you place the money by the watch? A. No, I missed the money after I got out of bed, before I missed the watch; I then looked at the watch, and put it on the shelf again - I am sure I had the money when I went with her - she had a glass of rum at a public-house - we should have gone into a bye place, but there was a watchman - I have gone to a bye place with her, and given her a shilling; I never went home with her till that night - I did not give her any thingthat night but the glass of rum - I am a groom - I changed half a sovereign at the public-house; I had paid about 2l. away before I went home with her; when I got home with her, I took out the purse, and said I hoped I should not be robbed; she said I was perfectly safe - she did not say she had had this money sent her by a friend from the country.

GEORGE PALMER
. I went with the prosecutor. I got in at the window and took the prisoner.

JOHN BUZZARD
. I was on duty as patrol; at twenty minutes after three o'clock I met the prosecutor and the watchman - I went to the house where he said he had been robbed, but we could not get in; the landlord was present, but was not willing that we should break the door, and we did not like to do it - we fetched Timbrell, and found the watch; I took the prisoner to the watch-house, searched her, and in her shoe I found the sovereign - that was all.

ROBERT HAYWOOD
re-examined. Q. What awoke you in the morning? A. I suppose it was Allen dressing herself - I did not hear her till just as she was going down stairs; I called to her, and she made no answer.
GUILTY (of stealing only.) Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

1768.
SAMUEL FISHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 watch, value 10l., the goods of
Matilda Parlett
, from her person .

MATILDA PARLETT
. I live with my father, who is now in the Fleet-prison - I keep house for him there. On the 24th of August I met the prisoner in the New-road, between twelve and one o'clock in the day; he first spoke to me about the weather, and then asked if I would have something to drink - I said No, several times, but at last said Yes; I had never seen him before - I walked with him for about half an hour, and then went to my uncle's, in Gloucester-place; he waited for me at the end of Gloucester-place - I went to see my uncle, but he was out of town; I sat talking with the housekeeper nearly three-quarters of an hour, not thinking he would wait so long, but when I came out he was where I left him - he took me into a public-house, No. 75, Norton-street
; it might be later than one o'clock - we went into the parlour; we had a pint of ale, and after that he ordered a beef-steak, of which I partook - he had another pint of ale; several persons came in - the door was not locked, and the window which looked into the street was open; a lady and gentleman came in, and staid for an hour and a half - I was conversing with them about situations and other things; several persons came in - I staid there till a quarter past seven o'clock; the prisoner then went away in great haste, while I sat there, as soon as the gentleman and lady were gone; the prisoner had heard my watch tick, and said I had got a watch - I said I had not, but at last I said I had, showed it him, and said, "I will defy you or any man to take it from me;" some other persons then came in the room - as soon as the prisoner was gone I thought of my watch, missed it, and told the landlord - he looked out, but could not see the prisoner; we then went to the Regent's-park barracks, but could not trace him - I had the watch five minutes before he left the house; the next morning I went to the public-house, and then to Knightsbridge - I asked the serjeant if such a man had been out, and he said he had; I pointed the prisoner out to the serjeant-major, who said that is him by his looks - there were a great number of men exercising; the watch was fastened round me by a piece of tape, which was cut - I left the tape at the barracks; I was not more than half an hour sitting near the prisoner - I was not very close to him; he put his hand round my waist at one time, but said nothing - there were lights brought in about an hour before he went away.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Are you in any way of business? A. No - I have been with my father; I have not been to service or any business - I was with Mrs. Hart on liking, for two or three days, but the place was too hard, and I left her, finding my health declining; it was between twelve and one o'clock when I met the prisoner in the New-road - I was conversing with him for half an hour or an hour, before I went to my uncle's; I did not make any appointment with him, he said he would wait - I then met him at the corner of Gloucester-place; we went to the Little Cannon in Norton-street - I was not in the Goat and Compasses at the corner of Fitzroy-street, I am quite sure of that; it was between one and two o'clock - we had the beef-steak at the Little Cannon; I think he had a pint of ale afterwards - he might have had three pints in all; I did partake of it before he went away he had a glass of gin and water; I had some of that - he had a pint of beer; I had some of that - he put his arm round my waist after that; he had not done any thing to me before - people kept coming in; no fondling had taken place between us, or any thing of the kind - I do not say he did not kiss me; it was only once - that was early in our sitting; it was not all the time we were there - he paid for what was had; he did not make me any present - my watch was gold, but the chain was not gold; my father is in prison through a person he had been a great friend to - the lights had been lighted an hour before the prisoner went away; the room was not a dark one - I did not see which way he went; I showed the tape to him at the barracks, he took it from me and it fell on the floor - he said, "I have no knife, and how could I cut it;" I did not feel it done, but it was very easy for him to break it - I told the quarter-master my name was Parlett, and I was residing at a friend's; I did not tell him my name was Parker, and that I lived in Britannia-row - I was quite sober, upon my oath; the pot-boy did not conduct me to any place.

COURT. Q. When was the kiss given? A. About an hour and a half before he left; no one was in the room at the time - I do not know whether the light was gas or not; I mentioned to the landlady that my watch was gone.

RICHARD BLAKE
. I am landlord of the Little Cannon, or the Good Man, in Norton-street. I was not at home when the prosecutor and prisoner came in; I came home at three o'clock, and saw them there - I believe I went in twice, once with a glass of gin and water; she was sitting by his side - seven or eight persons came in while they were sitting; I did not see them go -Mrs. Blake was in the bar, and said she would see the couple go; the witness did not go out, but in about five minutes after the prisoner was gone, she came from the parlour, and said she had been robbed of a gold watch - Iwent into the parlour; there was no one there - she did not describe how she had lost it; I said I would search the parlour, the yard, and the water-closet, before she went - I found nothing; I did not ask her particularly how she had lost it, and she did not tell me - she was the worse for liquor; they had two pints of ale, one glass of gin and water, and one pint of porter, after I came home.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see one of your potboys conduct her to the water-closet? A. No; I thought the prisoner belonged to the first or second regiment of Life Guards, and went with her to the Regent's barracks the same night - when I went into the parlour she was sitting close by the prisoner on the bench; the lights were not lighted more than twenty minutes before they went - the witness was not drunk; she was the worse for liquor.

ISAAC MOOREY
. I am waiter at the Little Cannon.
