I remember the prisoner and the witness being there - they came in together; the prisoner asked her what she would take - she said, "I won't have any thing to drink, I would rather have something to eat;" the prisoner said bring in a pint of ale at all events - he pulled off his gloves and gave me 1s., and said fetch us some beefsteaks; I took them in, and saw no more for an hour, I dare say - another pint of ale was then called for, and I took that in.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see or hear any thing like a watch about her? A. No.

MATILDA PARLETT
re-examined. I did not sleep in the Fleet Prison the night before; I was at a friend's, No. 8, Halton-street; I am sure I had the watch when I got up, and fastened it with the tape as usual; I had looked at it in the day - the reason I said I would defy any man to take it from me was, because I did not know what character he was, and I thought it would deter him - my friend is not here at whose house I slept.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent.

ANN EDSON
. I lived at the Goat and Compasses. On the 24th of August I served the prosecutrix, and a soldier who was with her, with two pints of ale; I cannot swear the prisoner is the person - the man had a red coat on; I have no doubt of the prosecutrix's person.

COURT. Q. What time was it? A. Half-past twelve o'clock when they came, they left at half-past one - the house is at the corner of Fitzroy-street; I saw something about this in the newspaper, but had no idea I should be wanted; I had a subpoena last Wednesday - I had no conversation with the prosecutrix; she was in the back room - she had a white shawl on with a narrow border, and a white bonnet with coloured ribbons; I observed her face - my master and his two nieces live there; I served them with what they had.

WILLIAM BOWER
. I am a private in the First Regiment of Life Guards . On the 24th of August I was at the Regent's-park barracks - the prosecutrix came there that evening, she was what I call drunk; the landlord of the public-house asked for the officer of the guard - I said there was no officer, there was a corporal; he said that would not do; I sent the orderly man to the adjutant - they staid two or three minutes; the prosecutrix reeled up against the table; the adjutant asked her if I was the man - she said No, he had no pouch-belt on; he asked her what time he left her - she said at half-past nine o'clock; I then went to the guard-room, and it wanted a quarter to nine; she said she was positive it was half-past nine - the landlord said you mean half-past seven; she said No, half-past nine.

DANIEL PENNY
. I am the corporal. I was called in by the last witness; the prosecutrix appeared to me to be very much the worse for liquor - I heard her complain to the adjutant that she had lost a watch, and some soldier stole it at the Little Cannon; he brought forward first the orderly man and then the centry - she said he was something like the orderly man; she staggered about very much; the adjutant said, "I will show you every assistance in my power - leave your address with the corporal;" and while he was writing she frequently caught hold of the table to steady herself.

GEORGE MILLER
. I am a quarter-master at the Knightsbridge barracks. On the morning of the 25th of August the prosecutrix came there, and stated she had lost her watch - the prisoner was taken off the parade, and searched in my presence, but no watch or duplicate was found; she then gave her address, "Parker, 16, Britannia-row, Islington;" she wrote it herself - this is it; I saw her write it.

MATILDA PARLETT
. I gave him the address, but I did not write that - it is not my writing.
COURT. Q. Look at it; tell us whether it is your writing? A. Yes, this is my writing - but I thought if I could get the watch without my father's knowledge I would - I did not remember it before.
MR ADOLPHUS. Q. Who is Parker? A. They live at No. 16, Britannia-street; they are laundresses - I do not know what part of the house they occupy; I am not much acquainted with them.

MR. ADOLPHUS to
GEORGE MILLER
. Q. Have you made inquiries for them? A. Yes; there is no laundress of the name of Parker, there is one of the name of Sawyer; the prisoner has been ten years and a half in the regiment, and had a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

1769.
SARAH BANKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 sovereign, and 3 shillings, the monies of
Frederick Timberman
, from his person .

FREDERICK TIMBERMAN
. I am a sugar-baker . On the 30th of July I was going home, at half-past one o'clock in the morning, from a public-house where I had been spending the evening; I met the prisoner and another woman at the corner of Lambeth-street
; they asked where I was going; I said, "Home, and it is almost time for you to go home;" the prisoner then put her hand into my pocket and took out 1l. 3s.; she went across the road - two other girls came round her; I saw her trying to make away with the money - the watchman caught her, and found some silver on her, but could not find the sovereign; I was sober.

Prisoner. I had been drinking at the White Lion public-house, and he came and asked if I would have any thing to drink; he called for liquor three times, and asked if I would take a walk with him - when we got out he said he had been robbed. Witness. I was at no public-house with her at all; I do not know how much money was found - the watchman is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1770.
ROBERT HIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 4th of September , 2 spoons, value 1l. , the goods of
William Wise
.

ELIZABETH WISE
. I am the wife of William Wise - we live in George-street, Islington
. The prisoner lodged in our house a fortnight; I missed these two spoons out of the top drawer of a chest in my bed-room.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. When was this? A. Last Friday week; I let my lodging to a woman, who said she was a shoe binder, and the same evening the prisoner came, and was there the remainder of the time - I said the woman might have taken property, and given them to him to pawn; I cannot say when he had been at my house, but I have a side door which persons go in and out at - the prisoner came there on the Sunday after I missed them; I accused the woman of stealing them; I do not believe it was the prisoner.
COURT. Q. Had the young woman been at your house? A. Yes; I went on the Friday to put my little baby to bed, and missed them - I think I had seen them the morning before.

FRANCIS PARKER
. This spoon was pawned with me on the 4th of September, by the prisoner; he said it was his mother's, and asked if I thought his mother was not possessed of a silver spoon.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. Yes - he had been several times at the shop.

SAMUEL SHERWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker. This spoon was pawned with me on the 4th of September, by the prisoner; he said it was for his mother.

ROBERT WORTLEY
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner; the prosecutor charged him with stealing the spoons- he acknowledged that he pawned them, but did not say how he came by them.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the spoons were given him to pledge.
NOT GUILTY .

1771.
MARY DOWNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July
, 28 sovereigns, the monies of
Sarah Catherine Williams
, her mistress ; and
ALICE KELLY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. LEE conducted the prosecution.

CELIA WINDER
. I was at Mrs. Sarah Catherine Williams' house on the 3rd of July, and she being ill, I sent for a doctor: the desk was wanted to write a prescription - I took out of it twenty-eight sovereigns: I put them into a drawer, locked it, and gave the key to Mrs. Williams, who is not here - she is ill.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is she married? A. Yes; her husband is out of town.
NOT GUILTY .

1772.
JOHN HURLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 87lbs. weight of soap, value 2l. 6s., the goods of
George Godfrey Holdsworth
, his master .

GEORGE GODFREY HOLDSWORTH
. The prisoner was in my service, as errand-boy ; he had lived with me five or six months the last time, but he had been with me two years before. On the 17th of July my wife sent him with a cake of yellow soap to Mrs. Marshall; I was at home when he returned, and said Mrs. Marshall liked the soap, and would have 56lbs. of it on the Tuesday following.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. He had been a long time with you? A. Yes; I have a female servant - my wife frequently received money of the prisoner, and he has taken out goods in my absence; he has gone out with me to receive monies - we were on familiar terms; I have drank with him when we have been out for four or five hours - I did not miss any soap.

ANN HOLDSWORTH
. I am the prosecutor's wife. On the 17th of July I sent a sample of yellow soap and mottled, to Mrs. Marshall, by the prisoner; he brought word that it was approved of, and she would have half a hundred weight of it on Tuesday - he did not pay me for any soap delivered to her.

Cross-examined. Q. Has he not, on other occasions, brought you money? A. Yes; I was not aware of any goods being sent out that day to any customers; there might be, but it was by my husband's orders - I had not given the prisoner general orders to take out goods; we have a book, in which we keep entries of the sales, but Mrs. Marshall never had credit in her life - I do not enter money received; I have often received money of the prisoner, but have accounted to my husband for it - I have not received money of the prisoner several days after, for ready money transactions - he was taken on the Saturday.

ESTHER MARSHALL
. I keep a chandler's-shop. I received half a hundred weight of soap by the prisoner, on the 17th of July, for which I paid him, and said I would have another half hundred weight the following week, but I did not name any day; this is the bill and receipt.

Cross-examined. Q. Whose writing is this? A. The bottom part is the prisoner's; I have received bills before, but I do not know who wrote them; I have not particularly examined how the month was put - I know this delivery was on the 17th of July, and I remarked at the time that I could scarcely tell whether the month on the bill was June or July; I have dealt with Mr. Holdsworth for some time - I did receive the second half hundred weight of soap, but not from the prisoner.

ANN HOLDSWORTH
re-examined. On the 17th of July the prisoner took a sample of soap to Mrs. Marshall's, and brought word back that she would have half a hundred weight on the Tuesday, but on the Saturday he was taken on another charge, and on the Thursday my husband called and asked when Mrs. Marshall would have the half hundred weight of soap, as he had not had an opportunity of sending it before, and she said, "I had one half hundred weight and paid for it - has not your lad given you the money?"

Cross-examined. Q. Whose hand-writing is this bill? A. The prisoner's; he made out bills of parcels sometimes - I have entrusted him to do it, but I have looked over him - he has received monies when I have receipted a bill and sent it out.

Prisoner's Defence. I received the order from Mrs. Marshall, and took the soap from my master's shop by my mistress' knowledge, and brought back the money - my mistress was very busy at tea with her sister.

ANN HOLDSWORTH
. My husband was on the Jury here, and we had tea at four o'clock - he left home at near five; the prisoner did not leave my house.
JURY. Q. If you had sent the prisoner with the orderyou would have asked him for the amount on his return? A. Yes.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1773.
ALEXANDER FAIRBAIRN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 file, value 5s., the goods of
James Edwards
, his master .

JAMES EDWARDS
. I am a coach-spring maker , and live in High-street, Bloomsbury
. The prisoner had been in my employ, but left me about four months before the 19th of July; I missed a great number of files, and have only found this one, which has my mark on it.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. He was not in your employ at this time? A. No; he used to look in as a shopmate ; he has been in my service off and on this seven years - he says he took this off my bench: it is usual for men, when they go out to work, to take rubbers and files; they might leave them, but I never knew it done.

THOMAS BURROUGHS
. I bought a file for 6d. or 7d., but I cannot say it was of the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you swear that is the file? A. No; I sold the one I bought to Welkes - my wife never purchased one of them, to my knowledge.

GEORGE WELKES
. On the 30th of April I saw this file in Grub-street, and bought it of this man for 9d.

ROBERT JAMES
. On the 17th or 18th of July this rubber was brought to the shop, and I detained it, knowing it to be stolen.

FRANCIS FAGAN
. I took the prisoner on the 21st of July; he said he had taken it in a fit of drunkenness, and was very sorry for what he had done; the prosecutor asked if he had taken any more, and he said No.
GUILTY. Aged 45.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1774.
WILLIAM ELSBURY
was
indicted for embezzlement .
MR. SMITH conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM DANBY
. I live at Lambeth; my wife is in a lunatic asylum at Peckham, for which I pay the parish of St. Andrew, Holborn, 9s. a week. On the 7th of July I received a note from Mr. Wilks, saying he was desired to apply to me for the arrears of my money: and on the 10th of July, after tea, from half-past five to six o'clock, I sent by my nephew two sovereigns, to the best of my recollection - it was 2l.; I said to him, "Bill, take this over to the workhouse, and make haste back;" he returned between seven and eight o'clock, and said he had delivered the two sovereigns at the gate.

WILLIAM BANTING
. I am nephew to the witness. On the 10th of July he gave me two sovereigns, which I took to Gray's Inn-lane workhouse
, and gave to the prisoner, who was at the gate - he took a book down, as they generally do, and seemed to write something; he said, "That will do," I went home and told my uncle.
Prisoner. Q. Was it not three sovereigns? A. No - it was two.

JOHN WOOD WILKS
. I am assistant overseer of the parish of St. Andrew, Holborn . The prisoner was the gateman , and was formerly a messenger; it was his duty to put down in a book any payments that were made, and to carry them to account. On the 10th of July I had a settlement with him, between ten and two o'clock - I received 2l. of him, which he had received from four or five persons, and gave him a receipt for it; I wrote several times to
William Danby
for the arrears due from him, but I do not recollect the day; the prisoner continued in his place us gate-man on Saturday, the 11th of July; and on Monday morning, when I went, the first thing I heard was that Elsbury was off - I sent down to the lodge for the book, in which I found this entry made."Danby, 2l.;" I never saw the prisoner write, but I have little doubt it is his writing; this 2l. has never been paid to me, nor to any one else, to my knowledge: the prisoner was paid so much per week for his attendance, and had an extra allowance of provision.

GEORGE STRIPLING
. I am a watch-house-keeper. On the 17th of July the prisoner came to me, and said he came to give himself up, and he supposed I had heard what he had done - I said I had heard he had done wrong, but I did not know to what amount; he said to the extent of 40s. - he said he was sorry for what he had done, and he was a fool for it.

Prisoner's Defence. I leave myself to the consideration of the Court and Jury; it was a great error, but not done intentionally - I have had 20l. or 30l. to get change, and if I had intended to defraud, I could have gone off with it.
GUILTY. Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy on behalf of the Parish .
Confined Two Months .

1715.
WILLIAM VERRYARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 bevil, value 2s.; and 1 plane, value 1s. , the goods of
George Stockdale
.

GEORGE STOCKDALE
. I am a carpenter , and was at work at Eaton-square
on the 5th of September. I lost a bevil and a plane from a house I had the key of; the prisoner was foreman in the employ.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. I believe you and the prisoner are old friends? A. No; he was foreman to Mr. Smith; he has not lent me his tools - he has none; he lent me a bead plane once - I never lent him any: I did go with him to Bartholomew fair, but not on the night of the robbery - I did not lend him these tools, nor go to my master to get him turned out: I have not said, "I have got master Verryard now, and I am d-d if I don't transport him." - I said, if I could find who had the tools, I would.

JOHN GRINDLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a plane and a bevil pawned by the prisoner; I have known him twelve months - he said his name was Verryard, and he lived in Chester-street.

Prisoner's Defence. I can safely say, with a clear conscience, that he lent me the tools to get half a gallon of beer, and he drank with me; when he came to the fair he spent his money with me - I left him at half-past ten at the top of Holborn, and little did I think that a man I had treated as a brother would be my prosecutor.

GEORGE STOCKDALE
. I went to the fair with him the night afterwards: I paid for every thing I had there, and he paid for what he had - I never lent him these things, nor did I know it till one day I met his wife, and she said he had between 3l. and 4l. worth of duplicates - thatled me to suspect him; all the other men's tools were gone.
NOT GUILTY .

1776.
HENRY TURNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 7 books, value 2l. , the goods of
Robert Wilks
.

ROBERT WILKS
. I am a bookseller in Chancery-lane
. On the 10th of July the prisoner came between five and six o'clock in the evening, and looked at seven volumes of Law Reports, which were in my window; he said he had a brother in the law, who he was pretty certain would be glad to buy them, if I would send them to an office he had in Leadenhall-street - I thought he was on no good, and wanted to get rid of him; he said if they were sent that evening, and I would call the next morning, he would settle for them - I then went out, and did not return till eight o'clock; my shop was then shut up.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not tell the boy to dust them? A. No; you remarked that they were dirty, and I said the boys could easily clean them - they might be put on one side for the purpose of being dusted - these are the books, and here is another book which I know nothing of.

THOMAS WOOD
. I am shopman to Mr. Wilks. The prisoner came after Mr. Wilks was gone out, and said he was waiting for me to take the books down to his chambers in Leadenhall-street - I was not present at his interview with Mr. Wilks; I then went with him, and left the books at No. 25, in the East India chambers - he opened the chamber with a key, and opened a desk which he said he meant to put the books into; I did not return to my employer till the next morning, when he desired me to go anddemand the books: back - I went, and waited till the prisoner came; I said I came for the books to save me from any further noise - he said it was a fair bargain betwen Mr. Wilks and him, and his brother could not come to town that day; I went across the way, and saw the prisoner come out and go to Mr. Higham's - when he came out, I went there, and asked if he had come to sell or to buy books, and the books were on the counter; I told them to detain him if he came again.

SARAH HIGHAM
. My father is a bookseller, and lives at No. 54, Chiswell-street. On the 11th of July the prisoner came there, about nine o'clock in the morning, with a porter, and brought these books, which are Dowling's Reports; he wanted 4l. for them - my father said he would not give that, as one of them was spoilt with ink; he then said he would take 50s. - my father said he would not have them till they were looked over, and he was desired to call at two o'clock; he said he could not call till four - he requested to have a few shillings, and we let him have 3s.; the witness then came in, and gave us information - the prisoner came at twelve o'clock, and we told him they were so much damaged he had better take them away, and return the few shillings; he said he had more to sell, and he would bring them - Mr. Wood came in, and he was detained.

JOHN LEWIS
. I am a porter. I was employed by the prisoner to carry the books.

ANDREW WOOD WEST
. I am a headborough. I took the prisoner when Mr. Higham sent for me - he asked where I was going to take him; I said to take him up - he wanted me to go to Mr. Wilks, and then to Hackney; I said I was not authorized to go any where - when we got to the corner of Bunhill-row he ran off, and I called Stop thief! a man ran against him, and I came up to him.

ROBERT WILKS
. These are the books. I never intended he should have them, and had not sold them to him - they are labelled nine guineas.

Prisoner's Defence. I went to Mr. Wilks' shop to look at the volumes; he ordered them to be dusted, and said they should come that evening - I went in an hour after, and saw the shopman; I said Mr. Wilks had agreed to send them to my office - the shopman took them down; a person came, who looked at them, and said they were in so bad a condition they were not worth 5s. - under that conviction, and thinking Mr. Wilks would take less, I asked the low price I did for them; Mr. Wilks now says he did not intend I should have them - but he said I should, and he knew they were for immediate sale; Mr. Higham said they were worth nothing but for waste-paper, and wished me to take the covers off them.

LINDLEY JOHN HIGHAM
. I did not say so - I had a suspicion, from the manner in which he took the 3s., that they were not honestly come by, and left word with my family to tell him to return the 3s., and take them away.

THOMAS WOOD
. The name "Mr. Turner" is on the chamber door.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1777.
EDMOND TOMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 watch, value 10s. , the goods of
James John Tyler
.

JAMES JOHN TYLER
. I am a working goldsmith . On the 24th of July I lost my watch from my house, No. 6, Great Chesterfield-street. Marylebone
- I did not miss it till the next morning, when the woman it belonged to came and asked if it was ready; I then missed it from my work-board, where I had left it - I know the prisoner by his coming two years ago, and offering me some spoons, which I did not buy.

MARY ANN TYLER
. Between six and seven o'clock that evening the prisoner came to sell a seal - he remained about a quarter of an hour; the shop-board was open to him at the time - I left the board while he was there, but we did not miss the watch till next morning.

DANIEL CARTER
. I am in the service of Mr. Daniels, a baker, in South-street, Manchester-square. On the 1st of August the prisoner came up to me in George-street, and asked if I wanted to buy a watch - I said Yes, I was going to buy one soon; he took this watch from his pocket, put it into my hand, and said he wanted 7s. for it - I saw there was one of the hands broken, and it wanted a glass; I gave him 4s. 6d. then, and 2s. 6d. in the evening - I took it to Mr. Berquez to have it repaired.

FRANCIS BERQUEZ
. Carter brought this watch to me on the 1st of August; it is worth 5s. or 6s.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I took the prisoner at his father's one morning - I told him I wanted him on suspicion of stealing a watch from Mr. Tyler; he denied it at first,and then said he had bought it of a gentleman's servant who was out of place, for 5s., which he had saved up.
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Transported for Seven Years .

1778.
HENRY STANLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 sovereign, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the property of
Robert Boyd
.

ELLEN BOYD
. I am the wife of Robert Boyd; we live in Star-court, Little Compton-street
: the prisoner lodged in there on the 7th of August - he was sitting in my room that night; I pulled off my apron - there was a pocket in it, in which was a sovereign, a half-crown, two shillings, and a sixpence; I put the apron on a chair, close by where he sat - I went to get some coals; he put his hand into my pocket, and took out a handkerchief, which had the money tied in one corner - I was putting on the coals, I turned my head and said to another lodger, " James, Henry has got my money and handkerchief;" he said, "Yes, he is only gone into the yard - it is only a lark" - I staid a few minutes, but he did not return; he ran away - on the 9th I met him in Seven-dials; he had no money, but he had a good hat on, a pair of stockings, and a different handkerchief and trousers to what he used to wear.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not send me to Mr. Smith, to see if you had left any money there, where you had been drinking, and were brought home by a man and woman? A. No, nothing of the kind - I did not leave my home.

JAMES VAUGHAN
. I lodge in this house. I saw the apron on the chair near the bed-side; the prosecutor had given me a sixpence out of the corner of the handkerchief where the sovereign and silver was; to fetch a pot of beer, about half-past ten o'clock, and then the prisoner took the handkerchief and went towards the yard - he made his escape, and never returned till we found him in Great Earl-street on the Wednesday.

FRANCIS MACE
. I took up the prisoner. I found half a crown and some halfpence on him, a good second-hand hat on his head, and the trousers he has on.

Prisoner's Defence. I solemnly assure you I went to Bartholomew-fair with this woman's husband - he told me she was in the habit of taking all his money and valuables, wasting them, and then coming back to her old quarters; when he returned home that night he found her drinking in a gin-shop with her daughter - after I got home he chastised her, and then they went to bed with the witness; her clothes were in a chair by the bed-side- I heard some one touch the clothes, and her husband rose up and said, "Henry, Ellen is off;" he dressed himself and went out; he returned in the morning, and said he had found her in a watch-box with the watchman, and she had been circulating scandalous reports, which I do not choose to repeat - she came home; her husband and this man gave her a beating; she then desired me to go to the house of a person named Smith, to inquire if she had left any money there - I left the house without knowing any thing of the money; the trousers I have on were given me by a friend, and the hat I exchanged for an old one.

Prisoner to
ROBERT BOYD
. Q. Have you not stated that your wife has often left you, and that you found her and her daughter drinking after you returned from Bartholomew-fair? A. No, I did not; I did not see you after I entered the fair - we were going to have some supper when you came home; I found my wife at home - I did not return with any man and woman.
Q. Were not you, your wife, Sullivan and his wife, drinking in Smith's wine vaults that morning? A. No.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

1779.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 6 skins, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Henry Lay Champlin
, in a certain vessel, in a certain dock, adjacent to a port of entry and discharge, called the Port of London .

GILBERT DUNCAN
. I am a Police-constable. On the 10th of September I saw the prisoner near the London-dock gate, about seven o'clock in the evening - he had six skins in his coat; I asked how he came by them - he said he brought them from New York, in the ship Cambria
, in which he was a seaman ; I went to the Cambria, and the mate said they had nothing of the kind on board the vessel, to his knowledge, but they had that day been loading some skins from the dock.

WILLIAM JUDGE
. I am a Thames Police-surveyor. I went on board the Cambria on the 11th of September - I found a cargo of bales of skins, and one of them was very loose, so that persons could pull the skins out; I brought it on deck, and went to the searchers, who came and examined the bale, and found the same sort of skins in it.

JOHN BLUNT
. I am a searcher. I examined the bale, and found the same sort of skins in it.

JOHN COOKE
. I shipped twenty-nine bales of skins on board the ship Cambria, for New York - these appear to be exactly the same sort.

SKINNER ROW
. I am a clerk in the house of Row and Co - these skins were shipped from their house; we do not know the consignee, but the captain of the Cambria is Henry Lay Champlin.

JAMES THOMAS
. I am a seaman on board the Cambria. I came from New York with the prisoner, but never knew of his having such skins as these.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he purchased the skins at New York, and had brought them home as a present to a friend.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Judgment Respited .

1780.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted
stealing, on the 11th of September , 1 writing-desk, value 18s. , the goods of
William Bowden
.

WILLIAM BOWDEN
. I am a broker . On the 11th of September I missed this desk, about five minutes after I placed it on the table - the officer brought the prisoner back with it.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you say you did not know it? A. I said I would look and see, and then I missed it - I know the desk now.

WILLIAM HOLT
. I was standing fronting the Sessions' House, about ten o'clock in the morning, and saw theprisoner running by with this desk; I took him, and asked the prosecutor if he had lost any thing; he said No; then he looked, and said, "I lost it from this table;" I took the prisoner to Hatton-garden.

Prisoner's Defence. A gentleman came up, and asked if I was willing to earn a shilling; he said, "Take this box to Islington," and told me to go on - I went about two hundred yards, and then this gentleman came and asked where I got it.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1781.
JOHN KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 4 shillings, 1 sixpence, and the sum of 6d. in copper money , the monies of
Stephen Swain
.

HANNAH SWAIN
. I am the wife of Stephen Swain. On the 10th of September we lost 5s. out of the till, in our shop, in Chad's-place, Gray's Inn-lane
- I went up stairs, a quarter before three o'clock, to fetch my baby down - I left no one in the shop; a person had been in the shop about two minutes before, and asked for change for half a sovereign; I looked, and had but 8s. 6d.; I then went up to get the child - it was cross; I just showed the child the garden from the window, and I heard the prisoner knock on the counter - I came down, and was struck with his appearance; he said, "How do you sell these apples?" I said, "Two for a halfpenny;" I gave him two; he gave me a halfpenny, and I put it into the till - he went away; I looked round to see if any thing was gone - I then drew out the till, and missed the money; I ran out with my baby, and called to him to come back - he set off running; I overtook him; I asked him for the money - he said he had no money, and had taken none.

JOHN BLAKE
. I am an officer. I came up, and took the prisoner; the prosecutrix said she had lost five shillings - I found on him four shillings, one sixpence, 4 1/2d. in halfpence, and one penny piece - he said he had it of his sister, who lived at No. 82, Chapel-street, Somer's-town -I went there, but there was no such number.

Prisoner's Defence. I had but just got in the shop when she came down: I bought the apples, and went out; I heard a cry of Stop thief! looked back, and the prosecutrix came up - the money found on me I got at my sister's, at Somer's-town.

MARY KELLY
. I lent the prisoner, who is my brother, five shillings, and pawned a handkerchief to make it up - this is the duplicate of it; I kept him twelve months after the death of his mother - I could not keep him longer, as I have a child.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1782.
JAMES CONNELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Charles Bicknell
, from his person .

GEORGE WILLIAM HYAT
. On Sunday evening, the 12th of April last, I saw a gentleman; Morgan and some other boys were near him, but I cannot swear to the prisoner as one - Morgan took a handkerchief from the gentleman, and put it behind him; in five minutes I saw him cross Coventry-street - he was taken; he said he did not take it, and he would go to the boy who had it.

JOHN HARRIS
. I am a plasterer. I saw the mob -Morgan told me to go to
Jem Connelly
, in Peter-street, and he would give me the handkerchief - I went to the prisoner, and he gave it me.

THOMAS GOOK
. I received charge of Morgan, who was tried, and transported for life - Harris brought me the handkerchief, and I was ordered to take the prisoner, but he was out of the way till last Monday.
NOT GUILTY .

1783.
JOHN HEWITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 feather bed, value 2l. 10s.; 3 blankets, value 9s.; 2 sheets, value 5s.; 1 candlestick, value 1s. 6d., and 1 flat-iron, value 6d. , the goods of
John Craft
.

SARAH CRAFT
. I am the wife of
John Craft
- we live in Gloucester-court, Whitecross-street
. I let a lodging to the prisoner's wife - he lived there with her; they came in June, and left in August - they owed one week's rent - I missed the articles stated, and have only found one pair of sheets.

CHRISTOPHER DEER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sheets pawned by a female, in the name of Davies.

ROBERT LOCK
. I am a constable. The prisoner was taken before the Alderman, but being a county charge, it was given to me - I asked where the woman's bed was, and he said, "It is where you can't get it;" I found the duplicate of these sheets at his lodging.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not have them.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1784.
JAMES HATTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 4 candlesticks, value 4s. , the goods of
Mary Smith
.

EDWARD SMITH
. I am a publican - I keep the Two Brewers, in Bunhill-row
. About one o'clock, last Thursday, the prisoner was going out; I went, and found two candlesticks in his pocket, and two in his hat - they belonged to my mother,
Mary Smith
.

THOMAS EARLE
. I was passing, and saw a mob - I took the prisoner - the prosecutor produced two candlesticks, and I found the other two.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Seven Days .

1785.
JOHN HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 4 plucks, value 9s., and 1 sheet, value 1s. , the goods of
Henry Caton
.

HENRY CATON
. I am a butcher , and live at Blackmore, in Essex. On the 14th of July I had four plucks and one heart, to go to Monday, Venables, and Co.; I sent my man with them in a cart.

WILLIAM REYNOLDS
. I am servant to Mr. Caton; I received the plucks from him tied in a wrapper - I lost them just below Mile-end-gate
.

THOMAS JEVANS
. I am a watchman. On the 14th of July, at three o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner in company with two others with a bundle, in Collingwood-street; I pursued them - they made their escape to Northampton-street; I came back, and examined a yard where I had a glimpse of the bundle going over, and found the plucks -I know the prisoner, but he had not the bundle; I did not see the cart.
NOT GUILTY .

1786.
JOHN DONALD
was indicted for
stealing on the 10th of September , 1 book-stand, value 1l. , the goods of
Stephen Law
.

The witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1787.
ANN BAKER
and
WILLIAM THOMPSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of June , 4 bedsteads, value 8l.; 4 beds, value 8l.; 4 bolsters, value 1l.; 8 pillows, value 1l.; 4 sets of curtains, value 5l.; 3 tables, value 5l.; 2 chests of drawers, value 4l; 10 chairs, value 4l.; 4 mattresses, value 4l.; 1 palliasse, value 10s.; 8 pairs of blankets, value 2l.; 1 desk, value 1l.; 60 knives and forks, value 2l.; 2 sets of fire irons, value 10s.; 40 yards of carpeting, value 4l.: 20 brass rods, value 20s.; 1 fender, value 10s.; 1 tea urn, value 10s.; 1 coffee biggen, value 10s.; 6 pairs of sheets, value 3l.; 1 sofa, value 2l.; 1 pair of pantaloons, value 5s.; 1 hat, value 2l.; 2 shirts, value 6s.; and 12 books, value 2l. , the goods of
Henry Provis
.
Messrs. ADOLPHUS, PRENDERGAST, and DUNN conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY PROVIS
. I live in Buckinghamshire, and am an architect and engineer . The house No. 37, George-street
, is mine - I let it furnished to the female prisoner; the rent had been 60l. per year unfurnished, and was to be 70l. per year furnished: and to commence at Christmas, 1826- I went into the country, but frequently returned to town.

COURT. Q. Was the furniture in it your's? A. Part of it was mine and part Baker's; in return for her services, I had furnished one room, which was to be her's - the furniture of that room might be worth about 10l.; the other furniture in the house belonged to me, and was worth about 60l.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You returned at various times? A. Yes, and every thing was quite right up to the 7th of February, on which day I left town; I returned again on the 28th of July - the house was shut up; I knocked some time at the door and could not get in, but one of the windows was open - some one got in and opened the door; the house was stripped of every thing but the kitchen poker - there had been some books in the kitchen, which were my own property; there were some clothes which I had worn when I had been in London - there was all the articles stated in the indictment gone, and many more; I have seen a table and some other things since.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you married? Yes; I have no one who was present when I let the house to Baker - she had lived in my service, at different times, perhaps for six years, partly in London and partly in Buckinghamshire: she was my housekeeper - I think there were six bedsteads in the house, and four were mine - I have no one here of whom I bought any of them, or who saw them in my possession; the male prisoner lodged there - my agreement was, to have a bed in the house when I came to town, provided there was a spare one; and she was to provide me with food - I generally lodged in the attic; I was not there long at a time - I have been there while the male prisoner lodged there; I have taken tea with him - there was a large mahogany table which I had let with the house, in the room he occupied; I bought it at a sale of Mr. Howard, in Judd-street - the female prisoner did not buy the articles I call mine; that I deliberately swear - she, perhaps, accompanied me to buy half of them; but, upon my oath, I did not give them to her - I have sent her food, but not for her to know who sent it.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Have you seen any of your articles in the possession of
Robert Davies
? A. Yes; the kitchen table, at which I have repeatedly written, and a chest of drawers - I sent her food in prison, because I heard she wanted it; she said she was starving.

BENJAMIN LAMB
. I am a surgeon. About March last, I was about to purchase a piece of furniture; Mrs. Baker told me she did not know a cheaper place than Oxenden's rooms in Oxford-street - I said I was not aware that any articles of value were sold there; she said Mr. Provis bought the furniture there which belonged to him - and Thompson observed, that very good articles were sometimes to be got there as bargains, but that entirely depended upon the attendance or non-attendance of Jew brokers - the furniture was removed from No. 37, George-street in June or July; I understood, she spoke generally of the furniture of the house - I did not understand it meant all the furniture of the house; I knew she bought some herself - after the furniture was removed, I assisted in apprehending the male prisoner; he begged and entreated to be let go - I would not, and he ran away; he was taken to the watch-house, and produced a receipt for the furniture, having purchased it of the other prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Then your only occupation is not that of a surgeon, you take thieves? A. I give them to the officer - I cannot tell of any one article of furniture which she had purchased: I only knew by what she said to me that she had purchased some - I attended her when she was ill; I had no hostile feeling towards either of the prisoners - I had some legal proceedings with Baker for my expences as a surgeon; I do not exactly know the amount of my bill - the debt stands as it did; I knew Thompson to be the person against whom the warrant was issued - I saw him in the street, and apprehended him; I never did such a thing in my life before - I live at No. 17, Carmarthen-street; I do not know that Baker had ever sold these goods as her own - I do not know her hand-writing.

MR. DUNN. Q. Is Mr. Provis a friend of yours? A. Yes, I have known him some time - I saw one load of the furniture handed out of the passage of the house to the carman; I endeavoured to find Mr. Provis' address - I was three days finding it out, and before I could write he came to town.

ROWLAND WILLIAMS
. I am a surgeon in Carmarthen-street - Mr. Lamb resides with me; I have been at the house of the prisoners - I was there in the beginning of June; I had some conversation with Baker - I told her that the other prisoner had circulated a report that the furniture was his, and that it was very wrong such reports should be circulated, for very likely, as he was in some difficulties, an execution would be put in, and it would be taken - she said if any thing of that kind happened she would send to Mr. Provis, and be would trounce them, for the furniture was his.

FRANCES SMITH
. I lived as servant at the house - Mrs. Baker was my mistress; Thompson occupied the front andback parlour in the latter end of June - the whole of the furniture was removed by Thompson's direction; he sent it away in a cart - I saw him assist in the removal; there were some books which were tied up in a cloth, and sent away by him - the clothes were all tied up and sent away; the bedsteads, chest of drawers, and other things were put into the cart - Baker was not present when the whole of it went away; I remember Skinner was one of the carters.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you attend the first examination? A. Yes; I saw Thompson at Marlborough-street, and asked him if he would pay me my wages - he told me he had no money, and could not pay me; I gave evidence after that, but I should have done so if he had paid me - I did not know Baker was in difficulty; I knew there was to be an execution in the house - I did not know the goods were removed to avoid the execution; I was present when the Sheriffs' officer came - I do not know when it was; I did not leave the house till the goods were removed - the surgeons did attend me; I think the goods were removed the same week that the Sheriffs' officer came - I think it was within two days; I know they were removed to avoid the execution.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Why do you know it? A. The officer told me so - he did not call himself a Sheriffs' officer; he asked for Mrs. Baker - that is all I know; I do not know what he was, and Thompson did not say.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Upon your oath did not this gentleman come to the house and produce his warrant to seize? A. I do not know; he offered me a paper, but I did not know what it was - I did not know the man.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Were your wages paid when you left the house? A. No; I did not see Thompson till he was in custody - I did not propose that if he would pay me I would not give evidence; some proposals have been made to me by Mr. Wallis, who is not here.

JAMES PARROTT
. I am a carter; I know Thompson. In June last my master, Mr. Skinner, sent me to No. 36, George-street, to remove some things - I went in the morning, between ten and eleven o'clock, and twice afterwards in the day; I saw Thompson, the servant, and an elderly woman - I took the goods, which consisted of chairs, tables, and other things, to a coffee-shop at the corner of Grafton-street; Mr. Thompson sent me on, and followed the cart - when I got to the corner of Grafton-street I put the things down by the railings: another cart came and took some of them - Thompson was present at the time; I took a large table to Mr. Chapman's, a pawnbroker, by Thompson's order - he said it was paid for; I removed two other loads in the course of the day - Thompson was present, I acted under his orders - he told me he was going to take them to a sale the next morning; he did not say whose they were.

GEORGE CHAPMAN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at No. 30, London-street, Fitzroy-square. I received the table; Mr. Provis saw it, and claimed it - Thompson came to my shop, said he had a table to dispose of and wished me to go and see it - he gave me the number of the house in George-street; I went, and saw him there - he said from some pressing circumstances he wished to sell it; he did not state any particulars, and I bought it.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did not he tell you an execution was expected every day against the woman? A. I saw no woman, and cannot tax my recollection as to whether it was said.

JOHN WALTON
. I keep a coffee-shop, at No. 11, Grafton-street, Fitzroy-square. Thompson came to me, and said he was a house-agent and broker ; he asked if I had any place in which he could put some things for a few days - I told him I had a place at liberty; he brought some things, and put them in my kitchen - this was about the beginning of July, I think; he was a stranger - he did not say he had any thing to sell; he brought some things, and took them away in two or three days; I saw bedsteads, and, I believe, a chest of drawers, but there were a very few things - they remained three or four days; the carman is here who took them away; I saw one parcel of them taken away, but I was obliged to go out - Thompson was present, and the carman; that was all I saw.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean that Thompson was present? A. To the best of my knowledge he was there; I think I saw him.

ROBERT DAVIES
. I live at No. 27, Little Pulteney-street. I bought a chest of drawers, a large deal table, and a few more things of Thompson - the prosecutor has seen them and claimed them; he did not say whose they were.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not hear from him that it was removed to avoid an execution? A. No - I went to Meard's-court, and there I bought them; Thompson appeared to be the occupier of that place.

JOSEPH SKINNER
. I am master of the carman who has been examined. Thompson came to me, and I sent my man: he came for him again, and I sent him again; in about a fortnight I was going down George-street - he came and said he wanted a cart, could he have it; I said Yes - I drew up to the house, and took out a bedstead; Baker was in the kitchen, helping us up with it; I did not wait, but sent for my man, who took them.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear of any execution against the goods? A. I heard nothing at all, but by seeing the cart loaded in such a bustle, I thought there was something very queer in it.
MR. PROVIS re-examined. I went to Mr. Davies, and saw some property, which was mine; I had let it in the house to the female prisoner - I saw the table shown by Mr. Chapman; that was a part of it.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there a coffee-biggin? A. No; I found nothing portable; there were two large tables and a chest of drawers - I know the woman has bought goods, and put them in the house; I do not know whether she bought a chest of drawers or a deal table, but the table I saw was my own - I do not know whether she was in any difficulty; I never saw her from the 7th of February till she was in custody: all I know about the man, is that he was a lodger in the house - the lodging was furnished, and was let to him by the other prisoner; he might take her for the owner of the house.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Have you yourself had any conversation with him, as to who was the owner? A. No - the property she bought was bought with my money partly, which I owed for wages; I think it was legally hers but morally mine; I was to allow it her in the rent.
COURT. Q. Did you know of any execution? A. No- I have heard of such a thing since I have been in town, but I know nothing of it.
MR. CLARKSON called -

LAURENCE NATHAN
. I am an officer of the Sheriff of Middlesex. I had this warrant in my possession; before I received it I had this warrant in my possession; before I received it I had been to No. 36, George-street, for the purpose of arresting Thompson. I saw this servant, and told her my object; I saw Baker, and told her the same: this warrant is dated the 28th of July - I went to execute it two or three times, but the house was closed; when I went there first the house was fall of goods, but when I entered with the warrant there were no goods on the premises; I endeavoured to follow them, but could not find them - the warrant is against William Thompson and Ann Baker - if I had found any goods I should have seized them, and sold them; I remember being in the Court of King's Bench; I arrested Thompson, and he offered Baker as bail to me - she offered to become bail for the man: I asked if she was a responsible person, and could pay the money, if he should fix her, and she said Yes, her furniture in her house in George-street would pay it.
BAKER - GUILTY. Aged 43.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Twelve Months .

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 47.
Transported for Seven Years .

1788.
MARY BROWNE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 1 trunk, value 12s. , the goods of
Adam Margatroyd
.

ADAM MARGATROYD
. I am a trunk-maker , and live at Knightsbridge
. I lost a trunk from my door on the 28th of July; I followed the prisoner, and took her with it, about two hundred yards off.

CHARLES THOMPSON
. I saw the prisoner take the trunk from the door, and gave information - she was taken.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Seven Years .

1789.
THOMAS JOSEPH ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
Joseph Lawton
.

JOSEPH LAWTON
. I am a porter at Mr. Stevens', in Tottenham-court-road. I slept with the prisoner in the back parlour of a lodging-house - on the 8th of September I missed my coat, which I never permitted him to take - he denied knowing any thing about it.

JAMES ALDONS
. I am a pawnbroker. This coat was pawned on the 8th of September - I cannot say by whom.

THOMAS DUKE
. I am a patrol. I took the prisoner, and he produced this duplicate, which led me to the place.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I meant to bring it him before Saturday night, when he came home, and saw me - he said if I would give him up the duplicate he would say no more about it.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Weeks .

1790.
MARGARET WATSON
and
JANE BATNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 11 sovereigns, the monies of
Thomas Webb
, from his person .

THOMAS WEBB
. I am a seaman of the Maitland. On the 7th of September I had eleven sovereigns and 7s. - I got drunkish, and do not know what happened till I awoke, and found myself in bed with Watson, at No. 2, Shadwell-market
; it was day-light - she asked me to get something to drink; I put on my trousers, came down, and she showed me some money in her hand - I had received my money in the dusk of the evening, but I do not know any thing about meeting the prisoners; I missed my money when I got up stairs, after having something to drink.

ELIZABETH TURNER
. I keep the White Lion. Batner came on the Monday evening to me, and Watson followed her, and gave me two sovereigns to keep; Mrs. Scott, who is a witness, was quite drunk outside - she cannot be found now.
NOT GUILTY .

1791.
WILLIAM JORDAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 1 canvas bag, value 2d., and 4 sovereigns, the property of
Joseph Pigg
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1792.
ELIZA JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 6 sovereigns, the monies of
Andrew Oliver
, from his person .

ANDREW OLIVER
. I am a seaman of a merchantman . On the 10th of September, at half-past ten o'clock at night, I met the prisoner at No. 1, Dock-street
- I went home and agreed to stay all night with her; I was sober - I had eleven sovereigns and 24s. 1d. in my trousers pocket; she put away my trousers at the head of the bed- I am sure the money was in them; in the morning she said she was very bad, and wanted to go down stairs - I told her not to stop long; I then looked into my pocket, and six sovereigns were gone; I do not think the door was locked when we went to bed - I have not seen my sovereigns since; I am sure the prisoner is the woman - she did not return.
Prisoner. He dropped 12s. 6d. on the bed - I took it up, and put it into his hand; that was all the money he had. Witness. There were 14s. dropped out of my jacket-pocket, but the gold was in my fob.

MARY WILLIAMS
. I live in this house with the prisoner, in Dock-street. On the 10th of September she brought the prosecutor home - he appeared sober; at half-past three o'clock the next day the prisoner told me she had been shopping, and had bought a pair of shoes for 5s., a pair of shoes for a child, and a black bonnet - she then said she meant to go down to her grandmother, and leave her her money to take care of till Saturday, when she meant to go to Chatham; I did not see what money she had; but she said the shoes cost 5s., and the child's boots 5s. - I do not know what the bonnet cost; the prosecutor afterwards came into my room, and the prisoner turned her back to him; he then went away, and she said, "He don't know me again," and burst out laughing - I said, "I don't suppose he does know you?" we were having tea together at the time - as soon as he was gone, the prisoner and another girl got up and ran away; they sent me word in an hour that they were going to a raffle, and could not come back to tea.

ADAM HIGH
. I am a Thames Police-constable. I went with the prosecutor to Dock-street - he pointed out the prisoner, who was standing in the street; I took her, and said she was charged with robbing a man of six sovereigns; she said, "You are mistaken, I don't lodge in this street," and affected not to know the prosecutor - I took her into the house - she said she did not live there; I found a new bonnet on the bed, and she had a new pair of shoes on her feet - I asked whose bonnet it was; she denied all knowledge of it, but the next morning she said it was not a new bonnet, she had fetched it from the scourers, or something.

Prisoner. I did not tell you I did not know the man; I said I got the bonnet from Queen-street, but I did not know the woman's name - I never told Williams I had any money; I bought these things, but I pawned a handkerchief and a gown to do it.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutor had counted all his money, and seen it safe before she left him.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Life .

1793.
MICHAEL BARRY
was
indicted for bigamy .

The
prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1794.
JOHN MACKLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 4 loaves of bread, value 2s., the goods of
Jabez Thurgood
, his master .

JABEZ THURGOOD
. I am a baker , and live in Old-street - the prisoner was in my employ for three weeks or a month. On the 8th of September my brother sent him out with a lot of bread.

JOHN THURGOOD
. I am the prosecutor's brother. On the 8th of September, I gave the prisoner sixteen loaves to take to Mr. Selwin, in Golden-lane
; I went the next morning, carried the bread myself, and found but twelve booked - they keep the book, but the prisoner books the bread; I know this to be the prisoner's writing - I do not know what became of the other four: he knew the book would be seen - he was discharged the next day.

JABEZ THURGOOD
. I discharged the prisoner for another offence; I did not speak to him on this subject.

JAMES HAWTHORN
. I was applied to, and took the prisoner; he said the reason he kept the loaves, was his master not paying his wages.

Prisoner's Defence. I deny it; I met a man the night before, who said Mr. Thurgood had been accusing me of stealing eight loaves - I went home, and asked Mr. Thurgood if he had said such a thing; he said No: I went on the 8th of September to the shop, and was to take sixteen loaves, but we had not much bread, and I took but twelve, and booked twelve in the shop.

JABEZ THURGOOD
. I have known him eight or nine years - he bore a good character; I paid him all up on the Tuesday evening - he did come back, and said he understood he was accused of robbing me.
NOT GUILTY .

1795.
JOHN MACKLIN
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 4 loaves of bread, value 2s. , the goods of
Jabez Thurgood
.

JABEZ THURGOOD
. On the afternoon of the 8th of September, I put sixteen loaves of bread on the board, and sent the prisoner to the same place; he only delivered twelve - he came back intoxicated; I paid him and discharged him in about two hours; here are only twelve entered in Mr. Selwin's book, and I am sure I gave him sixteen: I am sure he took sixteen, and took them all at once - he was not to go to any other customer, and brought none back.
Prisoner's Defence. My master put down sixteen - I delivered them on the shelves; I did not count the bread.

SAMUEL SELWIN
. I keep a chandler's shop. On the 8th of September the prisoner brought me twelve loaves, and no more - I saw him write the number in my book.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined One Month .

1796.
THOMAS SIMPKINS
and
CHARLES SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September
, 1 saddle, value 30s. , the goods of
George Houghton
; and
STEPHEN SERJER
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same goods, well knowing the same to have been stolen ; against the Statute.

SIMPKINS
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

GEORGE HOUGHTON
. I live in Harford-street, Mayfair
. On the 3rd of September, Smith, the prisoner, came to me, and said he came from
John Watson
(whom I knew) to borrow a saddle - I objected to let him have it; he returned in ten minutes, and said if I would lend it to Watson he would use it for his own riding - I let him have it for Watson; it was to be returned by twelve o'clock the same day - I saw Watson the next day, and asked him why he had not returned the saddle; he said he had never borrowed it - Watson is not here.

WILLIAM SPINDLER
. I am a general-dealer in saddles and harness. On Friday week a message was left for me to go and look at a saddle at No. 9, Hart-street - I met Webster, and said "I am going to look at a saddle, there was one lost out of the park, perhaps it is it;" I went there and asked the man in the shop if there was not a man who had a saddle to sell, he said go to the first-floor- I went up, and the woman said "My husband is gone out and has got the saddle;" I went back to my house and heard that it had been there - I went to the Duke of Wellington public-house, and saw Serjer, and another man who had the saddle; Serjer said, "It does not belong to me, it balongs to a man named Smith - I want 36s. for it;" I told Webster.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I am an officer. On the 4th of September I went and saw Serjer with the saddle - he said he bought it of a man named Smith, but he did not know where to find him; I took him - he was examined the next day; some of his friends looked out for Smith, and said he was at a public-house - I went and said, "Is your name Smith?" he said "Yes - I gave the saddle to Serjer, and I received it from Simpkins;" I took him to the office - Simpkins said he was the person who applied for it under false pretences.

Smith's Defence. I never knew where the prosecutor's shop was; I met Simpkin, who asked me if I knew a person who would buy an old saddle which he had cleaned up, as it had got mouldy - I said I knew Serjer, and took him to him.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT.
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16.
First Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1797.
WILLIAM SPONG
was indicted for
stealing,on the 2nd of September , at St. Pancras
, 1 watch, value 30s.; 5 gowns, value 3l.; 3 petticoats, value 6s.; 4 pairs of - stockings, value 4s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 9s.; 2 shifts, value 6s.; 1 sheet, value 6s.; 1 brouch, value 5s.; 1 spoon, value 2s., and 1 waistcoat, value 2s., the goods of
Mary Ann Bird
, in the dwelling-house of
Margaret Jones
, widow .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 26.

1798.
JOHN BOYCE
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Thomas Gardner Niner
, on the 24th of July , at St. Luke, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 watch, value 1l., his property .

THOMAS GARDNER NINER
. I am clerk and warehouseman to Messrs. Wood and Co., of Wood-street Cheapside. On the 24th of July, at near twelve o'clock at night, I fell in with a woman - she was a stranger to me; she accosted me, and I eventually accompanied her home - she took me to Chequer-alley, Bunhill-row
; she appeared to be a girl of the town - I was not tipsy, but a little elevated; I had been supping with a friend - I had my senses about me; I went to bed with her - I could not go to sleep, for I fancied I heard a noise in the room; it was an up stairs room - I think it was two pairs of stairs; I am almost certain of that - at last a man made his appearance before me from a cupboard; it was rather a large room, fifteen or sixteen feet long, I should think - when the man made his appearance the woman was in bed with me.

Q. When you first went into the room with the woman, did she bolt the door? A. She locked it, and she did not get up to unlock it - I had not been asleep at all; the man made his appearance from the cupboard, suddenly - it was the prisoner; I had been in bed about an hour or an hour and a half, and am quite positive nobody had opened the room door - I was undressed, and in bed; as soon as the prisoner made his appearance, I jumped out of bed; before he spoke to me - he said, "D - n your b - y eyes (or something of that sort) what do you do here with my wife?" I desired him to do me no bodily harm -I am not certain that I used the word bodily; I said this in consequence of his using these threatening expressions, and from his manner - I was very much frightened at the time at his manner and his words - he then nailed the window with a hammer and nails; it was a sliding window - he had a hammer and nail there; he then said if I made any resistance he would call those to his assistance who would use me ten times worse than he would, and that he could have plenty to his assistance; he said he would call his brother to his assistance, who would use me worse than he would, or could - the woman at this time was sitting at the foot of the bed; he went to the cupboard which he had come out of, and wetted a knife - I did not see the knife, but it had the sound of a knife; this alarmed me very much - there was no light in the room; it was daylight at the time.

Q. When he was nailing the window down, or during the time all this was going on, did he threaten you at all? A. He threatened me very much, by saying several times that he would use me ill by calling his brothers to me - he said that several times; he asked me if I could give him money - I told him I dare say I could get a friend; in fact, he asked me, when he found I had very little about me, if I could get a friend to advance me some -I had a watch in my possession; during the time I was in bed, it was in my hat, which was close by the bedside; on the chair; I dressed myself before any thing was said about the watch - when I was dressed, he said,"Leave your watch."

Q. Did he say that in a threatening manner? A. He did; I told him I valued the watch very much, but it would not be of much value to him, that he had better take what money I had and let me go; he did not take my money - I took the money in my hand and offered him - it was only 3s.; he said it was only 3s., and refused it; he made another request for my watch, and said if I did not give it up he should take other means to make me, or he should call his brothers, who would soon set me to rights, or something to that effect; I gave the watch up to him through fear from those threatenings: I had taken it from my hat and put it into my pocket; I took it from my fob, and gave it to him with my hand, through fear.

Q. You gave it out of fear from this threatening language; his whetting the knife, nailing down the window, and saying he would call his brother, who would use you worse, is that true, on your oath? A. That is true - when he first appeared at the foot of the bed I do not think he asked if I had any money; he unlocked the door and let me out; the woman was a perfect stranger to me; I had made no bargain to give her any money, but I gave her, I think, 2s. in the room; I had no intention of stopping all night; I went and gave information directly; the prisoner is the man - he was taken up in about an hour, and my watch found on him; I parted with it in consequence of fear.
Prisoner. Q. Did you give the watch into my hand? A. I did; I did not first offer to send the watch to pledge, nor offer you 50l. not to expose me to the public.

Q. Did I not tell you to be cautions under what circumstances you gave me your watch, as you valued it? A. You told me, provided I would return at ten o'clock with a sovereign, you would return me the watch; I did not authorize him to pledge it.

Q. What was the terms you gave me the watch for? A. Through fear; I was not treated with hospitality in the room; I was treated most shamefully - you did produce to me a paper which you said was the certificate of your marriage; he took it from a box, and said it was the certificate of his marriage.

JOHN BROWN
. I am an officer. The prosecutor came to my house a little after six o'clock on Friday morning, and informed me he had been robbed of his watch - I went to the house he pointed out in Chequer-alley, and went up two pairs of stairs - he gave the account he has now; he was in a very agitated state; I went up stairs to the room; the prosecutor was with me - the room was locked, and nobody in it; I obtained a key of the landlord, who lives but a few doors off - and while I was in the room searching for the property, I heard footsteps on the stairs, and the prisoner made his appearance; the prosecutor said,"That is the man who has robbed me;" I laid hold of him, and he immediately produced the watch from his pocket with a view to give it to the prosecutor; he presented it to the prosecutor as I caught hold of him, but I prevented his giving it to him.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not ask me when I entered the room where the man's watch was? A. You did not give me the opportunity - you pulled the watch out of your pocket before I could hardly get hold of you; the moment you showed your face on the top of the stairs, the prosecutor said "This is the man that robbed me;" the prisoner heard that, and it was after that he gave up the watch; I received it and took him to the office.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 24th of July, I came home about a quarter to one o'clock, and on my arrival, found the door open; the prosecutor swore it was locked and bolted at the office - I went in - this man started from the bed; I asked who he was, and what he did on my premises - he said he was seduced there by the woman; I said it was impossible, and that the woman was my wife - he said that could not be; I said it was so - he begged for mercy; and asked if I would permit him to put on his clothes - I said I would, provided he had no injurious implement about him - he asked if I would search him; I said No, I would take his word, and he dressed, placed himself in a chair, appeared very agitated, and crying out about his woman and child - he pulled from his pocket a small parcel containing a child's frock or pelisse, and said he would give me 50l. not to expose him, as he would lose his situation, and offend his wife; I staid in the room some time, then undrew the curtain - my wife placed herself near the window, and having occasion to go down stairs, I took a small brad and nail to fasten the window, which was a little open when I entered the room; I went to the cupboard to strike a light with a flint and steel, to light the fire, and the prosecutor represents that as a knife - I went down stairs, came up again in five minutes, and found him, and the woman both by the window, he blaming her for bringing him there; I then considered he had been seduced there - he begged of me to let him go; pulling a small sum of money from his pocket, asking if that and his watch would do - he asked me to pledge the watch, and asked if he could place confidence in me, and leave his watch with me till he returned; I asked what he was going away for - he said he wanted to speak to a friend; I said I was determined to look into this - he then pulled his watch from his pocket; I believe it had before been in his hat - he laid it on the table, and asked me again if he could place confidence in me, and leave it with me- seeing he had been led into an error, I said I had no objection to take care of it till he returned; he was going away - I told him to be cautious, as the neighbourhood was a bad one; I gave him a card, he wrote my address on it with pencil, and went away - he was to come to me at twelve o'clock; I went out, walked about for ten minutes, and on returning, the female was gone - I took the watch from the box, put it into my fob, and walked about looking for the female; I could not find her, and on coming back, found Brown in the room - as I entered, the prosecutor said, "This is the man;" Brown asked me"Where is the man's watch" - "Here she is" said I, pulling her out of my pocket; the prosecutor seemed inclined to take it, but Brown pulled it out of my hand. I hope you will take it into your serious consideration, and treat me with impartiality.

THOMAS GARDNER NINER
re-examined. Q. Is it true that you gave him the watch to prevent his exposing you to your wife? A. I can only say I gave it him, through fear, and from no other account whatever; I did not say any thing to him about hoping he would not expose me or tell where I had been - how could I expect he would see my wife, when he did not know me; there is not a word of truth in what he has said.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 30.
Second London Jury - before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1798.
RICHARD HUBAND JONES
,
THOMAS THOMAS MAYNARD
, and
JOSEPH WILLIAM WEST
were indicted for that
they, on the 18th of April , at St. Dunstan in the East
, feloniously did cause and procure to be falsely made, forged and counterfeited, a certain false, forged and counterfeit warrant, for payment of money , which is as follows:
Custom House, London, 9th April, 1829.

Whereas the Collector and Comptroller of Fowey have represented to us that there is not money at that port sufficient to defray the necessary charges there; and whereas the Comptroller-general, after examining the said Collector and Comptroller's account current, has certified to us the truth of the same: you are to pay Mr. William G. Hemsworth, collector of the port, the sum of 1,973l., taking his receipt for the same, attested by his Comptroller.

. 1,973. C. W. WM. CUST. S. G. LUShINGTON. H. LEGGE. To Sir
William Booth
by, Bart., Receiver-general and Cashier of the Customs. with intent to defraud our Lord the
King
, against the Statute.

2nd COUNT, the same, only charging the intent to be to defraud Sir
William Boothby
, Bart .
3rd and 4th COUNTS, the same as the first and second, only calling the instrument an order instead of a warrant.
5th COUNT, charging the prisoners with falsely making, forging and counterfeiting, &c. the said warrant, with intent to defraud the King.
6th COUNT, charging them with uttering and publishing the said warrant as true, with the like intent.
7th and 8th COUNTS, the same as the fifth and sixth, only stating the intent to be to defraud Sir William Boothby.
9th and 10th COUNTS, the same as the fifth and sixth, only calling the instrument an order instead of a warrant.
11th COUNT, for forging the same, with intent to defraud Sir William Boothby.
12th COUNT, for uttering and publishing the said order as true, with intent to defraud Sir William Boothby.

13th COUNT, for uttering and publishing as true a certain false, forged and counterfeited warrant for payment of money, and a certain false, forged and counterfeit receipt for money, well knowing the same to be false, forged, and counterfeited; and which said false, forged and counterfeit receipt for money is as follows:
Fowey, - Received, 13th April, 1829, of Sir William Boothby, Bart., Receiver-general and Comptroller of his Majesty's Customs , the sum of 1973l., being the amount of the annexed impressed order.
Witness, H. J. W. COUCHE. W. G. HEMSWORTH, Collector. with intent to defraud the King.
14th COUNT, stating the intent to be to defraud Sir William Boothby.
15th and 16th COUNTS, the same as the thirteenth and fourteenth, only calling it an order instead of a warrant, and an acquittance instead of a receipt.

17th COUNT, that the said
Thomas Thomas Maynard
feloniously did utter and publish as true the said warrant and receipt, well knowing it to be forged and counterfeited, with intent to defraud the King.

18th COUNT, that the said
Richard Huband Jones
and
Joseph William West
, before the felony last aforesaid was done and committed, feloniously and maliciously did make, move, procure, counsel, hire and command the said
Thomas Thomas Maynard
the said felony to do and commit, against the Statute.
19th and 20th COUNTS, the same as the seventeenth and eighteenth, only stating the intent to be to defraud Sir William Boothby.

21st COUNT, charging the said
Thomas Thomas Maynard
with uttering and publishing as true the said order and acquittance, well knowing it to be forged, with intent to defraud the King.

22nd COUNT, charging
Richard Huband
Jones and
Joseph William West
as accessaries before the fact, as before.
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating the intent to be to defraud Sir William Boothby.
MR. ATTORNEY-GENERAL with MESSRS. BOLLAND and SHEPPARD conducted the prosecution.

SAMUEL ROBERT
MURE. I am an extra clerk in the Comptroller-general's office, in the Custom-house, and was so in April last. These papers (looking at them) were presented to me to be entered and marked, on Saturday, the 18th of April - it was the day after Good Friday - I cannot speak exactly to the hour; it was between twelve and two o'clock; I have no recollection of the person who presented them to me - I observed he was not a tall man; I entered and marked the documents in a green book, which I hold in my hand, and returned them to the person who brought them - the prisoner Jones was a clerk in the same department as me, in the Comptroller-general's office, but does not sit in the same room - I have known him since I entered that office, which was about a year and a half ago; I never knew him in any other office in the Customs.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You put your name to them, supposing them genuine documents? A. I did.
Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. How many clerks are there in the Comptroller-general's office? A. Ten or twelve - it is all considered the same department.

EDWARD BEAUMONT
. I am assistant to the receiver general of the Customs, and was so in April last; these two documents (looking at them) were produced to me on the 18th of April by a person who was rather short - I think the person was very much like the short prisoner(Maynuard); I am unable to identify him - I saw him for a very short time; I think the resemblance strong, but cannot identify him - on the documents being put into my hand, there was something in the receipt, that struck me, a little remarkable; it appeared something like a schoolboy's writing - I communicated with the corresponding clerk, and being satisfied the document was genuine, I marked it for payment, with my initials and the date, the 18th of April - the course of business, after I had marked it, would be for the individual presenting it to me, to present it at the Treasury for payment, which, I believe, was the case - for Croxford, the clerk of the Treasury, not having cash to meet it, came to me for a cheque on the Bank, to pay it with; (looking at the cheque) this is the cheque I gave him for it - this receipt was annexed to the document, and purports to be signed by the comptroller of the Customs; when I pay a warrant of this sort, I do not ask the name of the person receiving it, or for whom it is received - that is Croxford's duty; I have been in the Custom-house upwards of thirty-four years - these two documents are filled up perfectly regular and correct in all parts.

Q. Are both these documents the work of one office or would they pass through two offices? A. That would emanate from the Secretary's department; I know of no order given at the Bank respecting the payment of cheques for the Customs - (looking at a 5l. note) after this fraud had been committed, I traced a 5l. note; I believe this is it, by the name of Maynard at the back of it, but I have put no mark on it - I obtained that note from the Bank of England; I think, on the 7th of May I went to Lees', the banker's in Lombard-street, from there to Ruden and Co's., Salvador-house, Bishopsgate-street - I finally traced it to a baker, of the name of Bristow; I have no doubt this is the note delivered to me, in consequence of this notice from the Bank, which is attached to it - I had no other 5l. note at that time; it was cancelled when I got it from the Bank - I had no other cancelled note. After this fraud was discovered, placards were stock in the lobby of the Custom-house; here is one which I took down from the officer - the 5l. note, No. 5068, is the last of the series mentioned here.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You think one of the prisoners is like the person, but you do not swear which? A. Certainly not; if I had met him in the street or play-house, I think I might have passed him without noticing him - the name of Maynard on the note is not my writing; I identify it, by that name being on it when I received it cancelled from the Bank - I never had it before.

JOHN CROXFORD
. I am in the Treasury department of the Receiver-general's office, and was so in April. These documents (looking at them) were presented to me for payment, on the 18th of April, by a person who stated that he came from Praed and Co's. house; I examined the documents afterwards, and found Praed and Co. written across it, and asked him, supposing he had been in the habit of coming from Praed's, why he had not put his name on it as usual, and he wrote his name,
Thomas Maynard
- from the appearance of the prisoner Maynard, I believe him to be the man who presented it; I had not sufficient money to pay it, and went to Mr. Beaumont and asked him for a draft on the Bank of England - he gave me this draft, to the best of my recollection (looking at it) - I gave it to Maynard; it was necessary that he should take the draft to the Comptroller-general, to be countersigned by him before it would be paid at the Bank - I do not think that I told him that was necessary.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Had you any previous acquaintance with the person you call Maynard? A.
