On the 31st of July, the prisoner came to the shop; I was showing her some prints -I saw the upper pieces move, and one slipped off the counter; the prisoner had bought eight yards of one, paid 1s. on it and said she would call for it at night - I accused her with taking one off the counter - she denied it; I came round, looked into her basket and found it there - this is it; there is nineteen yards of it - it is one I had shown her, and asked her 1s. a yard for.

Prisoner. It was not in the basket. Witness. Yes, it was; I took it out myself when I accused her of it; she took her basket and put it on the other side of her, and put her apron before it - when I found it, she said she did it through distress; that her mother was lying ill in bed, and she lived at No. 25, Golden-lane, which is false - she was not known there.

JOHN WILLIAM
HARRISON. I took the prisoner; she said she did it through distress - she had 1s. 3d.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating she was not conscious of the property being in her basket.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1813.
JAMES TURNER
and
WILLIAM PARKER
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the warehouse of
James Newton
, on the 15th of August , and stealing therein 15 glass bottles, value 3s. 9d., and 2 gallons and a half of wine, value 2l., his property .

FRANCIS HILL
. I am clerk to
James Newton
- his premises are in Harrow-alley, Aldgate High-street
, in the parish of St. Botolph. I went on Sunday morning, the 16th of August, to examine the premises - I found two locks broken and fifteen bottles of wine taken away; we picked up a crow-bar in the warehouse - Mr. Newton is a wine-merchant; I have seen some of the wine since, and have every reason to believe it is Mr. Newton's - one of the bottles has our seal on the cork, and this neck of a bottle has the seal.

JAMES ROBERTS
. On the 16th of August I was in Harrow-alley, about two o'clock in the morning; I went up the yard towards Mr. Newton's cellars, and saw the two prisoners coming out - I went up to them, and said,"What do you do here?" Parker went on - I stopped Turner, and said, "You seem very much loaded, you had better let me help you" - he had, I think, seven bottles about his body and in his coat-pockets; I took twobottles from him - he then pretended to run after the other prisoner; I called Stop thief! and did not lose sight of Turner - he was stopped as he crossed the street; Parker was brought in after I took Turner, and I have no doubt of his being the man that was with him - these are the two bottles I took from Turner; when he was stopped these bottles were broken, down his trousers, and these others were taken from him at the watch-house - I found this phosphorus-box on Parker; Mr. Newton's cellars are about three hundred yards from the street.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where was this? A. In a yard up Harrow-alley, in Aldgate High-street - I have no doubt of Parker; I described his jacket - he was not in my presence half a minute, and I had never seen him before; I should not like to be too positive.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Is there any lamp in the passage? A. Yes, a gas-lamp just over where he was - I am positive I never lost sight of Turner; I was close at his heels - I knew him before.

JOSEPH WHITNEY
. I am a watchman. At two o'clock that morning I heard a cry of Stop thief! I saw Turner run across the road - I ran and knocked him down; I took him up, and found in his breast two bottles, in his waistcoat two more, and in the thigh of his trousers this other bottle, broken - there was no one else running.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. What distance was this? A. About forty yards from Harrow-alley, on the opposite side.

WILLIAM MILLER
. I saw Parker running down Petticoat-lane, about two hundred yards from Harrow-alley, just before two o'clock - I told him to stop, and crossed to meet him: I hit him with a stick - he whipped over the way, put his hand into his bosom, took out a bottle, and hove it at me; I ran and sprang my rattle - he made a stop, and threw another bottle at me; my partner came up and stopped him - a third bottle fell from him and broke; there was red wine in that - I took up the necks of the others, but there are no marks on the corks.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How do you know it was not red mixture for colouring wine? A. I could smell it was wine - there was a gas-light just over our heads; the neck of that bottle was broken.
JURY. Q. Had you time to notice whether there was any wine in the bottles which he threw away? A. No - it was a very wet night.

DANIEL SHEPHERD
. On Sunday morning, the 16th of August, I was on duty, and heard the rattle spring - I ran up and saw Parker running; I laid hold of him - he let a bottle of wine fall, which broke all to pieces.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. It was a very wet night? A. Not then - it was very fine; it had been raining - I have no doubt the other bottle was intended for me, had it not slipped out of his hand before he had the opportunity of throwing it; I found by the smell that it was port-wine - I swear it was not claret.
Turner's Defence. I had been at a public-house, and had occasion to go up this passage - I saw the bottles; I was going to apprize the owner of it - there is some sheep dung up the alley.

Parker's Defence. I work on board some barges, for Mr. Curry, of Russell-buildings - I was going home, up Petticoat-lane, and the first watchman struck me; I certainly had three bottles, but they were not wine - he broke one, and one fell down; I did not run, but was going along, and the other watchman took me.
MR. HILL. I have now opened the bottles - they are port, and we missed bottles of this description.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Had you occasion to inspect the cellar? A. I had been there two or three days before - no bottle is sold out of that cellar; they come to our house for it - I swear it was not sold, because I keep the books; I could see by the saw-dust that some had been taken.

COURT. Q. What was the wine kept there for? A. For stock - we never go there for small quantities; we use it as a warehouse - it is a large cellar or vault; I missed fifteen bottles. TURNER -
GUILTY . Aged 27.

PARKER -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1814.
CHARLES WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , at St. Michael, Cornhill
, 28 pieces of foreign gold coin called Napoleons, value 22l., the property of
Adey Bellamy Savory
, in his dwelling-house .
SECOND COUNT, the same, only omitting the words in italics.

ADEY BELLAMY SAVORY
. I am a
dealer in bullion
, and live at No. 14, Cornhill
. I had forty-five Napoleons on the 20th of July, and twenty-eight of them were taken; I had not noticed them very particularly; I deal in money generally - they were taken from my son; I was present, but did not see them taken; they were usually kept in a drawer, or in a bowl in the window.

JOSEPH SAVORY
. I am the prosecutor's son. On the 20th of July a person came into the shop and asked for 50l. worth of French money - I counted out forty-five Napoleons into my hand and laid them on the counter; I turned to my desk to reckon what they would come to, and the person who came for them said he would step into Birch's and take something while I made the account; the prisoner then came in, seized a handful of the Napoleons, and ran off - I called my father from the back shop, and jumped over the counter - I pursued the prisoner down Pope's Head-alley and Lombard-street to the Mansion-house; a person I knew, of the name of Finch, was coming by, he saw I could hardly catch him, he caught him, and brought him back - the prisoner was running: Finch is not here; I took the prisoner to our counting-house, and went back to Pope's Head-alley to look for one Napoleon he had dropped, but it was gone; he had the rest of the money on him.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Were they in your possession? A. They were on the counter close before me; I did lose sight of the person who took them for perhaps half a minute or a quarter of a minute - he ran two hundred or two hundred and fifty yards before he was taken; it was about five o'clock - there were a great number of persons about - our dwelling-house is in the parish of St. Michael, Cornhill; the Napoleons were within half a yard of me - they had not been paid for.
COURT. Q. Had there been any bargain between you? A. No.

WILLIAM WORCESTER
. I took the prisoner at the shopa quarter before five o'clock; I saw the witness coming with him - I went and searched his person; he said, "They are in this pocket;" and took twenty-five Napoleons out of his right-hand pocket, and put them into my hand; I felt in his pocket and found one more, and one was found on the mat of the door - one I understood was lost.
Prisoner. Is the property in Court?

JOSEPH SAVORY
. No; the gentleman came in again for it and had it - he was a most respectable man.
COURT. Q. Is this a dwelling-house? A. There is a watchman sleeps there; there is a bed, but we do not use it.
Four witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 27.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, on account of his character .

1815.
WILLIAM WARD
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Hough
, on the 8th of August , and stealing 320 yards of gilt moulding, value 7l. 10s.; 12 yards of baize, value 14s., and 1 blanket, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Edwards
.

RICHARD HOUGH
. I live in East Harding-street, St. Bride's
. On Friday night, the 7th of August, my street door was double locked, by my son - when I came down in the morning the box was broken off and the lock was double shot - these gold mouldings which had been on the landing of the stairs were gone; they had been rolled up in a green baize as they are now.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When was this? A. On Saturday morning, the 8th of August - I did not call a constable - I know a man of the name of Smith, who came half drunk to examine the door, after the prisoner had been examined two or three times - he said he came to examine the door, but he did not - I certainly was taken into custody on this charge myself, and my son; I believe that was the only charge ever made against me - I have no recollection of ever being taken up on a charge of felony; I do not recollect that I was ever taken up; if I ever was, I have forgotten it - I cannot swear to a thing I do not recollect - I have been on a Jury, and I have been a constable - I cannot give any other answer; I have known Smith but a short time; I do not know that he is a constable - I have not received any money for the evidence I am to give - I borrowed some money of Mr. Edwards; I expect the reward according to the hand-bill as I took the prisoner with the property, and if it belongs to any body, I suppose it does to me - I did not say to Edwards, "You may as well let me have some money now, as it will be part of the 5l.,; and I am sure of convicting him;" I had about 2l. which I borrowed, and the boy's wages; the boy has seven shillings a week - I had seven shillings on that, and I think I borrowed four times ten shillings of him - I believe the prisoner has a high shoe, but he can walk as well as I can - I believe I received 1l. of Mr. Edwards, on the first or second examination - I did not borrow it to get my clothes out of pawn, that I might be a respectable witness - some of my clothes were in pawn, and very likely I might take some of them out with that money - I was kept in custody from Saturday night till Monday, and was examined before Alderman Ansley - I did drink a glass of gin with the prisoner when we were looking after the moulding - I did not know him before; but when I heard where the mouldings were, I went to him politically, as I understood he had offered them to Fairbrother - I went to the Spotted Dog, and found the prisoner; I called him out, and said,"I want to speak you; but we won't go into the taproom, as there are some people there" - he made no objection to go into the parlour; he said, "I thought you were coming to tap me on the shoulder for a bill of exchange;" I said, "No, Ward, I am nothing in that way; but Fairbrother says you know a person who has some mouldings to sell;" he said, "They are as far off as Mile-end-road;" I said, "I don't mind going as far as that;" he said, "You can't see them; a friend of mine took them for a bad debt, but if you will give me 3l. 10s., I will go and fetch them;" I said, "No, but call in the landlord;" the landlord came - I said, "I will put two sovereigns in your hand, to bind the bargain; and if Ward brings the mouldings, and they are what I want, I shall have thirty shillings more to give;" the prisoner then called a man named Nelson from the tap-room, and went out to fetch the mouldings; in fifteen or twenty minutes Nelson and he brought in these mouldings; he said, "Now, here they are;" my son was present, and I believe the landlord - I looked at them, and I said, "Mr. Ward, last Saturday morning my front-door was broken open, between five and six o'clock, and you are very much like the man that came out with these mouldings;" I gave charge of him - he said he thought I had behaved very bad to him; I said, "You need not think any thing of that, as I was taken up, and was forty-eight hours in hold;" the officer said, "You had better tell who was with you;" he said, "I will have my b-y neck broken before I will split;" the reason I called him Ward was, because his wife went with me, and she called him Ward - I might have been in the same room with him before, but not to my knowledge - I have not drank gin with him before or since.

HENRY EDWARDS
. I had these gold mouldings safe at my own house in the middle of the day, on the 7th of August; I went out, and left word with my lad,
Samuel Hough
, to leave work at seven o'clock, and take them to Mr. Moore's at the other end from the town, instead of which he stopped at his father's, the last witness, and left them there - I have seen them in the hands of the officer, and know them to be mine; also the baize and the cloth.

Cross-examined Q. How many whole windows are there in Hough's house? A. I think very few; there are very few panes of glass whole - it is very much dilapidated; I know Smith - he is a gilder; he is not a constable now - Hough has had 2l. from me by three instalments; I do not recollect when he had the first, but he said it was to enable him to appear respectable at Guildhall to give evidence - he asked for it for the purpose of taking his clothes out of pawn; but before the second hearing he sent for some more money I would not let him have it - he came in his former dishabille; whether he asked for any more then or no I cannot say - he did ask for it on the ground of what he should receive on conviction, but I said I was so little acquainted with those things, that I did not know whether he was the right man to have it, but at any rate he could not have it till after the conviction - he has made no proposition to me to quash this prosecution; he is glad it has happened, and wanted tomake as much of a job of it as possible - after I refused to let him have any more money, he was ungenerous enough to serve me with a writ for false imprisonment, and I was taken up.

SAMUEL HOUGH
. I was in Mr. Edward's employ, and received this property to take to Mr. Moore's, in St. Martin's-lane, but I took it to my father's house, as I have done before - I double locked the street door, and the next morning the box of the lock was off, the lock double-shot, and the door broken open; I ran out into the street very much alarmed, and a young woman said she saw two men, one in a fustian dress, a tall thin man, and the other a short stout man, with a blue frock coat and black apron.

Cross-examined. Q. What kind of house is your father's? A. A very large house - I was quite surprised at finding the door open; I had locked it - the windows are nailed up all but one; there are not above two or three panes broken - my master has said before, that if I felt myself tired I might leave my work at my father's; I was taken up, and so was my father; we have served a writ on Mr. Edwards - Smith came to examine the door; he did not examine it very attentively; he came tipsy with another man - I do not know whether he examined the door - he was standing on the steps; I suppose his eyes were three quarters of a yard from the door.

COURT. Q. You thought, from your master's practice, you might leave these at your father's? A. Yes: I was to have received some more in the wood at Mr. Moore's, and he said if I was tired I might leave them at my father's.
MR. EDWARDS. I went out about dinner time, and told him I wished him to leave work at seven o'clock, and take them.

RACHAEL WILLIAMS
. I was near Mr. Hough's house about half-past five o'clock that morning, and saw two young men come out of the house without anything; they went towards Gough-square - the prisoner has the features of one of them; I observed he was a stout man, but I cannot say it was the prisoner - before six o'clock I saw a man go and push the door open, go to the corner, then go into the house, and bring something out in a green cloth on his shoulder, and go towards Gough-square; I did not know they were mouldings - I afterwards saw the boy crying, and said, "What have you lost?" he told me, and I said, "It was gone out of your house before six o'clock."

GEORGE FAIRBROTHER
. I am a picture-frame maker. The prisoner came to me about the 10th of August - he called me down stairs, and said a person at the end of the court had something to sell in my way; he did not know exactly what; I went to the end of the court - a person there pulled out a piece of moulding, and said he had some hundreds of yards of it for sale; I said I did not want any of it - the prisoner was at the opposite side of the court; the mouldings were similar to these - I told Mr. Hough of it, and he asked if I could tell him where the person lived who offered them; I took him to the prisoner's house, in Star-court - he is a very respectable man; he is lame - no one can see him walk without knowing it; he goes very much on one side.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. About four years: I was not at the public-house when he was apprehended - I came in afterwards, and went to the watch-house; I did not hear him say he would rather be hanged than split - I do not think he did.

SAMUEL HOUGH
. The prisoner said he thought he was very ill-used; the officer said, "You had better tell who was with you" - he said, "I will rather have my b-y neck scragged than split."

JOHN DUNCAN
. I received the prisoner on the 11th of August. In taking him to the watch-house, I said he should tell where he got them - he said he would suffer his neck to be twisted, or something, before he would let any one into it; they were found at the Spotted Dog, in Clement's-lane.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not the word he used, that he would sooner have his neck twisted than peach? A. That might be the word - I understood sooner than implicate another person.

COURT. Q. What was it? A. I should surmise that there was some other person connected with the robbery, and he would sooner take the whole weight upon himself than tell of any other person - Fairbrother was in custody at the time.

Cross-examined. Q. He spoke rather angrily, I believe? A. Yes; I cannot charge my memory as to whether I spoke to him about my being in difficulties, and had got over them - I might have said it, or I might not; I have been tried, but I really do not know whether I said so to him or no - it was an attempt at a rape charged against me - you pleaded the cause for me, and I was honourably acquitted.

Prisoner's Defence. I am totally innocent; it is necessary to state that I wear a cork shoe four inches high - this girl said she saw some person come out like my features; this prosecution has been got up for the money - this man got bills stuck up; a person came to me, and asked if I knew a person in the gilding line - I said, Yes, and directed him to Fairbrother; Hough then came to me with my wife, and made me drink; as he told the Alderman - he made people drunk, and then got any thing out of them; he then said I knew a person who had some gilt mouldings, and if I would bring them, he would give me 2l., and no questions should be asked - he then sent for a constable, and had us all taken.
NOT GUILTY .

1816.
JOHN ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 pair of half-boots, value 4s. , the goods of
George Clarke
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Jane Clarke
.

GEORGE CLARKE
. I am a shoemaker and Manchester warehouseman : my dwelling-house is at No. 29, Stonecutter-street
, where my wife keeps a shop . The prisoner and another man came there with each a basket, on the 6th of August - the prisoner asked for some half-boots to look at, and then said he would come again; the other man then said he would come again - my wife said to the prisoner."Where are those I showed you?" he said, "You put them into the glass case:" I said to him, "Let me look into your basket;" he set off and ran - I pursued; he dropped the basket, and it contained these boots; I took them up, and a neighbour stopped him - I gave him in charge.

JANE CLARKE
. I am the prosecutor's wife: he hasstated what is correct. I had seen these boots safe ten minutes before.

WILLIAM DRINKWATER
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - these boots were given to me; he had a crown-piece and a sixpence.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had no intention to steal them.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Seven Years .

1817.
MARY MAHONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 8 1/2 yards of ribbon, value 6s. , the goods of
Henry Gaze
.

- GAZE. I am the wife of
Henry Gaze
: he has a milliner's shop in Cheapside
. The prisoner came there, and asked to look at some ribbons, at half-past five o'clock, on the 22nd of August; I shewed her some - she staid above five minutes; she did not buy any, but was going away - I saw something under her shawl, turned it back, and saw this ribbon, which I took from her; it was one of the pieces I had shown her - she said she had not taken it.
Prisoner. Q. Did I turn from the counter? A. You went a little way from the counter - I do not think you turned your back.

Prisoner. I stood at the counter, and you accused me of stealing it; I looked, and it was on the counter, under my shawl. Witness. She was about half a yard from the counter - I saw something project under her shawl, turned back her shawl, and took it.

SAMUEL PAGE
. I was sent for, and took this ribbon from the witness - I searched her as far as decency would permit, and then Mrs. Gaze searched her, and found this other ribbion in her bosom.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to see if they could match the ribbon I had, but they had none - I deferred having any.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1818.
JAMES WHITTLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of a person unknown, from his person .

EDWARD MOORE
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 4th of September I saw the prisoner in Bartholomew-fair
, about five o'clock; he took this handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, who was standing looking at Clarke's show - he handed it to a woman who appeared as his wife; she put it into her bosom - I seized him; some persons came up and hustled me - an officer came up and I took him to the Compter.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Was this during the fair? A. Yes; there were a great many people - I distinctly saw the prisoner take the handkerchief; he was not a yard from me - I went back and looked for the gentleman, but could not find him; I had not an opportunity of mentioning it to him at the time, because I was hustled by the prisoner's confederates - I had seenthem with the prisoner before; there were four of them.
Prisoner's Defence. When the officer took me, I said"Why do not you speak to the person I took it from?" but he dragged me away.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Third London Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1819.
HENRY WICKS
was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Edward Turner
, from his person .

HENRY EDWARD TURNER
. I am a clerk . About two o'clock, on the 4th of August, I was in Cheapside
- before I had got to Cheapside I had felt a push against me, and when I got there I wanted my handkerchief, and missed it from my coat pocket; I turned round and saw the prisoner putting it into his own pocket - I collared him, took it from him, and took him to Guildhall.

CHARLES RICHARD BULL
. I am a porter. I saw the prisoner take this handkerchief from Mr. Turner's pocket - he put it into his own pocket; Mr. Turner collared him, and said, "You have got my handkerchief" - he said "It was that boy;" there was no other boy.
Prisoner. Q. Why did you not take me? A. The gentleman took you before I could come up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1820.
GEORGE SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William George Rolfes
, from his person .

WILLIAM GEORGE ROLFES
. I am a broker . I was passing through Abchurch-lane
on the 4th of September, the officer asked if I had lost a handkerchief - I felt, and it was gone; he went and fetched the prisoner, and this handkerchief, which I believe is mine.

JOHN GIRTON
. I am an officer. I saw this gentleman in Abchurch-lane - I saw the prisoner go up by the Post-office, put his hand into this gentleman's pocket, and take out the handkerchief; I told the gentleman, then went and took the prisoner with it, between his breast and his waistcoat - he took it out and threw it down; there were others with him.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take it at all.
The prisoner received a good character, and his father promised to take care of him.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.

1821.
SAMUEL SMITH
and
RICHARD GRAHAM
were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Gansden
and
Judah Jacobs
, on the 22nd of June , and stealing therein 2 coats, value 30s., their property .

WILLIAM GANSDEN
. I live in Barbican
, and am a tailor
. On the 22nd of June, about twelve o'clock in the day, a pane of glass was shoved in, and two coats taken out of the window - I did not see the transaction; I have no doubt the glass was perfectly sound - I had probably seen it in the course of the morning several times, but cannot say exactly; I had been up stairs about ten minutes, was called down, and saw some persons in my shop - they said, "Here is a man who has been taking two coats out of your window;" one of the prisoners were there, and they were pursuing the other.

ANTHONY ROWEN
. I am a watchman. I was coming up Barbican - I saw the two prisoners at the prosecutor's window; I saw Graham put his hand in, and pull thesecoats towards the window - he took one out and gave it to Smith, who concealed it under his coat; Graham then took another, and they walked on towards Smithfield- I rushed in between them, seized Smith, and brought him back; the officer followed Graham, and took him within four or five minutes - I found one coat on Smith.
Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. How long did you see them there? A. A long time - I had a good view of the window; I cannot tell whether they were drunk or sober.

WILLIAM CARTLAND
. I am a brewer's labourer. I was crossing to Golden-lane, and saw the prisoners at the window - Graham had his arm in the window; I told Rowen to look - I then saw the officer coming along, and told him; he pursued, and took Graham - a coat was found on each.

JOSEPH HORTON
. I am an officer. I produce two coats - I took Graham with one of them, and the other was found on Smith.

WILLIAM GANSDEN
. They are the property of myself and my partner,
Judah Jacobs
.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not state last Session, that your partner's name was Lawrence Miles? A. No.
Graham's Defence. I was intoxicated, and have no recollection of it.
SMITH - GUILTY. Aged 23.
GRAHAM - GUILTY. Aged 29.

Of stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1822.
FREDERICK IRELAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
Edward John Ockley
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1823.
JOHN STEDMAN
was
indicted for a misdeameanour .

The
prisoner pleaded GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

1824.
THOMAS BIRCH
was
indicted for fraud .

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY .
Confined Six Months .

1825.
THOMAS FARLEY
was
indicted for a misdemeanour .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1826.
WILLIAM HARRISON SCATE
and
EDMUND SEALE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 6 pairs of stockings, value 13s.; 6 shifts, value 30s.; 1 veil, value 2l.; 3 petticoats, value 9s.; 4 yards of silk, value 20s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 shawl, value 9s.; 4 yards of lace, value 10s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 12s.; 1 sovereign; 1 half-crown; and 12 shillings , the property of
Emma Harwood
.

EMMA HARWOOD
. I live at No. 4, Leicester-street, Leicester-square
; I am a dress-maker - I occupy a room at the top of the house; this property was all taken from there - it was all secure on the 27th of August, when I left it in the morning, and the following morning it was missing - I have seen it since in Bear-street, Leicester-square, in the prisoner Scate's possession; he is a broker - I did not know him before this; I did not know the other prisoner till this occurrence; the property was distrained for 2l. 17s. 9d. rent; the inventory was left, stating that the property was at No. 4, Lloyd's-court, St. Giles' - I found it at Mr. Scate's warehouse on the Monday, where other goods were kept; I could not find Mr. Scate at home till the Monday - on the Friday, Mr.
William King
called and told me where the property was; when I saw Mr. Scate, I told him I was come to pay the rent and the expences, but there was no rent due - the things were not on the premises when the rent became due. I was before Sir George Farrant - Mr. Scate was sent for several times, but he did not come, and Sir
George Farrant
advised me to prefer a bill against him - I did not owe any rent at the time the things were removed; he removed them by my direction in the first instance, and then he got Mrs. Sanders, who was my landlady, to allow him to seize - I have not got my property again.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Should you know Mrs. Sanders' hand-writing? A. Yes; I believe the name of "Dinah Sanders" to this paper, is her writing - I am not aware that I have gone by a dozen names; I am come into Court quite unprepared to meet the trial, and my most essential witness is out of town - I have not gone by any names, known to Scate but Harwood, and that name he has seized in; I have gone by three names, but not by any other name than Harwood in this affair - I did go by the name of Richardson, from family circumstances; I have a brother by the same father but not by my mother; he has a brass plate on his door in the name of Edgar, and I have been addressed as Miss Edgar in the way of business - I lived at Brompton when I went by the name of Richardson: I knew a gentleman of that name, but in consequence of my own family, I must beg leave to decline answering these questions.

COURT. Q. When did you remove? A. On the 8th of August, and the rent was due on the 10th - the things were left under Scate's care, in Leicester-street, where he took them from Well-street, till a debt was paid; he was to remove them merely as a broker, not to keep them - I had a landlady named Mrs. Sanders; my quarter with her expired on the 10th of August - before I removed I paid her all; I believe she is here to prove it - I had entrusted this property to be taken care of by Scate; he removed it from Leicester-street to Bear-street, under a distress for rent due to Mrs. Sanders, as he said, but I owed her none - the things were taken out of the drawers and pawned; there was a purse with a sovereign in it, and some duplicates - Scate redeemed some of the things.

Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. You have sworn to your landlady's writing? A. I have sworn to my belief of it; I never saw her write but once - she told me she had signed a warrant; this paper is not my hand-writing - I will swear it is not.

COURT. Q. Did you ever sign any receipt? A. Never, but in the presence of witnesses; I only signed two receipts - one for 2l. 5s. 9d., and one other; the value of my property was about 60l.; Mr. Seale's bill is 7l. 1s.; I have not seen all my property - a purse, a sovereign, and some duplicates are missing; no one has given me any account of that money - the property I have seen is worth about 40l.; that is now detained for the 7l. - (paper read.)
I hereby undertake to redeem the goods contained in the inventory hereunto annexed on Saturday - in default of my doing so, I give all power over them to Mr. Seale.
Witness. The money has been tendered, but not the 7l.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am a broker. I have seen the property in Seale's shop.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you not a convict? A. No; there is a judgment hanging over me till next Term - I have been convicted in the Court of King's Bench, for being misled by a landlord.

HARFORD JONES
. I am drawn into a conspiracy. A person redeemed two rings, who very much resembled Scate - I have been induced to swear he is the person; I am almost certain he is not - they sent him on purpose, I am sure they have.
NOT GUILTY .

1827.
ANN LAWDAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of March , 2 snuff-boxes, value 10s.; 1 segartube, value 2s.; 1 veil, value 10s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s., and 1 pillow-case, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Chave
.

The witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1828.
MICHAEL DUFF
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Thomas Turpin
, on the 8th of August , at Christchurch, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 sovereign, 2 half-crowns, and three halfpence, his property .

THOMAS TURPIN
. I am a painter and glazier ; I live in Grey Eagle-street, and work for Mr. Hart. On the 8th of August, about half-past twelve o'clock at night, I was in Black Eagle-street
; I had been drinking a little, but I was sober - I was leaning my hand upon a dray; I felt myself sick; I am often taken sick and faint in my business - the prisoner and another man came up; one of them struck me in the back, and I felt my waistcoat pockets lift up, and heard my money rattle; I put my hand into my pocket, and ran and called Watch! the prisoner and the other ran away - I lost a sovereign and two half-crowns from my right-hand pocket, and three halfpence from my other pocket; I left my hat behind me, and followed them about one hundred and forty yards; I stated at first it was two hundred yards, but I have measured it since - the prisoner ran down to Grey Eagle-street; he turned two corners, but I was close to him, and never lost sight of him; I took him, held him till the watchman came, and gave charge of him- I then went back, and got my hat; I am quite sure the prisoner is one of them: I am sure I had the money before that; for as we were coming out of a public-house I took the sovereign and two half-crowns, put them in my right-hand pocket, and the three halfpence in the other; that was about half an hour before - I was not knocked down; it was a blow between my shoulders; it was from a fist, I think.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. The two half-crowns and sovereign were in your right-hand pocket, and the three halfpence in the other? A. Yes; I was ten or eleven hundred yards from the public-house I had come out of; it was the Blue Coat Boy, in Dorset-street; there are warehouses where I was robbed; it was half-past twelve o'clock; I had just come out of the public-house, and was leaning my hand against a dray - I left work at eight o'clock, and went to have a pint of beer at the Seven Stars, in Brick-lane, with two of my shopmates and one of their brothers; we had two pots of beer there, and whether it was one or two quarterns of gin I cannot be certain - I changed a shilling there, and paid for one pot of beer; I put a few halfpence towards the gin - I spent 10 1/2d. altogether; my day's wages was 3s. 6d.; we then went to the Blue Coat Boy, had one pot of beer and one quartern of gin; we went there about half-past ten o'clock, and staid till twelve - we drank no more; I was quite sober; I saw the prisoner searched at the watch-house; I do not know that he stated the exact money he had in his pockets; no sovereign was found upon him; he did tell me to go home for a drunken fellow, and not to follow him, for he was not the man; I was calling Stop thief! because he was going away from me; I do not know any thing about him - I never was in a Court of Justice or before a Magistrate - I go to work at six o'clock in the morning.
COURT. Q. You say there was a sovereign and two half-crowns in one pocket and three halfpence in the other, and the prisoner ran away, and said, "What do you follow me for? A. Yes.

JOHN BUDMORE
. I am a watchman. On the 8th of August I was on duty in Brick-lane, between twelve and one o'clock; I heard a cry of Watch! and ran as fast as possible; when I got to Black Eagle-street, where the drays stand, I saw a bat lay; I passed that, and went on; the prosecutor had hold of the prisoner, he said, "I give you charge of him, he has robbed me of a sovereign;" he did not then mention any half-crown; but in going along he said he had lost two half-crowns and three half-pence -I took the prisoner back; the prosecutor took up his hat, and we went to the watch-house - I could perceive the prosecutor had been drinking; but he walked, and told his story very sensibly.

Cross-examined. Q. Would you say he told the truth if he said he was quite sober? A. He had been drinking, but he must have gone very rapidly to the place where he took the prisoner - he seemed capable of knowing what he was about; I think he had taken rather too much - he did not, at that time, say in which pocket he had his different monies; I saw the prisoner pull the money out of his own pocket - there were two half-crowns, and I think 7 1/2d.; but the watchman has nothing to do with that.

DANIEL GRAY
. I saw the prosecutor have in his possession one sovereign, two half-crowns, and some copper, because he changed 1s.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A painter and glazier - I was with him at the Seven Stars, and we then went to the Blue Coat Boy: I left him in Brown's-lane, and hade him good night - that was close to his own house; it would not take him above five minutes to go home - he was not sick when I left him; he had not been drinking so as not to know what he was doing.

MOSES SIMMONS
. I was the watch-house-keeper. The prisoner was brought there, and searched in my presence - there were two half-crowns and 7 1/2d. on him; the prosecutor charged him with having robbed him of a sovereign, two half-crowns, and 1 1/2d. - he appeared to tell his story sensibly.

Cross-examined. Q. Had he been drinking? A. Yes, I thought so, and at first refused to take the charge,but afterwards he told his story so correctly I did not think he had been drinking; the reason I thought he had been drinking at first was he seemed in a great flustration, and said he had been robbed a great many times over - I did not think he was drunk but that he had been drinking; at first he kept saying, "I have been robbed of a sovereign and 5s." for several minutes: and from his manner I did not think it was true - he did not at first say which pockets the coin had been in, but afterwards said the half-crown and sovereign were in one pocket and the 1 1/2d. in the other; I knew him by sight - the prisoner produced the money himself.

Prisoner's Defence. I came home from work at half-past eight o'clock - I said to my father, "Shall I go and enter myself into that benefit society to night?" he said,"You are getting a young family, I think it would be advisable;" I said my master would not give me any money - he said, "You shall not be lost for that;" and he went out, changed a sovereign, and lent me two halfcrowns and one shilling - I went to the Sugar Loaf to be entered, but the man, who was to propose me, was not there; I stopped, and had a pint of porter, a small glass of gin, and a short pipe of tobacco, which cost 4 1/2d. -I remained there to see if this man was there when the society broke up, but he did not come; that made me late - as I turned into Grey Eagle-street to go home this young man came and said, "I will have you about my sovereign;" I said, "Go about your business, you drunken fellow" - he laid hold of me, the watchman came up, and took me; the watchman said, "Come to the watch-hosue, you can see the man is drunk."
Five witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 24.
OLD COURT.
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 17.
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1829.
HENRY KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June , at St. Anne, 3 watches, value 46l., and 1 seal, value 4l., the goods of
Charles Wieland
, in his dwelling-house .

CHARLES WIELAND
. I am a watch-maker , and live at Limehouse, in the parish of St. Anne
, and rent the house. I became acquainted with the prisoner's friends at Boulogne; his father keeps an hotel there, and is a very respectable person - in consequence of this I became acquainted with the prisoner, and he lodged in my house as a friend; he had been there about eight days on the 10th of June, when my son missed some watches - in consequence of what he said, I looked and missed three from a drawer, and a gold watch, which was locked in a dressing-case in my bed-room; he had access to any part of the house - he left the house when I was out; I expected to see him again in the evening - he did not return; this was on the 10th of June - I did not see him again till the 11th of July.

THOMAS WALKER
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce a watch, pawned by the prisoner on the 10th of June.

CHARLES FREEMAN
. I am an officer. I saw this robbery mentioned in the reports; I apprehended the prisoner on the 11th of July, on suspicion, and found a watch pawned at Walker's; the prisoner told me he had sold the gold watch to a watch-maker at Chatham, and the other to a shoemaker at Gravesend; I went and found them both.

JOHN IGGLESDEN
. I am a watch-maker, and live at Chatham. I bought this watch of a person; it was not the prisoner.

SAMUEL SAUNDERS
. I live at Gravesend. I bought this watch of the prisoner.

CHARLES WIELAND
. These are my three watches - here is one silver repeater, worth 30l., with the seal attached to it, which is worth 5l.; I should charge 35l. for the watch and all - this other watch is worth 22l.; he broke open two sets of drawers and a dressing-case. He attended his father's billiard-rooms at Boulogne.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 20.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor, on account of his family, and believing it to be his first offence .

1830.
THOMAS EDWARDS
and
HENRY DUFFY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , at Hornsey, 2 cows, price 40l. , the property of
John Bacon
.

EDWARDS
pleaded GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 18.

JOHN BACON
. I live at Grenville-mews, Somer's-town. On the 3rd of August I had six cows in Southwood-lane, Hornsey
, which I should think is at least thirteen miles from Dulwich - my man left them in Southwood-lane, on the 3rd of August - he was examined at the office, but the Magistrate did not bind him over, on account of the expence: I saw them in the field about three days before, and on the day before, I think; I will swear I saw them safe three days before they were stolen - on the 3rd of August, about two o'clock, I found two of them were gone; I went to Smithfield, and inquired about them among the drovers and Police - I got information, and went back to my fields to be certain they had not broken out - I found them both in Kennington-pound on Tuesday morning, the 4th of August, about ten o'clock; they appeared jaded, and very thin indeed - their bags were ready to burst with milk - I took Edwards in custody on Tuesday morning, in an open shed, at Dulwich; he had lived with me, and left me on the 17th of February - the prisoners are own brothers; Duffy came twice to see him while he lived with me - Edwards gave the name of Edwards when he lived with me - the other goes by the name of Henry Duffy; I know him by his visiting his brother - I took him in Bunhill-row, on the 6th of August, in consequence of information.

JAMES PAGE
. I live at Muswell-hill. On Monday morning, the 3rd of August, between four and five o'clock, I was going to work, and saw the two prisoners in Mr. Bacon's field; I saw them drive the two cows out of the field - Edwards opened the gate, the other drove them out, and Edwards fastened the gate up after him - I live adjoining the field, and knew the cows; I have seen them since, and know them to be the same - I knew
Thomas Edwards
before, but not Duffy; I rather think he is the other man by his clothes - I looked at him, and believe he is the man, but I am not exactly positive; I said I thought him the lad, when he was taken up, and think so still.
JURY. Q. Have you any other means of being certain of him except by his clothes? A. No; I thought they were going to take them home - I knew Edwards had been in Bacon's service.

STEPHEN BROWN. I live at Mr. Upjohn's, at Highgate - I know Bacon, and knew his cows. On the 3rd of August, between four and five o'clock in the morning, I was about half a mile from Bacon's field, and saw his two cows - I have seen them since, and know them to be the same; Edwards was one person who was driving them, and Duffy the other - I knew Edwards in Bacon's service, and thought he was going to take them home; I am sure of the other prisoner - I had never seen him before, but took notice of him, and said he was the man when he was apprehended.

GEORGE CORK
. I am an assistant to Mr. Moyes, a salesman, of Smithfield-market. On Monday, the 3rd of August, about eight o'clock, Edwards brought me two cows, and delivered them to a drover's charge, to tie them up; the drover asked who was to sell them; he said,"The salesman that stands before the Bear and Ragged Staff;" we usually stand there - at one o'clock Edwards came to Mr. Moyes, and the cows were taken away - I never saw Duffy.

JOHN WARREN
. I am an officer. I was on duty at Dulwich, on the 3rd of August, and saw Bacon, who informed me of the robbery - I only know that two cows were turned out in a field at Dulwich.

SAMUEL CHAMBERS
. I am a Bow-street patrol, and was with Warren.

JOHN BACON
. Edwards left my service on the 17th of February, and lived with Mr. Marsh, of John-street, Kent-road.
Duffy's Defence. I neither had any thing to do with what I am charged with, nor do I know any thing about them.

DUFFY -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 20.

1831.
CATHERINE WINGROVE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 80 yards of carpet, value 14l., and 15 yards of oil-cloth, value 2l., the goods of
Samuel Hollingsworth
, in his dwelling-house .

SAMUEL HOLLINGSWORTH
. I live in Bedford-street, Bedford-row
. I have lost a quantity of property, carpets, and rugs - the prisoner's husband was our porter, and lived in the house, but he had left when this property was taken - I never saw the prisoner there; the property must have been taken through the connivance of my son, who, as well as my porter, have both been convicted.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Gazelee.

1832.
MARK JOEL
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Bloom
, in the Liberty of Norton-falgate, on the 27th of May , and stealing therein 1000 yards of silk, value 500l., his property .
2nd COUNT, calling it a warehouse instead of a dwelling-house.
3rd COUNT, for stealing 100 yards of silk, value 20l., the goods of the said John Bloom.
MR. BRODRICK conducted the prosecution.

SUSANNAH BLOOM
. I am the daughter of John Bloom, who lives in Spital-square, in the Liberty of Nortou-falgate
. On the 27th of May my father went out, about ten o'clock in the morning - the warehouse is part of the dwelling-house, and under the same roof; in consequence of information from the servant, I went and looked at the warehouse at half-past four o'clock in the afternoon, and saw that a wooden window of the warehouse, which is in the passage, was taken down, and laid in the passage - my father came home about five o'clock, and I communicated to him what had happened.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. How many persons were in the house? A. Three; my mother, the servant, and myself - it is our dwelling-house; the family live there - I might have seen the property before, but I did not take any particular notice of it.

JOHN BLOOM
. My house is No. 24, Spital-square, in the Liberty of Norton-falgate; it is extra parochial. On Wednesday, the 27th of May, when I came home, about half-past five or six o'clock, in consequence of information, I went to the warehouse, and found it broken open - a wooden window, which had originally been a door, and slides up and down, was taken down - I found every thing on the counter as I had left them in the morning, and did not examine the rest of my stock till Saturday morning, when I had to execute some orders, and the very goods I wanted to send out were gone - I reckon that above nine hundred yards of silk were gone; I was in the habit of seeing it every day, and am sure it was there on the Tuesday and Wednesday morning - I know it was there; I missed fourteen pieces, containing about nine hundred yards - the value is about 320l.; the shortest piece was worth at least 12l. - I am certain no piece was worth less than 5l. On the 7th of August I was going along the Quadrant, in Regent-street, and saw part of one of my pieces of silk in the shop of Mr. Poulson, a tailor; I went in, and asked the price of it - I examined it, and was sure it was mine; Poulson gave me a pattern of it, and on the 20th of August I went there with an officer, and found the piece in the same state as when I first saw it - I brought it away, and there was a short length of another piece; the officer has them.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you any other name? A. No, nor any partner; I reside at the house - the silks were on the ground floor.

Q. How does it happen that you did not discover the robbery the next morning? A. Being trustee to an estate I was obliged to go out next morning early - the property might have been stolen between the Wednesday and Saturday, for what I know; I was in the habit of seeing those fourteen pieces of silk every day before Wednesday - I was busy out of doors on Thursday and Friday- when I was at Poulson's I fixed on one piece of silk, which I said belonged to me; and it did not afterwards turn out that it had been in the shop for six months previous- I went to Mr. Shoolbred's and saw a good many pieces of silk, but none of mine; there were several young men there- I do not recollect seeing a little boy; I saw Mr. Shoolbred's brother - I fixed on a piece of silk there I thought was mine, but found afterwards it was not; no little boy spoke to me about it - there was a young man who said it had been in the shop six months.

Q. Had you not ascertained that it had been there previously, and did not belong to you - would you not have sworn as positively to that as you do now to the silk in the indictment? A. No; because I found it was a different colour - mine was gold and blue, and that was yellow and blue.

COURT. Q. You saw a piece of silk at Shoolbred's which you first thought was yours? A. Yes; but I examined afterwards and found it was not; I speak to the two pieces found at Poulson's, because I only made one piece of the brown with the blue and white selvedge, and the other piece I can swear to by the selvedge.

JANE GULBRUNSON
. I was servant to Mr. Bloom at the time of the robbery - I went down stairs to answer the bell about four o'clock, and saw the wooden window of the warehouse was taken down; it had been safe when I saw it in the morning, about half-past six or seven o'clock - I had passed it after that, and had not observed it out; I had been by in the course of the morning, it was safe the last time I went by; when I found it down I informed Miss Bloom - the sash-lines were cut, and the window put down on the ground.

Cross-examined. Q. Your master was out? A. Yes; I do not know what time he came home - he was informed the shutter had been taken down and the rope of the window cut; there was no alarm made till he came home; I cannot say how many people had been to the house between half-past four and six o'clock - persons had been to the house; I was engaged up in the parlour, and Miss Bloom was up in the bed room: I was down in the kitchen from twelve o'clock to half-past four; I cannot see the wooden window from there - there is a middle door before you enter the place where the window is - my mistress was in the parlour and sometimes in the bed room from twelve to four; I had not seen any persons near the premises outside - the robbery was not committed before two o'clock, for I was down in the kitchen before two, and I know that Miss Bloom went into the warehouse about three.

SUSANNAH BLOOM
re-examined. I went down to the warehouse at four o'clock to a customer who came, and know it was all safethen - I left nobody in the warehouse, and did not return till the alarm; I knew the customer.

Cross-examined. Q. How many persons were in the house at four o'clock? A. Myself, the servant, and my mother; I was up in the bed room after four o'clock - my mother is not here; she was up stairs from four to half-past, and the servant was in the parlour - that does not command a view of the warehouse.

BENJAMIN POULSON
. I am a tailor, and live in the Quadrant, Regent-street. I bought both these pieces of silk, which are claimed by the prosecutor, of Mr. Shoolbred, in Tottenham-court-road - I bought the brown piece on the 23rd of June, I cannot exactly recollect when I bought the other - here is the invoice of it.

Cross-examined. Q. Is the brown a common or uncommon pattern? A. Very common; I have purchased many silks of the same make, but never bought any of exactly the same colour; the manufacture of the silk is very general, there is plenty of the same material made - I know by the invoice I bought it of Shoolbred, and can swear it is the piece I bought of him - I had no other of the same colour; I cannot say whether it was delivered in my presence or that I received it myself; I have no knowledge of any other silk being in the house, and will swear I had it from nobody but Shoolbred, though I might not be at home when it was brought - I call it slate colour, some call it grey - it is quite a common description of silk; I have no other reason for saying I bought it of Shoolbred than I have stated.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. You had no other piece of silk in your possession? A. Not of that description.
COURT. Q. Did you make any bargain with Shoolbred about it? A. I bought it at his house; I believe I made the bargain with his brother; it was sent to my house; here is the invoice.
MR. BARRY. Q. Is there any brown silk mentioned here? A. No; here is ten yards and a quarter of silk.

JAMES SHOOLBRED
. I am a mercer and draper, and live at No. 155, Tottenham-court-road. I had a piece of brown silk like this in my possession, and sold a piece like it to Poulson on the 23rd of June; I sold him several others; I sold him a piece like this other - one of the lengths I sold him was part of a piece I bought of Vanberg - I do not know this from any mark, but there was a brown piece of a very similar colour I bought of Vanberg - it is part of the length; I bought of Vanberg one hundred and fourteen yards and a half, and produce the invoice and the cheque I paid him; it was of various colours - I bought it as one hundred and fourteen yards and a quarter of balantine on the 12th of June; the colours of these two pieces are similar, but I have no mark on them, and cannot swear to them.

Cross-examined. Q. You have been some years in the business? A. Yes; the silk produced are the most common patterns that are made - I would not take on myself to swear to the silk of this pattern, unless I had a mark on it: I can generally tell who I purchase silks of, because I mark all the rollers - I do not mark the silk; these rolls of silk were mixed with my stock - I have only been in this particular branch of the business two years, and have had from four to five hundred pieces of silk of this description, in that time - there will generally be a little difference in the colour; I was not at home when Bloom came to my shop, but came in before he left - my shopman is not here; one piece of silk was given into my hand - there was a piece, which I knew to be mine; Bloom said nothing about that in my presence - I did not receive the silks from Vanberg; he brought me up the silks one day, and I offered him 4s. 6d. a yard; he would not take less than 4s. 9d., and took them away - next day, when I was out, he came with them; I did not receive them myself - some of my servants attended before the Magistrate.

ISRAEL MOSES VANBERG
. I live at No. 69, Leman-street, Goodman's-fields. I am a silk-mercer and linen-draper; I sold Shoolbred silk several times - I sold him some on the 12th of June; this is the invoice of it - among what I sold him, there was silk something like this, but I cannot say this is the article; I cannot say whether there was silk of the same colour and description - I had the silks which I sold him, from
Isaac Israel
, as his agent; I received them on the Tuesday previous to the 12th of June, which was Friday - I sold Shoolbred the silks I received from Israel; I delivered them at his shop, but cannot say this is the silk.
Cross-examined. Q. You sold silk of a similar description to him several times? A. Yes; it is impossible to say whether these are them - I did not put any mark on them.

ISAAC ISRAEL
. I am a shop-seller and tailor. I know the prisoner; he came to my shop the beginning of June, and had some silk to sell - it was on a Tuesday or Wednesday; I cannot say it was the beginning of June - he did not say what quantity he had, but I bought one hundred and fourteen yards of him, and delivered the same silks I bought of him to Vanberg, to sell for me - the prisoner brought it to my house in rolls and in a bag; I cannot say whether the silk produced is the same - I cannot tell whether there was any like this; they were waistcoat silks - this is waistcoat silk; I sent my nephew to Vanberg to make inquiries about the price of silks, but for nothing else then.

Cross-examined. Q. You sent him to ascertain the value? A. Yes, just to see what it was worth - that was after I made the purchase; it was a very common kind of silk from what I saw - I cannot say this is the same; Vanberg had it to sell on commission - I am sure of that; it was about the 7th or 8th of June - I cannot state the time particularly; I was examined before the Magistrate about a month ago, I suppose - it was in June I bought the silk; I think it was in June - I generally keep books, but sometimes do not use them, and did not on this occasion.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. How long had you the silk before it went to Vanberg? A. I cannot say; I dare say about nine or ten days - I sent my nephew to borrow 20l. of him to pay for them; he brought me a 10l. and two 5l. notes - that was the same day as I purchased the silk.

COURT. Q. The day you purchased the silk of Joel you sent your nephew to borrow the money of Vanberg? A. Yes, that was the time - I sent him to make inquiries, to ascertain the price - I bought the silk about two hours after I got the money, but did not send them to Vanberg the same day; it was about two or three days after - when the prisoner came with the silk, my little nephew called me up to him.

Q. Look at those two pieces - you are not asked whether they are the same, but are they at all similar or like what you bought of the prisoner? A. I cannot swear whether they are at all like; I saw the two pieces of silk before the Magistrate - I cannot tell whether these are the same they are similar to what were produced before the Magistrate.
Q. Were those produced before the Magistrate similar to what you bought of Joel? A. They were similar to them, but I cannot tell whether they are the same.

ISAAC ISRAEL
, JUN. I am the last witness' nephew. I cannot say that I know the prisoner; I have seen him pass many times - I saw him at my uncle's the beginning of June, when he came and told Mr. Israel he had some silks to show him, but what sort of silks I cannot say; I called Mr. Israel to him, what Joel said I cannot tell, because I never see business transacted; when I called Israel down - I went out of doors and never saw any business transacted; Mr. Israel sent me to Vanberg for 20l.; I got a 10l. and two 5l. notes, which I gave him - I cannot say what day that was; I believe it was the same day as Joel was there.

COURT. Q. Do you know whether it was the same day or not? A. I cannot swear it was; Joel was not in the shop when my uncle sent me for the money - I cannot say what it was for; I told Vanberg my uncle wanted to borrow 20l. - I did not tell him what for; I did not ask him the proper price to give for silks.

Q. Your uncle states he sent you there to inquire, recollect yourself, and say whether you can say it was on the same day? A. It was the same day, I am sure - I came back and gave my uncle the money in the shop; I did not see Joel then, and do not know what my uncle did with the money.

ISRAEL MOSES VANBERG
re-examined. I did not advance money to Israel - I lent him 20l. which the last witness came for; he sent me samples of the silk first, by the hands of his eldest nephew - I told him the value, and in two hours he sent his little boy for the 20l.; I received the silks a day or two afterwards - I took some samples about, and got the silk, I consider, on the 12th of June, the day I sold it to Shoolbred; that I think was two or three days after I lent the money.

RALPH ISRAEL
. I am nephew and shopman to Isaac Israel, and know the prisoner. I saw him at my uncle's shop the beginning of June - he had a bag with him; I did not see what was in it exactly - I saw some silk in it; I took some samples of silk to Vanberg, by my uncle's direction - I showed him the samples, made inquiries of him, and took his answer back to my uncle; Israel gave me the samples - I did not see where he got them from; I saw Joel come in - I remained in the shop till my uncle gave me the samples; he cut them off the silk which he bought of Joel; I cannot take on myself to swear whether these two pieces were there.

Q. Nobody asked you: I ask whether in the samples you took there was any of that description? A. Similar, but not the same; I cannot say it is the same, because it is out of my recollection - it is very near three months ago; I do not recollect whether it is the same.

Cross-examined. Your master deals in silk, I suppose? A. Yes; it was early in June, but I do not know the day; my master has dealt with the prisoner several times in silks - I cannot give the date to any particular transaction.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. Do you know how long before this transaction he had sold your master any silks? A. I cannot tell - I cannot mention any time.

COURT. Q. You have stated these two pieces are similar, but not the same; do I understand you to swear positively they are not the same, or that you cannot take on yourself to say they are not? A. I cannot take on myself to say they are not the same - I mean to say I can swear they are not the same.
Q. How can you take on yourself to say they are not the same? A. Because it is out of my recollection - they are similar but not the same; I mean to say positively they are not the same.
Q. Tell me the difference between these and those that came out of the bag? A. I cannot tell: I mean to say they are not the same - I do not know the difference.

JAMES BROWN
. I am a constable of Worship-street. On the 20th of August I went with Mr. Bloom to Poulson's, and took two pieces of silk from the window, which I produce; I apprehended the prisoner on the night of the 21st, in Petticoat-lane - I took him to a public-house, in company with the street-keeper, and asked him if he knew a person named Israel - he said No; I again asked if he did not know Israel, who lived within three or four doors of the Mint, on Tower-hill; he then said Yes - I asked if he had sold Israel any silk for waistcoat pieces; he said No; I think I only asked him that once - I took him to anotherpublic-house, and left him with Adams, while I fetched Israel - he was in a room with a dozen people, and the moment Israel went in, he said, "That is the man I had the silk of;" the prisoner made no answer - I took him to Worship-street.

JOHN ADAMS
. I am a headborough. I was present when the prisoner was apprehended - Brown's statement is correct.

MR. BLOOM. This brown silk is mine - I know it by the selvedge; I generally make white selvedges, but having a remnant of blue to get off, I put this blue to it - the silk was made by my direction; I could tell you how many threads there are in this selvedge, and how many in that; the other piece is also mine - there are eight claret-coloured threads outside the selvedge; I remember manufacturing silk of that sort - I lost three pieces of this description at the time of the robbery; two of them were sixty-eight yards long, and the other thirty-five and three quarters.

Cross-examined. Q. How many pieces of that description have you manufactured? A. I suppose one hundred of this pattern - the brown is a common pattern, but not a common colour; they are shots - it is brown and black, what we call a cane; I manufactured two of this description - one was a white selvedge, and the other of this colour; I sold the other two years ago - another manufacturer might put on exactly the same selvedge, but that is a hundred chances to one.
MR. BRODRICK. Q. Had the piece you sold the same selvedge as this? A. No, that was a white selvedge - this is blue and white.
MR. BARRY. Q. Is it not common to manufacture with a white selvedge? A. Yes; but not blue and white - I will not swear that no other manufacturer ever made with blue and white.

MR. BRODRICK. Q. Had you ever manufactured any other with that selvedge? A. No, not of this colour; I sold twenty-five yards of this piece to Mr. Maund, of Corn-hill, and have got this piece back to prove it - I asked him to lend it to me; I sold it to him on the 2nd of May, and know it to be the same piece - I went there, and brought it away myself to compare; they are both one piece - they tally exactly in the selvedge; I am positive they are from one piece, and will swear it.

COURT. Q. Of how many yards did the piece originally consist? A. Eight-four; I sold twenty-five to Maund, and six and three quarters to Kestevens, of Milk-street; about fifty yards were taken out of my warehouse - the piece found is about seven or eight yards.
Prisoner's Defence. I am totally innocent of the charge, and know no more about it than a child.
Eleven witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH - Aged 59.
Of Stealing above the value of 5l. in the Dwelling house, but not of breaking and entering.
Before Mr. Baron Vaughan.

1833.
ELIZABETH CARTER
&
ROBERT CARTER
(THE YOUNGER) were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June
, one 40l., one 30l., two 20l., nine 10l., and five 5l. Bank notes, the property of
Johanna Keefe
, in the dwelling-house of Robert Carter the elder; and
ROBERT CARTER
(THE ELDER) was indicted for
feloniously receiving one 30l., one 20l., and two 5l. Bank notes, part of the said property so feloniously stolen, he well knowing the same to have been stolen .

2nd COUNT, stating them to be the property of
John Richard Farre
.

3rd and 4th COUNTS, stating them to be the property of
William, by divine providence, Archhishop of Canterbury ,
Primate of all England and Metropolitan.
5th and 6th COUNTS, stating them to be the property of a person or persons unknown.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN RICHARD
FARRE, ESQ . M.D. I live at No. 4. Charterhouse-square. Mrs. Keefe was my aunt - I saw her alive last on the evening of the 1st of June; she resided at
Robert Carter
's house, No. 91, Drury-lane
- I received information of her death, and went there again on the 8th of July, having been at Brighton: I saw Mrs. Carter, and told her I was administrator to the estate - she replied that she knew it; I told her I had proof that the desk of Mrs. Keefe had been opened, and Bank notes to a considerable amount removed from it - she replied, she could not help it; she had done her duty - and when I pressed her again and again on the subject of the Bank notes, she denied all knowledge of them, not only once but repeatedly; I told her it was the last time I should have it in my power to show her that mercy which I wished, and desired that the whole of Mrs. Keefe's property should be sent to No. 11, Charter house-square, on the following day; and at the same time to send for payment of her bill for lodging, attendance, &c.; she made no answer, except to deny all knowledge of the notes - I left her, and went to the Police-office; she never told me that Mrs. Keefe had made her a present of the notes: I never saw her on any other occasion till she was in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. What was the lady's age? A. As near as I can judge, between seventy and eighty - it might be seventy-five; there was that kind of habit in her which I should expect from a lady who had married early in life, and lived much abroad - she lived in lodgings much below her station; I believe that resulted from penurious habits - she went to lodge there on the 2nd of April, and had lodged there previously, between 1822 and 1824; I called on her there several times - I cannot recollect how often: I do not recollect where she went to lodge after that - I saw her repeatedly; I was scarcely a week without seeing her - I saw her when she lodged in Carey-street, in 1829, repeatedly, and she used to come either to my house or to some of my relations, every week; I sent her to the West Indies twice, at my own expense; before she went to Carter's I understood she lived in Portugal-street, after she left Carter's the first time; I did not visit her there, being much occupied in my profession, and she usually called on me or my family - I saw her last on the 1st of June; I left town the next morning for Brighton, for my own health, and left her better than I had seen her from the commencement of her illness in February - I left her dropsical and ill, but expected she would recover; she kept her bed when I left - she was confined to her bed all the time she was at Carter's; her complaint required it - I did not direct any medical friend to call on her; Idid not think it necessary, and it was my opinion she would not submit to any advice but my own - I had great difficulty to get her to submit to mine; she was of a determined mind, and would have her own will in every thing - she dressed respectable: not like a pauper - I think I saw her repeatedly at Carter's, but not so much as at Carey-street; I considered her convalescent on the 26th of March - I may have seen her once or twice a week at Carter's, but not for the last fortnight, till the night before I went to Brighton, having been ill myself; she was the only person I visited - she was confined there with the consequence of her former disease, and did not require my attendance there oftener than I have stated; she was in bed - I had not an opportunity of seeing her dressed; I saw her dressed at Carey-street, before she took to her bed - she certainly dressed in a way I thought unworthy of her; very much in the style of a pauper - but when she visited she dressed respectable; I had enabled her to become wholly independent, having sent her twice to the West Indies, at my own expense, to obtain an independent income, which she had been deprived of for twenty-five years - she had 200l. a year transferred to her by the Court of Chancery, and claimed a great deal more; she lodged on the ground floor in Carey-street - if it had been kept as I could have wished, I considered it a decent lodging, but it was dirty; she was attended by a servant whom she employed, and I got a nurse for her at my own expense.

Q. When you told Mrs. Carter to send all the things to Charterhouse-square, did not she tell your Mrs. Keefe had left her every thing in the house? A. No, nothing like it - Mr. Franks, of Mill-hill was present, and Miss Springweiler; Mr. Franks is a Magistrate - she did not state this to me, nor in my hearing, but denied positively all knowledge of the notes; she did not say any thing had been left her by Mrs. Keefe - I claim on the property as sole administrator, to answer all claims as the whole of the estate; I have a sister who claims as well - we are her next relatives; I am a creditor of 150l.

Re-examined. Q. Were you and the deceased on good terms? A. Perfectly so - we never had any difference; I thought she would recover on the 1st of June, and only required good nursing and nourishment - I had a better opinion of her then, than at any time from the commencement of her illness, and did not provide a nurse on that occasion, because I was satisfied with Mrs. Carter's attention up to that time; she had enjoyed the 200l. a year from 1821.

MISS
ANN SPRINGWEILER
. I am single, and was intimately acquainted with Mrs. Keefe - I am no relation, but have been acquainted with her many years. I remember her going to live at Carter's on the 2nd of April; she was then in a bad state of health - I had visited her during her illness about twice a week till her death; I saw her last on Monday, the 1st of June - she died on the 8th; I know she was in possession of about 225l. in Bank notes - I had counted them for her on the 10th of April, and had them in my hand on the 15th; I did not see them on the 1st of June - they were deposited in her desk, of which she kept the key herself: it was put into a purse in a little drawer by her bed side - there was also a 200l. bill of exchange, four sovereigns and a half, and some ear-drops: I had seen those in April and May - I saw the bundle of notes about three weeks previous to my last visit; they appeared just the same in bulk as when I had opened them - the drops of her ear-rings were in the desk, and were gold; I saw them there in May - she was very particular about opening her desk; I frequently brought it to her, wishing her to open it herself if she wanted to go to it, but I used to open it when I was there: she used to direct me to take the key from the purse in this drawer, if she did not take it herself - when she wanted a note changed she employed me to do it, and was very particular about it; I changed a note for her last on the 10th of April, when I saw them altogether - about three weeks previous to my last visit or after that, she used to point to her desk and say to me, "There they are for you to pat your hand on in case any thing happens to me;" but generally added, "I am not going to die yet." On the 8th of June Mrs. Carter's son came to me at No. 1l, Charterhouse-square, and informed me of her death; I went almost immediately - Mrs. Carter told me she died about nine o'clock that morning very suddenly, and had been very angry in the night at her employing a nurse to attend her instead of herself - I asked why she employed a nurse without sending for me; she said she had been too ill to attend to her herself - I asked her for the key of the desk, saying I knew there were papers of consequence there; she said she had the key in her possession, went down, and brought it up - I opened the desk in her presence; I found it on the steps by the bed-side - I found all the papers in confusion; the bill of exchange was there, but neither the ear-drops nor any one of the Bank notes - I then said there was a parcel missing, which was of consequence to Dr. Farre; she replied if they were merely papers they could not be of much consequence, and stated that Mrs. Keefe had told her she had no money, but there was a bill of exchange coming due in October when she should be paid for her lodging - the bill in the desk is due in October; Mrs. Carter had told me, previous to this, that Mrs. Keefe was to pay her 13s. a week for lodging, and desired me, on one occasion, to apply to Mrs. Keefe to allow her 1s. a day more for her attendance - this was about the 10th of April; I made the application to Mrs. Keefe, who was very angry - she said 13s. was quite sufficient, and she would allow nothing more - on the 8th of June Mrs. Carter told me Mrs. Keefe had desired her to shut the doors against every body, and take charge of every thing; she did not say for what purpose - I left the desk there, taking home the 200l. bill and the West India letters; I went there, I believe, every day but two, till the funeral; notice was sent to Dr. Farre, who came to town that day week - I think I had no more conversation with her myself about the desk, but I went back on the day she died, with Mr.
Frederick Farre
- he stated to her, in my presence, that the property was missing; she said she knew nothing about it - he asked who had been in the room; she said she knew nothing at all about it - on the 18th I went in company with Mr. Franks, and opened the desk; I was showing him, in Mrs. Carter's presence, the manner in which the notes used to lay there, and where the drops were in a small box in the desk - Mrs. Carter said she had picked the drops up in the fire-place, and sent her child down for them; the childreturned, and she gave them to me - we never examined any thing out of Mrs. Carter's presence; she heard what I said about where the notes used to lay; but gave no account of them, or what had become of them - I myself only asked her if she had met with any papers or parcels; but the notes were mentioned in her presence more than once - she said she knew nothing of them; Mr. Franks asked me for the key of the desk on the 26th of June, and took out both these papers (looking at them) in Mrs. Carter's presence - the desk was then locked, and I had the key.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was Mrs. Keefe a woman rather grateful, as to acts of kindness done to her? A.
