I never thought her so - she made no will; I have no recollection of her saying any thing to me, but"There the notes are for you to put your hand on;" she did not tell me to give them to Dr. Farre, but I concluded that was her meaning - I saw her last on the day Dr. Farre did; she certainly appeared to require nursing very much, but appeared better, and I was prevented from going to see her - I am not aware that Mrs. Carter sat up one night with her - Mrs. Keefe had a stick to knock with to call her in the day time; I am not aware of her doing that in the night; Mrs. Carter did not appear to me to be particularly fatigued on the day of her death - she did not appear pregnant; I visited Mrs. Keefe almost daily in Carey-street - she was a very odd woman; her apartment at one time was in a filthy state: her dress was more like a pauper than a lady; she was a self-willed obstinate woman -I do not know why she returned to lodge at Carter's; I was surprised to hear of her going back, because I understood she had left there in anger - she had lived there before for two years; if she had wanted the desk in my absence, she could not lift it herself, but must have some one to bring it to her; Mrs. Carter's words were that Mrs. Keefe had told her to shut the door against every body, and take charge of every thing; she did not say she had given her every thing.
COURT. Q. Did she on any occasion insist that the notes, or any other property, had been given to her? A. No; she only said she was to take charge of every thing.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you never hear Mrs. Keefe say she intended to make Carter a compliment? A. Once, when I applied about the shilling a day, she said, in an angry manner, "I will make her a compliment;" I did not take out all the papers when I first examined the desk - I turned them over in the desk, and opened every West Indis letter; there were a great many papers; it was not full- I did not put any papers on the steps, or on the bed, nor put them on one side; there was no room to do so - there were a great many loose papers - I examined them, and am certain there were no Bank notes among them; I might be ten minutes rummaging the desk.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Do you live in the house of Dr. Farre's father, as one of the family? A. Yes - I frequently went to see Mrs. Keefe, when Dr. Farre did not; Mrs. Carter knew I was a member of the family, no doubt - if the desk was brought to Mrs. Keefe, she could open it with the key, and put the key away in its proper place; Mrs. Carter said she was assisting her out of bed, that her head dropped on her shoulder, and she died immediately - when Mrs. Keefe said she would make her a compliment she did not fix any time for it, in words or otherwise.

FREDERICK JOHN FARRE
, ESQ. I live with my father, Dr. Farre. On the 8th of June I went with Miss Springweiler to Mrs. Carter's house - I said I had no hesitation in telling her that notes to a considerable amount were missing from the desk, and I was sure, for her own sake, she would be anxious to afford some explanation of it, as it appeared to me very mysterious; she said she knew nothing about them, and could not be answerable for them - I saw her again on the 10th and 26th - I believe she was asked by Miss Springweiler whether she could afford any further information about the paper - she could not; the desk was opened on both occasions before me - Mrs. Carter was the only person in the room; I saw
Robert Carter
, Jun, write at Charterhouse-square - I stood over him, and observed his writing; I am fully persuaded that the two papers found in the desk are in his hand-writing.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Did you visit Mrs. Keefe at any time? A. Yes; I visited her on the Sunday week previous to her death, not afterwards - I am studying medicine; Mr. Franks was with me on the 24th and 26th, and on two other occasions; I have not been in Court during the examination of the other witnesses.

RICHARD FRANKS
, ESQ. I live at Mill-hill, and am a Magistrate of Middlesex. I went to Carter's with Mr. Farre and Miss Springweiler, on the 18th of June, and saw Mrs. Carter - Miss Springweiler desired her to come up stairs; she came up - I asked her where she took the key of the desk from: she said, "Out of the drawer, by the bed-side, and it was in a purse;" I asked what made her take the key; she said she thought she had a right to take it; I told her she did very wrong; she had made herself liable by so doing - I did not say to what she was liable; she was agitated, and shook very much - I said all she ought to have done was to close the eyes of the deceased, tied a handkerchief round her mouth, locked the door, and sent for her relations - she made no answer: I asked to see her daughter Catherine, who is about twelve years old, and asked her, in her mother's presence, whether Mrs. Keefe had laid quiet in the night she died, and if she was out of the room the whole night - she said she laid very quiet, as usual - I asked if she had asked for the desk; the daughter said she had asked for it on the Friday before the Sunday, and she had handed it to her on the bed - I asked what Mrs. Keefe took out of it; she said a sovereign, and gave it her to get change; I asked if she had left any papers or things on the bed, after she had locked the desk - she said she had not left any thing, and Mrs. Keefe told her to put the desk where it was, and the key and purse in the drawer where she usually kept it - I then requested Miss Springweiler to open the desk, and look into every part of it very particularly - it was searched, but no notes found; the notes were not mentioned - Miss Springweiler asked Mrs. Carter if the ear-drops had been in the desk; she said she would go and fetch them - I said, "Don't move out of the room, you may send for them;" and she sent the child, who brought them up -Mrs. Carter said she found them under the grate: I wished to see the nurse, who had attended Mrs. Keefe that night - they sent for
Catherine Williams
, who came; I asked her if Mrs. Keefe had moved in the night, or asked to see any body, or expressed a desire to do any thing; she said she did not, that she passed a very quiet night; the childand she were in the room all night, that she left at half-past six o'clock in the morning; I asked why she left so early; she said she was not well, and went home - no part of this statement was contradicted, either by Mrs. Carter or the child: she said she was lying as usual, quite quiet; when she went away, I asked the child what time she left the room; she said soon after the nurse, to go down to breakfast: the trunks were all opened in the presence of Mrs. Carter and the child, but no notes found - I do not know that Mrs. Carter was told what we were searching for - I went to the house, I think, five times with Miss Springweiler and Mr. Farre, Jun.; we left the trunks and things in the sitting-room, and one of the trunks open: the last time I was there, which was ten days after the death, Dr. Farre told her, in my presence, that a number of notes, amounting to 225l., were stolen out of the desk, and it was the last time the parties would have an opportunity of extricating themselves; Mrs. Carter said she knew nothing of the notes - she had done her duty, and could not help it.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. The last was the only time the notes were specifically mentioned? A. That was the only time - I did not announce myself as a Magistrate; I acted as a friend of Dr. Farre, he being a professional man, and not able to attend - I was not acting as a Magistrate; I told her she had made herself liable - she was frightened before that; she could hardly hold herself still; she did not appear ill - I did not desire that she should be taken to Bow-street.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you go there as a Magistrate, or merely as a friend of Dr. Farre? A. As a friend; the little girl said she had slept with Mrs. Keefe that night.
The papers proved to be in the hand-writing of Carter, which were put in and read as follows -"Mrs. Keefe died 11th."Mr. Dr. Farre, 11, Charter-house-square."

SUSAN BROWN
. I knew Mrs. Keefe. I used to go to make her bed every night before she lived at Carter's; I took her luggage to Carter's - Mrs. Carter paid every attention to her, and Mrs. Keefe was certainly attached to her for her kindness; in the course of the week I asked Mrs. Keefe if Miss Springweiler should be sent for - she said she could do her no good if she were there; Mrs. Carter said Mrs. Keefe did not want to see her - I said, as there was such an alteration, the family ought to know it; Mrs. Carter sent me away, and said I was not wanted any more - I know Mrs. Keefe used to knock with a stick when she wanted Carter to help her into bed; I said on the Friday night that Mrs. Keefe was altered, and I said the same on Saturday night - I was to stop and sit up with her on the Saturday night, but I could not.

WILLIAM WOODBURY
. I am an officer of Queen-square. I took Mrs. Carter into custody in August; on our way to the office she said that the notes were given her by Mrs. Keefe - that Mrs. Keefe had called her little girl and given her a 200l. bill, but the child could not read, and she took it away from her again; I then asked, if any of the notes should be traced with the name of Carter on them, what she would say? - she said, "It will be all very well; they were given to me - indeed she gave me all;" I understood her to mean all that was in the desk, and I think she said, "I am sorry I let the desk go." I afterwards apprehended Carter, Sen.; he said his wife had given him the notes; that he had passed them, and he was not ashamed of it - that his name was on them; that he had passed them at a public-house in his neighbourhood, and one at an ironmonger's - that his wife had not acted right, for she should have brought him the key of the room, and then he would have kept the whole property, for he understood her it had been given to her.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. You went to Mrs. Carter's and took her? A. Yes, it was mentioned that I wished to take up the son, and the father went and brought him to the office, and attended the examinations from time to time till I took him, which was a fortnight or three weeks after, and then I found him at home at his business; he is a master builder, and has a large family.

MR.
WILLIAM WATERS
. I am one of the firm of Barnard, Hoares, and Co. bankers, Lombard-street. (Looking at three bills of exchange), these were paid at our house at different times to a person named Keefe, by the receipt on the back of them - I have no recollection whether it was man or woman; two of the bills for 120l. and 180l. were paid together - here is a list of the notes I paid for them(handing it in).

WILLIAM BEATON
. I am a clerk in the Bank of England, and produce thirty-two notes which have been paid in there, and are cancelled.

McCULLOCK ROSS
. I am a clerk at the Duke of Bedford's office in Montague-street. The prisoner, Carter, Sen., holds a lease under the Duke, and paid me this 20l. note (looking at it) for rent - I cannot say which of them paid it, but think it was the father; I believe so, for I do not think it was the son; I have written "Carter" on it -I recollect that it was a man.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. You have no perfect recollection so as to swear positively which gave it you? A. No; seing the name on it induces me to suppose it was Carter; besides which I recollect asking him about a man named Wilson, with whom he had a trial; I should not have put the name on it if I had not received it from him - the note is No. 15,311, dated the 9th of June, 1825.

WILLIAM BROWN
. I keep the Compasses in White Hart-yard. I received this 30l. note, No. 10,855, dated the 20th of June, 1825, from Carter, Sen. on the 16th of July, and put his name on it; here are two 5l. notes, Nos. 11,560 and 11,561, dated the 9th of June, 1825, which I received on the 16th and 20th of June, either from the father or son, I cannot tell which; my house is within two hundred yards of Carter's.

JOSEPH HART
. I am a wholesale ironmonger. I received this 5l. note, No. 11,564, from Carter, Jun. on the 18th of June - he lives fifty or sixty yards from me.

JOHN PARISH
. I am collector of rates. I received these two 10l. notes, Nos. 3122 and 3123, from Carter, Jun. - I think on the 20th of June.

JOHN TRIMBY
. I keep a public-house in Drury-lane. I received two 10l. notes, Nos. 3120 and 7616, and a 5l., No. 11,558, from one of the Mr. Carters, I cannot say which, for I am in the habit of giving them change almost every Saturday night, as they live next door; I cannot say when it was, as I have only put the name on them.

JACOB WATSON
. I keep a public-house in Drury-lane.Here is a note with my hand-writing on it; the name on it enables me to say I received it from Carter, but I cannot say which - I have no recollection of the transaction; what Carter it might be I do not know.

JOSEPH CARTER
. I live at No. 109, Drury-lane. I recollect a 10l. note being changed by one of the Carters, but which I cannot say.

MR. WATERS re-examined. The two bills of exchange were paid on the 11th of July, 1825; they were most likely presented to a clerk at the counter - the person who received them would write the receipts.
MISS SPRINGWEILER. I believe the words, "Received, J. Keefe," on the back of these bills to be Mrs. Keefe's writing.
The letter of administration granted to Dr. Farre were here read: the list of notes produced by Mr. Waters, corresponded with those given in evidence.

Robert Carter
's Defence. My wife has been in the habit, for twenty years, of keeping the cash; and when I wanted money to pay away, I always sent to her for it.

Robert Carter, Jun.'s Defence. When I was taken into custody. I was at work in Stacey-street; my father came and said I was wanted, and I went with him to Queen-square - I have been in the habit of receiving notes for my father, and giving them to my mother; and receiving them from her, when I wanted them to pay away.

Elizabeth Carter delivered in a long written defence, stating that she was on the most familiar terms with the deceased, who usually called her "Dear Carter, &c.;" and felt unhappy if any one but herself attended to her; and that, a few days previous to her death, she told her to send her daughter out of the room, and then gave the notes into her hand, telling her to keep them if she died, and telling her to take every thing in the place for herself, and had often promised to make her and family comfortable. That the papers in question, must have got into the desk when Miss Springweiler was rummaging it.

HARRIET DOBBINS
. I have lodged in Carter's house for sixteen months; I was called down the morning Mrs. Keefe died, to assist Mrs. Carter - it was when she was dying - I had seen her the Friday before her death, and at other times; I have heard her say Mrs. Carter behaved with the greatest kindness to her - on the Friday before she died, my sister and I were in the room helping her into bed; she was much troubled with dropsy - I asked if her doctor was aware of her being in that situation; she said, she believed so - that Mr. Farre was her doctor, and he was her nephew, but he was gone to Brighton, for the benefit of his health - she told me Mrs. Carter was to have all her property when she died, and that she had already made her a very handsome compliment - she was very infirm, and required great attention; Mrs. Carter paid her every attention - she slept in the room over Mrs. Carter, and had a stick to thump the boards to call her - I have heard Mrs. Carter say she went to a physician, in consequence of hurting herself by lifting her out of bed, as she was pregnant - I was taken to the Police-office on the part of the prosecution but not examined.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How often in the course of your being there did you see Mrs. Keefe? A. I should think four or five times - I was not at all intimate with her; every time I went into the room she talked about her property that she had given it to Mrs. Carter; I only saw her four times - the first time might have been five or six weeks before her death; she told me about the handsome compliment on the Friday - she said there was a time-piece on the mantel-shelf which had been given to her by an old sweetheart, and she had given that to Mrs. Carter; I heard nothing of Carter wanting 1s. more to attend her - I was not with her more than ten minutes when she died; she was sitting on the nightchair, but I assisted Mrs. Carter to put her into bed - that was at near ten o'clock in the morning; I never told the officer of this - I was at the office on the day Mrs. Carter went to prison.

CATHERINE WILLIAMS
. I sat up with Mrs. Keefe the night before she died - I heard Mrs. Brown ask Mrs. Keefe if Miss Springweiler had been to see her; she said she had nothing to do with her - she owed her nothing, and did not want her; a little before that Mrs. Carter was assisting her, and she said, "Carter, my dear Carter, my love! I want no one here but you, you are the first here" - Catherine Carter, the daughter, slept in the room before Mrs. Keefe died, and had done so for some time; on the Sunday night Mrs. Carter asked if she wanted Miss Springweiler - she said she did not want her there; she owed her nothing - "I want none here but you, Carter;" I remember her once sending for
Robert Carter
, Jun. - she gave him a glass of wine, and said,"My boy, I respect you, you are a nice youth - Will you have a commission in the army or navy? I will buy it you, and make a gentleman of you;" the boy thanked her, and said he did not want either - I remember, when Mrs. Keefe lodged in Carey-street, Mrs. Carter sent me to see her there three times; she desired me to give her kind respects to her, and begged she would move, as she was so poorly - she thought she had better not move back to her house; this was about a fortnight before she did move - Mrs. Keefe's answer was, that so Dr. Farre said, but that did not matter; that her rent where she was, was only 12s. a week, and Mrs. Carter's 13s. - I said I thought she paid 15s. there; she said she did not, but that did not matter - she would go back to Carter's, and if she was to die she would die there; I remember Carter burting herself by lifting her out of bed - she was often in the habit of doing so.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you very intimate with Mrs. Keefe? A. Yes - I washed for her three years ago; I have seen her several times as a friend - I used to go and work in her room; she was very stingy indeed - it surprised me to see her give young Carter wine.

JANE TAYLOR
. I am a widow, and live in Stanhope-street, Clare-market. Mrs. Keefe came from Carter's to lodge with me, in October, 1824 - she has spoken to me very handsomely of Mrs. Carter, and often wished to go back there again; I know Mrs. Carter was pregnant in May, or the beginning of June.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long did Mrs. Keefe lodge at your house? A. Six or seven months - she then moved over the way; I never visited her at Carter's - she never sent for me to go and see her at Carter's.

MR. FARTHING. I am a solicitor, and live in Great James's-street. I have a house at Wandsworth - I have known Carter, Sen. about twelve years, and have employed him as a builder for the last five; he was downat Wandsworth, building for me, the greater part of May, and seven or eight days in June - he was living at my house for the convenience of business, and slept there every night, except Sunday.
MR. MORLEY. My brother (who is a barrister) is Carter's landlord - he has been in the habit of paying me 180l. a year for rent for some time.
E. CARTER GUILTY (of stealing, but not in the dwelling-house.) Aged 41.

Strongly recommended to Mercy . -
Confined 2 Years .

R.CARTER, Sen. -
NOT GUILTY .

R.CARTER, Jun. -
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Recorder.

1834.
EDWARD HAYGREEN
and
WILLIAM DUTTON
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Hannah Rogers
, on the King's highway, on the 7th of September , putting her in fear, and taking from her person, and against her will, 1 frock, value 2s,; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 piece of ribbon, value 6d.; 1 pair of stocking, value 1s., and 1 lace collar, value 3s., her property .

HANNAH ROGERS
. I live at Bushey, with my father, and am single . On the 7th of September I had been to London with my father, and as we returned we went into the Crown, at Hendon
, between ten and half-past ten o'clock at night - it is about four miles from London; I staid there about an hour - I saw Haygreen there, but not Dutton - he asked me to sing, and I did attempt a song; I did sing, but it was out of fear, because I thought I was in bad company - I staid there because it rained hard; I left the public-house with my father, and had not got three hundred yards when Haygreen, and another man whom I do not know, interrupted me - Haygreen caught me round the waist, and said I should not go home; I had never seen him till he was at the public-house - when I saw they would not let me go, I instantly called to my father to fire his pistol, as I thought it would intimidate them - I knew he had not got one; while my father was in the act of taking a knife from his pocket, a bundle was taken from between my father's hands and mine - the bundle was under his arm, which I had hold of; when I asked my father to fire his pistol, he said he had one in his pocket that never missed fire, and while he was drawing a knife out the bundle was drawn away by one of the two; I could not see which took it - they ran away, and I have not seen it since; it was very dark, but there were three officers opposite, who called out "What are you at, can't you let the people pass quietly?" in ten minutes I saw the prisoners in custody; we were going back to the public-house, and met the officers with them - when I saw them in the public-house I was quite sure of Haygreen, but I cannot speak to Dutton.

Cross-examined by MR. BOLLAND. Q. What time in the morning had you left Bushey? A. At twelve o'clock- we stopped at the Crown on our way to town, about three o'clock, and called for a pint of porter, but had nothing else; we had some porter in London - it might be three pints; I did not drink a pint, I am certain - we had nothing more till we got to the Crown; there were a great many men there - we had a pint of porter, and Haygreen asked me to drink; I drank with no other man, to my knowledge - I am not certain whether I drank with any body else; I will not swear it - I might perhaps; I do not think I did - if I did, it was not with more than one; I began two songs, and did not get through the third - I do not exactly know what the songs were; the one I sang through was, "Yes coachmen all of London-town" - I will swear I only sang two, and part of a third; a woman asked me to sing - I said I did not make a practice of singing in public tap-rooms, and it was a long while before I attempted to sing; Haygreen put his arm round my neck - I did not put my arm round his waist, or round any man's waist; Haygreen attempted to kiss me, but I do not know whether he did - I begged of him to take no liberties: nobody else kissed me: I had a black veil on, and did not pull it up for him to kiss me -I did not go into the passage and beckon him out, nor any other young man; I knew Haygreen by his voice - I did not say it was a dark man who robbed me, but I could not tell who it was - I said it was Haygreen; I told the Magistrate he was the man, but I did not know his name - the patrol asked me if I could swear to him; I said Yes, if I had a light; it was a very dark night - all the company came out of the public-house together; we had a pint of porter outside the house before we went in, and sat under a tree with it - that was for a very few minutes; we went in for shelter - Scott, the ostler, brought us the beer; he did not advise us to go home, as it was late - I asked him for some water; he said had I not better have porter - I said I had had porter in town; I do not recollect his saying any thing about my going home.

THOMAS ROGERS
. I am the prosecutrix's father. I left home with her between eleven and twelve o'clock, and went to Windmill-street, Haymarket; we stopped and had a pint of porter at two houses - it was dark when we got to town; on our way back we stopped at the Crown, which is about four miles from town - Bushey is thirteen; my daughter had some water at the Black Lion in Kilburn, as she did not like the beer - I had two pints of beer in town; when we got to the Crown, the servant brought us a pint of beer, and the girl some water - we had it under the tree; it began to rain very fast, which induced us to go into the house - there might be six or eight persons in the tap-room; I cannot say how many - Haygreen was one; I do not know Duttol - we sat there an hour or more; one of them wished my daughter to drink - I thought as they were hard working people, there was no harm in it, and I did, out of fear, persuade her to drink; she drank with nobody but Haygreen - there were two women in the house; the servant had orders to shut the house up, and all the company went out together; Haygreen wanted to kiss my daughter - I told him to let her alone, that she was my daughter, and very tired; they would hardly believe she was my daughter - she sang merely to oblige the people, out of fear; she attempted two songs, but could not sing - I could tell by the beating of her body that she was in fear - she afterwards sung three verses; they said that would do - when we left the public-house, I had her bundle in my arm, and her arm was linked in mine; when we got about two hundred and sixty yards, we heard some people running after us - it was very dark; my daughter said"These men are coming after me" - I said, "Never mind, hold my arm;" Haygreen then caught hold of her, andsaid he would be d-d if she should go home with that old man; she said, "Father, why do you stand any nonsense? why don't you draw your pistol, and shoot them?"- I said I would, as soon as I could get it out, for I had one in my pocket that never missed - I had a knife in my hand, and was going to plunge it into Haygreen if my daughter had not been between him and me, and the patrol speaking, he certainly would have had it in him; I felt the bundle drawn from my arm very plainly - they ran away; the patrol pursued them directly; we stood a few minutes listening, and heard a noise - she said, "They have got them, father;" they were taken to the public-house and we went back; I saw Haygreen then - I am sure he is the man who offered to kiss my daughter; I cannot speak to the others - I am positive of Haygreen; we did not go back to the spot to look for the bundle; whether it was dropped near the spot I cannot tell.

Cross-examined. Q. At the time the party came up to you, was it not so dark you could not see any body? A. I could see there were two men, and I knew Haygreen's voice; he had talked very much at the public-house - I speak to him by his voice, his jacket, and his height; it was very dark, but I knew him again perfectly well, both by his dress, person, and every thing - he had a cap on; I did not notice whether the other people had caps; there might be eight, ten, or more in the house; there was a man called Austin there, and I hear he has absconded - I cannot say whether he had a cap on; my daughter had a little of the beer on the road, but I drank the best part of it - it might be ten o'clock or half-past when we got to the Crown; I do not think we sat under the tree above two or three minutes; I saw no one but Haygreen take liberties with her, farther than forcing themselves up against her; he kissed her, I cannot say how many times; I will say twice - that is as much as I know; he lifted the veil up to do it, she did not lift it up to my knowledge - she did not put her arm round his neck nor round any other man's; I believe no one took liberties with her but him - she went into the passage and beckoned to me to come home, not to him; whether any man went out to her I cannot say - I did not go home, as it rained hard; I did not like the company altogether, and I thought some might be going our way; I do not know who asked her to sing first - the man who has absconded sat next to her - I said, "They are all hard working people, I dare say - it will be no harm, sing if you like;" she sung, "Ye coachmen all," &c., for she said she did not recollect one - I said, "You do sing that at home;" I do not recollect telling her to sing another afterwards; the officers were very close to us when the men came up -I do not recollect the man, who brought us the beer under the tree, telling us we had better go home; they never separated my daughter's arm from me - it was drawn back by pulling - her arm was clenched in with mine.
Q. Might not the bundle be drawn out with their trying to get your daughter? A. It was drawn out by a hand; I will swear I saw it in the man's hand, and felt it taken.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON
. I am a Bow-street officer. I was on duty near the Crown a few minutes before half-past eleven o'clock; I was standing up against the pales, taking shelter, as it was very dark and stormy - I saw the two witnesses coming along the middle of the road; two men came after them - when they got up to them a kind of scuffle ensued; I heard a female say, "Father, take out your pistol and shoot them;" a male voice answered directly,"D-n your eyes, if you don't leave my daughter alone, I will shoot you;" I hallooed out, "What are you after there?" I might be twenty yards from them - the two men immediately ran away - I said to the party, "Don't be frightened, it is only the patrol;" the old man called out,"Then run patrol - they have robbed me of a bundle;" I immediately pursued the men - we lost sight of them entirely: it was very dark - we followed footsteps to the corner of Child's-hill-lane, about two hundred yards, and then lost the sound; I returned, and found the prisoners in custody, near the Crown - I said to the girl, "Are either of these the men?" she said Yes, Haygreen was the one who took hold of her round the waist - that she could swear it, and the father said he was the man; Haygreen said he was mistaken.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the men pass you in going after them? A. No, we were beyond them - I do not know a man named Austin; I had been into the Crown at a quarter past ten o'clock, to light a pipe, and saw the prosecutor and his daughter sitting there by themselves; there might be twenty persons there - it was full of people, labouring men and some women, girls of the town; I never knew Haygreen.

JAMES COVINGTON
. I am a patrol, and was with Thompson near the fourth mile-stone; I observed people coming from the Crown, and when they got within thirty yards of us, I heard a female voice say, "Father, why don't you draw your pistol and shoot them?" I heard a man say, "D-n you, if you don't let her alone, I will shoot you;" two men ran away - we called out, and the party called out, "Make haste, patrol - they have got my bundle;" we followed them as far as Child's-hill-lane; it was too dark for me to see them - Thompson and I went up the lane, and Blaney went up the road; in seven or eight minutes I saw the prisoners in Mr. Prior's chair - it is a garden chair, that stands about one hundred and fifty yards from the Crown - they were both sitting there; I told them we apprehended them on suspicion of a robbery that had been committed; I searched the chair and them, but found no property - they made no answer, nor any resistance; Blaney came up, and we took them to the Crown - the prosecutor and his daughter had come up in about ten minutes; both said they thought they could identify Haygreen if they had a light - we took them to the Crown - the daughter fainted as soon as she entered; we got a light, and went out to took for the property - I was not present when the daughter came too; I left the house entirely.

Cross-examined. Q. The night was very dark indeed? A. Yes; Prior's chair is a sort of alcove, which will hold six or eight people - it stands by the side of the path, and people may sit in it; there was a young woman sitting with them, and another standing about forty yards off - the chair is enclosed, except at the door-way.

JOHN BLANEY
. I am an officer. I was with the witnesses - I heard the prosecutor and his daughter coming along before this happened; they were about fifteen yards from me, when I heard the daughter say, "Father, take your pistol, and shoot them;" I then perceived two men run away - the father said, "Make haste, they have gotmy bundle;" I had not distinguished the features of either of them - I lost sight of them, and saw them in Covington's custody in about eight minutes; I saw the prosecutor and his daughter - they said the dark man. Haygreen, was the man who took hold of the daughter - they could not speak to the other.

Cross-examined. Q. Covington took them in the chair? A. He saw them in the chair about a minute before me; I made them come out - the witnesses said they could not speak to them till they had a light; when they saw them by the light at the Crown, they spoke to Haygreen - I had only seen two figures moving along: I could not tell it was the prosecutor and his daughter - I do not know of any man absconding from Wilsden.
COURT. Q. Did you afterwards go to the spot where this happened to look for the bundle? A. Yes; we searches there with a light that night, and could not find one.

JURY to
JOHN BLANEY
. Q. Was the place where the witnesses could not identify them, darker than where the robbery was committed? A. I should think, as near as could he, it was the same - I took Dutton, because I found him with the other.
Haygreen's Defence. I never followed the girl - I saw her in the public-house.

EDWARD WORDLEY
. I am landlord of the Crown. The prosecutor and his daughter came there about three o'clock in the day, and had two pints of porter - they returned rather before nine, I should think, and had a pint of porter under the tree - they then went into the tap-room; there were eighteen or twenty haymakers and labourers there - there was a lad named Austin who, I understand, has left the neighbourhood - he had a cap on; the prosecutor and his daughter went, and sat among the rest of the men, they did not appear alarmed - very far from it; the young girl sang several songs at her father's request - I believe she drank with most of the men; she was in two or three parts of the room, and I believe drank wherever she sat - they were there nearly two hours; I turned them all out together - I saw Haygreen lift up her veil, and kiss her two or three times; I saw nobody else kiss her - they returned to my house about three quarters of an hour after it was cleared - it was full that time; I have known Haygreen for three years - he was servant to Mr. Tilyard, and had the care of about one hundred cows; he was strictly honest, and rather above a man in his station.

COURT. Q. Was it not raining very hard while the prosecutor and his daughter were in your house? A. There were showers - it was not a continued rain, for I went out to see; it rained a little when they left: I did not know Austin, but understood he worked for Captain Lewis, opposite my house; the first time I saw him at my house was the night before - I know he has absconded, because the officers were sent after him; I heard the Magistrate order them to search for him - I believe it was neither of the officers that are here; he had a cap on on Sunday and Monday, and Haygreen had a cap - I had seen him and Haygreen sit down, and should judge they were nearly of the same height, and about the same stoutness.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT Seventh Day.
Second London Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1835.
PHILIP OVERTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 1 dressing-case, value 3l. 15s.; 1 pair of boot-books, value 3s. 6d.; 1 pair of nail-nippers, value 5s.; 1 pair of scissors, value 3s. 6d.; 1 shaving-glass, value 4s. 6d.; 1 shaving-brush, value 4s. 6d.; 2 glass boxes, with plated tops, value 4s.; 1 hair-brush, value 2s. 6d., and 1 clothes-brush, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Joshua Strickland Rigge
, and another, and to whom he was servant . Also for stealing, on the 16th of February , 12 dessert knives, value 2l. 2s.; 12 dessert forks, value 1l. 1s., and 30 pocket-knives, value 9l., the goods of the same persons. Also for stealing, on the 2nd of February, 6 dressing-cases, value 6l.; 16 razors, value 30s.; 5 combs, value 13s.; 1 bottle of otto of roses, value 3s.; 17 pairs of scissors, value 2l. 6s.; 16 brushes, value 16s.; 4 razor-strops, value 4s.; 1 workbox, value 12s.; 130 knives, value 12l.; 130 forks, value 6l.; 5 snuff-boxes, value 25s.; 100 fish-books, value 5s.; 1 segar-case, value 1s.; 1 razor-case, value 2s.; 1 glass bottle, value 1s.; 4 pairs of tweezers, value 2s.; 4 shaving-boxes, value 4s.; 2 nail-files, value 1s.; 2 corkscrews, value 2s., and 1 button-hook, value 1s., the goods of the same persons. And also for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 61 lbs. weight of ivory, value 7l. 10s., their property.

The prisoner
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1836.
JOHN LANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 4lbs. of cheese, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Sutch
.

THOMAS SUTCH
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in West-Street, Smithfield
. On the 10th of September, a little after nine o'clock, my wife told me this cheese was taken; I turned, and saw the prisoner going with it out of the shop; I called him back; he came back, put it down on the step, then came in, and said he had got nothing - he had got about five or six yards from the place he had taken it from when I saw him - he begged pardon, and said he would never do so again.
GUILTY . Aged 21.

Confined Fourteen Days , and
Whipped .

1837.
JOHN PESMAN
,
ANTHONY COLVIN
,
JOHN FORBES
,
HENRY SERJEANT
, and
CHARLES QUIXLEY
, were
indicted for a conspiracy .
MESSRS. BARRY and CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM REES
. I am a mariner. I was employed up to March last, on board the Royalist South Sea whalefisher - I was entitled to two tons of oil on board that vessel, instead of wages; the oil was sold at 70l. per ton- we arrived at Gravesend on the 21st of March last; Colvin and Pesman came on board, and brought some gin to entice as to sell our voyage, but I would not sell mine- Colvin did not then say any thing about any debt I owed him; we arrived in the London Docks on the 22nd- I took a lodging at
Philip Sullivan
's; on the 25th of March, Colvin and Forbes called on me; I was cominghome that morning - when they saw me, Colvin told Forbes I was the man, and he had nothing more to do with me, pointing with his finger to me; Forbes then took charge of me, and said, "Come home to breakfast, I want you to take a walk with me" - I went in and took my breakfast, and afterwards he told me to take a walk with him; I went with him and
Phillip Sullivan
- as we walked along he said I was his prisoner; I said, Why? - he said it was a debt I owed to Colvin; but I never owed him a farthing, except for porterage and waterage - I do not know what that might amount to; Sullivan was walking with me at the time, and must have heard what was said - he told me to walk on one side the street, that he might not disgrace me in the neighbourhood; he took me to the Mitre public-house, and Forbes called for a pint of gin and half a gallon of beer - I partook of it, I never object against a glass of grog; and Sullivan drank same - when I was half drunk, Forbes took me into the back parlour; Colvin, Pesman, Quixley, and Serjeant came in - we had drank the gin and beer in the other room; they said that I should go to gaol, if I would not pay Colvin nine weeks board that I owed him - Pesman said that for one: they said the amount of the bill was 7l. 13s. - I said I would not go to gaol for any one, to disgrace myself; Sullivan said he and another housekeeper would give bail for me if I owed any money - both Forbes and Colvin said they would not take bail at all; after they refused bail, they said I should go to gaol - I told them I would not go to gaol; Pesman told me I should if I would not sell the voyage, meaning my share of oil -I said I would not sign any bill of sale at all; I would not take a pen and ink in any bill of sale at all; I would not take a pen and ink in my hand - they had not mentioned a bill of sale, until I had agreed to sell the oil, and I offered my whole share of oil for 90l., clear of all debts, dues and demands - they would not agree, and I was compelled to do it or go to gaol; Pesman offered me 44l. 6s. 6d. I objected to it, but at last signed the bill of sale for it; it was a written paper, I believe - I did not read it; I can read - I only signed it; I believe Sullivan has it - this is a receipt given by Pesman, after the bill of sale was signed (read)

"I,
John Pesman
, have this day purchased of
William Williams
, of the ship Royalist, his share of oil at 70l. per ton, if he should be entitled to more than 70l. per ton, the balance I promise to pay. JOHN PESMAN.

I do not know what became of the bill of sale; I was drunk, and was compelled to sign it - all the prisoners were there at the time; I do not know who said any thing about the cheque - Pesman gave a cheque on the Bank; I did not see it to my recollection - my landlord told me of it; Sullivan went to the Bank with Forbes, and I was kept a prisoner all the time - (cheque read) "For 44l. 6s. 6d. on Sir William Curtis and Co., signed J. Pesman." Sullivan and Forbes went with it; I was Serjeant's prisoner at the time - Pesman and Quixley were there; when Forbes and Sullivan came back they reckoned the money on the table - a bill was then made out against me, of 7l. 13s., due to Colvin, and 1l. 5s. for the writ; I paid that and was set at liberty - I afterwards applied at Pesman's for the balance of my money; I cannot tell exactly when it might be - in the course of a week or two, I went to his house in Wapping; he began to kick up a row with me at his own door; he said he would not give any more money, as the oil had not been sold for any such price - Quixley drew this receipt and Colvin signed to it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What is your name? A.
William Rees
-
William Williams
' name is in the ship's book; that is a man who was lost, and the captain told me I should go by that man's name - I am half a Welchman and half an Irishman; here is William Williams on these ship's articles, but it is not my hand-writing - I do not see the name
William Rees
here; I never signed the name of
William Williams
to any document.

Q. Is the name of William Williams on this paper your hand-writing? A. No, Sir, it is not - I did not sign it in the presence of Sullivan; I signed the bill of sale in the name of
William Williams
- I declare to God I did not think of that; I dare say that is the paper I signed - this is
William Williams
; this is the signature I swore was not mine - I was before the Lord Mayor; I was not sober - I was sworn and examined, but did not well know what I was saying; I do not know how long I was being examined, perhaps half and hour - I did say, before the Lord Mayor, that I owed Colvin for waterage and porterage; I cannot say whether I said Pesman and Colvin had come on board the ship at Gravesend - I cannot say whether I did mention the porterate and waterage, but I know that is all I owed Colvin; I formerly, lived at Colvin's for five weeks, but did not promise him I would go to his house again after the voyage - I did not intend to go there; I gave him 1l. 7s. 6d. and I paid him 4l. 10s. at Gravesend.
COURT. Q. When did you pay the 1l. 7s. 6d.? A. About five years ago, when I was going to the Coast of Peru - I gave him the other money on board the ship between decks, down by the starboard side.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How often have you seen Mr. Isaacs? A. Several times; not at his own house, but some place in the country - I went down to a farm-house; I shall not swear in what part of the country - Mr. Isaacs. paid my expences down, and I was there three months; I cannot tell how often he visited me - I cannot tell whether he has been down twenty times talking about this business.
Q. What is the name of the place where the farmhouse is? A. I do not know the name of the town.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How far is it from town? A. That I cannot tell neither - I went in a coach; I suppose I was about four hours going - I did not know Isaacs before I went to the Mansion-house, but I believe he is the best friend I have got in London - we have not been conversing about what I was to swear at this trial; he merely came down to see how my health was getting on- we drank together, and he paid; the landlord's name was James Hall - he has a farm, and keeps a public-house; it was the public-house I was at - the sign of the George and Dragon; I do not remember the name of the coach I went by - Isaacs did not go with me; he told me to stop at Mr. Hall's, but I do not know the name of the town - the coachman took me to the house.
Q. You swear you do not know the name of the town? A. No, I do not swear it; it was in a village.
Q. Now do you mean to swear that you do not know the name of the village you were living in for threemonths, and that you never inquired? A. No, I shall not swear it.
COURT. Q. You are upon your oath, do not you know the name of the village where you wereliving - what County was it in? A. Essex, I believe; I cannot tell you the name of the town - I never inquired.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What was the name of the place? A. Brentwood; that is what I heard them say - I never saw any market there - there was a fair there once.
Q. Upon your oath, did you not know the name of the town all through the examination? A. I cannot swear to that.

Prisoner Colvin. Q. Did you say you gave me 4l. 10s. when you went out to Peru? A. Yes - I came out of the cabin, took two months in advance, and gave you 4l. 10s; you took the money, went on shore, and bought me a pair of trousers and 3lbs. of soap out of it.

Prisoner Colvin. He ran away from the ship, and I paid 3l. out of the money to a man for him; he was naked when I took him in, and he confessed before the Lord Mayor that he owed me 7l. 13s. Witness. I said I owed him something.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Why did you sign that paper by the name of Williams? A. I went to the office with Serjeant, from the Mitre, to overhaul the ship's articles - I could not find my own name in the articles, and I signed that in the room of my own name.

PHILIP SULLIVAN
. I lived at No. 2, Bremer's-court, Gravel-lane. Rees came to live with me on the 22nd of March - he continued there till the 25th, except when he went out occasionally, and eat and drank at my house. On the 25th Forbes and Colvin came - when I went down they were at the door; they asked if Rees was at home- I said No, he did not sleep there that night; I was talking to Colvin, whom I had known for some time, and Rees came down from Ratcliff-highway - Colvin pointed to Rees, and said, "Forbes, there is the man, I give charge of him - I have nothing more to do with him;" he then went away - Forbes asked him if he had had his breakfast; he said No, and he desired him, being his prisoner, to get his breakfast as soon he could - when he had done breakfast he ordered him out into the street; I accompanied him - I did not hear what passed between Forbes and Rees till we got to the Mitre; except that Forbes told him to walk with me and one or two more for fear of disgracing him, being known there; we got to the Mitre, where they called for liquor freely, and treated every body there - the others came in; the Mitre is about a mile from my house, near Aldgate-street - we went into the tap-room, where they called for the beer and gin; Rees drank, and so did Forbes - I was quite sober; nothing passed between Forbes and Rees till the others came - we were conveyed into the parlour by Pesman Quixley, and the others; when Pesman came, he said;" What is this business about?" Forbes said that Rees was taken prisoner; they asked Colvin if he had his bill- he said No, but he could make it out by word of month; I cannot say which of them it was that asked the question- Serjeant made out the bill; this is it - Pesman asked Rees if he would sell his voyage, his share of oil; he said No, he would not - I then offered myself, and another housekeeper, as bail till the ship was paid; Colvin refused, and swore he would have they money - I then told Rees to go to gaol, and said I would see him provided with every thing he wanted till the ship was paid; Rees said he thought it was a very hard case, after being at sea for thirty-two months and four days, to go to gaol for a debt he never contracted - Pesman then said he had better come to a settlement with Colvin, and he would give him 44l. 6s. 6d. for his share of oil; he asked what share of oil he had - he said, two tons and three barrels - Pesman told him not to mind the three barrels, as they would be little enough to make up the three tons, for there had been an alteration in the measure since he left London; he agreed to give 70l. a ton for his share of oil, and if it came to more he should have the balance - Rees said he would not accept of it; he said he would give him 44l. 6s. 6d. if the oil sold for 70l. a ton, and if it sold for more he would pay him the balance -Rees was unwilling to sell till he got a little in his heard, which was apparent to the five persons present, or to any person who saw him; when he got a little more, he agreed to sell it for 44l. 6s. 6d. sooner than to go to gaol -Quixley wrote this paper - he said it was better to come to a conclusion, and to walk about like the rest of his shipmates, than to be confined; Pesman then made out a cheque for 44l. 6s. 6d. - I did not look at it particularly; I only just folded it up; Forbes and myself then went to the banker's, and received the money leaving the prosecutor in custody - I had the check; I returned, and found Rees in custody of Colvin - I counted the money to Rees on the table; Rees signed a paper before I went- they did not explain it, but folded it up in a narrow compass, and Rees signed his name at the bottom; it was a large paper, and folded - there was no writing on it that Rees could see; I looked at it while he was writing -Pesman then produced a blank receipt; I do not know whether there was any stamp to it - he asked Rees to sign his name to it; I said he should not sign it till I knew the contents - he said he wanted it to draw the amount of the wages from the owners, and it was of no consequence; he then made Rees sign his name to it - he signed his name William Williams; he was able to walk home, and that was all - Quixley said the receipt was of no cousequence; he might sign his name to it, it was no harm - this was before I went to the Bank for the money; when I brought the money Rees counted out 7l. 13s., the amount he was arrested for, as he thought - Forbes would not accept of it till 1l. 5s. was paid for the writ; it was Serjeant who put down 1l. 5s. for expences - Rees then gave them nine sovereigns, and they gave him 1s. out; Quixley wrote a receipt, and Colvin signed his name to it - this is the receipt, it is for 7l. 13s.; they did not give any receipt for the 1l. 5s. - no person asked for it; he was then at liberty; in the course of a little time I went with Rees to Pesman's, and asked if there was any balance coming to him - he told him not to come bothering him about it, for after all the money he had given him, he never came to lay out 1l. at his shop - he desired him to walk out of his shop; he keeps a slop-shop, in High-street, Wapping - none of the other parties were then present; there were some sailors there - to the best of my judgment, when Rees signed this paper he was not in a condition to know what he was about, he was in such a terror and in such a fright - he was in liquor, and his mind in trouble besides.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you sober? A. I expect so - I had drank both heer and gin after going to the Mitre; Rees, Forbes, Colvin, Serjeant,
Tom Donovan
and I, drank - I saw Rees sign the receipt in the name of Williams; I saw him take the pen, but I was not near enough to see the way he wrote it - he wrote William Williams; I did not see it read.
COURT. Q. Why do you say he wrote William Williams? A. Because he was expected to do so.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many papers did he sign? A. I have not heard what he has sworn here, but he signed two papers - we passed by Pesman's shop in going to the Mitre; I did not state so before the Lord Mayor - I do not know a man by the name of Levy; I may know his face.

Q. Do you know that man? (a person was here pointed out to the witness) A. No, I never saw him, to my knowledge before; I do not know a man of the name of Moss - I have seen that man (another person) frequently before; I never asked him to buy the oil on behalf of Rees nor to advance any money upon the oil - I never saw Moss in company with Rees before the day we were at the Mitre; he was in and out - he was not there the whole time; he had nothing to do with the business -Rees did not, in my presence, ask Moss to get Levy to advance money on this oil; nor leave the Mitre, in my presence, with Moss, to go to Levy, to see if he would advance money on his share - he went to overhaul the ship's articles, to see about his name; that was the intention with which he left the house - they made an advance as his name has been scratched out by the captain, as there was a man left at St. Helen, and the captain said he should go by that man's name; Moss did not tell me that he was Mr. Levy's clerk - this bill was drawn out for Colvin; I did not say that Quixley wrote it; all I said was that Quickly wrote the two receipts - not that Quixley wrote the bill by Colvin's desire; to the best of my knowledge I never expressed that word - Rees boarded and lodged with me for thirteen weeks, and then I got tired of him; Mr. Isaacs took him and sent him into the country, for fear he should be tampered with by this party - he did not tell me what part of the country; I have no idea where it was - I have seen Mr. Isaacs; he told me to tell the truth, and that I always will do - Rees appeared to me to he sober at the Mansion-house: he might be in terror - to the best of my opinion he had only one glass of liquor, but I had not been with him all the morning - the sale of the oil was on the 25th of March, and I think in April we went to the Mansion-house; he went to recover his own rights - I did not hear him tell the Lord Mayor that he had not a stick to cover him, tell the Lord Mayor that he had not a stick to cover him, nor a farthing in the world; the money was not spent when he went - I can swear I had more than two sovereigns of his money to take care of; he would not want for a meal if I had it, if he was never to pay me for it - Mr. Isaacs brought an action against the owner of the ship for this very oil by Rees's direction; I know they brought the action for the whole of the oil - the Sheriff's officer arrested him for the whole amount; I did not go for Quixley and Pesman from the Mitre - I do not know that any one did; I did not know them, and cannot tell whether they frequent the Mitre or not; Quixley did say, that if in case Rees was entitled to more than 70l. a ton, and left the receipt with me, I could get it, but he did not say from whom - I cannot say whether Moss was present or not; Colvin was bailed - I do not know whether the others were required to give bail.

Prisoner Colvin. The day after the ship came into the London-docks, I went down to this man, and he said, if we can get him to sell his wages, we will, for he has been arrested for a suit of clothes, and I do not know how I shall get my money - Sullivan took him out of my house to his house, and I went there. Witness. I never did; I saw Colvin the day Rees came on shore - he was quite drunk, and when he saw me he began shedding tears for joy, at seeing me.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. At the time you saw Colvin with Rees, did Colvin say any thing about any debt? A. No, he went and got a pot of beer - we drank it, and then Rees went home to my house.
Prisoner Colvin. Q. Did I not mention it to you the day after, and you said, I should get my money? A. No.

COURT. Q. Upon the oath you have taken, did you know Colvin claimed any debt before the morning Rees was taken? A. Upon my oath I did not - Rees did tell me, that morning, that he owed him a trifle, but he did not say what.

MOSES NATHAN
. I am a Jew, and so is Pesman, but I believe Quixley is not. I live in Ratcliff-highway -Pesman is in the clothes business, and a slop-seller ; he finds clothes for seamen, and fits them out - the name of Pesman and Quixley is on the door; I live next door but one - I have seen Forbes in the neighbourhood, but I do not know whether he is in the employ of Pesman and Quixley; Harris takes care of the shop when Pesman and Quixley are not there - I have seen Forbes there when Harris, Pesman, and Quixley, have not been there; I cannot say that I have seen him managing the business - Forbes is a tailor ; Serjeant is a shoemaker ; he taken in lodgers, and lives in Pell-street, forty or fifty yards from me - it is at the back part of Pesman's shop; Serjeant does go on board ships to get seaman - Colvin is a waterman ; I cannot say where he lives - he goes on board ships to get sailors, and takes them on shore.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Has Serjeant's residence any thing to do with Pesman's shop? A. No; many of the others about there get their living by getting sailors to lodge - there is nothing particular in getting sailors; I have known Serjeant ten or twelve years - he has been in and out of my house, and I have had goods of him; Serjeant has been a sailor.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. You have told my friend you have seen the names Pesman and Quixley on the door? A. I have - the house is let out to different lodgers; there is another person lives up stairs - Pesman and Quixley's names are written, up separately, one on one side and and one on the other.

COURT. Q. Was Forbes behind the counter or no? A. I did not particular notice - I never heard any thing to the contrary, but that Colvin was an honest man; there are two windows to the shop, one on each side the door -I cannot tell whether they are in partnership; Harris is constantly there - there is but one door, and there is no other name but Pesman and Quixley: neither of them live there.

CHARLES ISAACS
. I am an attorney, and live in Mansell-street, Goodman's-fields. I have kept Rees in the country this three months.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has not Rees instructed you to bring an action against the owner of the Royalist for the entire amount of his share of the oil? A. Yes; I have arrested him for the whole sum - I cannot tell how much money I have paid for Rees; they have not sent me in the bill from the public-house - I never drank with him there; I never conversed with him on the evidence he was to give here - my clerk took down his evidence; I never did - I have been down to Brentwood on business, but never saw him; I saw him four or five times in the three months - my clerk paid his coach-here; I told my clerk to send him down to Mr. Halls, at Brentwood - I may have paid 15l. or 16l.; I will not swear I have not paid 30l. - I will swear I have not paid 50l.: I have his cause in hand, and I expect to get it - that will re-pay me; it was by my advice that he brought the action against Mr. Smith.

HENRY JACOBS
. I am a clerk to Mr. Isaacs. I went in March to the King's Bench to the Filazer's office, and to every public office where I thought a process could be issued by Colvin against Rees - I found no bill nor any serviceable process.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Were you present at the Mansion-house? A. Yes; Rees was like other sailors - he had been out passing the morning, but he appeared to give his evidence as a sober man; I took him from the Grand Jury room, as he was walking in the street, to the Spread Eagle, Gracechurch-street, and took him by the Norwich coach to Brentwood; I staid with him from the Friday till the Sunday - I did not tell him the name of the place; I cannot tell whether he knew it - I went to him there three times; I have drank in the same room he was sitting in - I paid for myself; the liquor he drank, the people who were there paid, he being a sailor; I did not write to him while he was there; I have conversed with him about his evidence here several times.
COURT. Q. You have heard his evidence this morning - does he appear more competent to give his evidence now than he did at the Mansion-house? A. Yes; more so.

Prisoner Colvin. I said I had no money, and he turned round, and said, "If you will turn evidence against the master, it will be something in your way. Witness. No, I did not - I was sent for; I saw him in a very destitute state: he said, "What am I to do?" I said,
"If you have any thing to state, put it on paper, and I will attend to it,"
Mr. ADOLPHUS addressed the Jury on behalf of Forbes, and Mr. BODKIN on behalf of Pesman and Quixley.

PHILIP SULLIVAN
re-examined. Q. Which room were they in when you went for the money? A. In the back parlour - there was no other person there that I took notice of; we had the drink in the tap-room - they had no drink in the parlour, unless it was while I was gone for the money- the agreement was made in the parlour.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. When Pesman and Quixley first came, where were you? A. In the taproom - we were there a quarter of an hour, while they were going backwards and forwards to overhaul his name; he had stated that he was entitled to two tons and three barrels of oil, before they went into the parlour.
Colvin's Defence. I am innocent. I kept the man when he was in distress; this man never kept him, only when he found he had a little money - I only received 4l. 10s. of him, and he had no clothes.

JOHN MOSS
. I am clerk to Messrs. Levy and Co. of Leadenhall-street - the Royalist was paid off there by Mr. Smith. the owner, about the 19th or 20th of April - it generally happens that the men have advances made - about three weeks generally elapse before the company are paid - the parties who have made advances attend when the ship's company are paid; I have known parties receive the whole of the sailors money; I was not in the counting-house at the time the Royalist was paid, but I was in the warehouse adjoining - I did not see Rees. I was at the Mitre on the day in question; I went about ten o'clock in the morning for change; while I was getting change, Colvin came out of the tap-room, and said there was a sailor of the Royalist there who wanted an advance, and asked me if Mr.Levy would make the advance - I said No, he would not; I said immediately, "Why don't you go to Pesman's or Quixley's, as they are in the habit of advancing money to the people;" he said No, he would rather Mr. Levy would do it, but he might go over, and see - I then left; I went there again about eleven o'clock, with a friend; while in the parlour, Pesman and Quixley came in - Pesman asked me if there was any sailor of the Royalist there; I said there had been some there about ten o'clock - Pesman then went out, and Quixley remained -Pesman returned in two or three minutes with Colvin, Rees, and one or two others. in sailor's dresses - Quixley turned round, and said to Rees, "Well, my man, what countryman are you?" he said, a Welchman - Quixley said, "I think you are an Irishman; before I can make you any advance, you must go over to Mr. Levy's, to see whether you belong to the ship;" Quixley, Rees, and his lodging-house keeper then left, and returned in about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour; Quixley then said the man belonged to the ship - he had pointed out his name - they sat down at an opposite table; I and my friend got up to leave the place; Quixley asked me if I would be kind enough to witness the payment of the money - I staid a few minutes; the man was complaining that he wanted a greater advance - Quixley said, "I shall not think of advancing you more till such time as your ship is paid, as dont know how it will turn out; the price of oil has fluctuated very much;" Quixley said,

"You are not compelled to take it, and I shall advise you to wait till the ship is paid;" but he said he must have money, as he wanted to go to Liverpool; he said, "Let's have it;" Quixley then wrote the receipt, Pesman this cheque, and Rees signed the receipt - this is it: after that, Pesman, Quixley, and my friend left the house - there was a memorandum given, just as I came away, that if the oil sold for 75l. a ton, he should receive the benefit of it; the whole cargo has been sold at 70l. a ton - the expenses of the voyage are to be deducted from that; I was present during the whole of the transaction, till Pesman and I left - I think Pesman made an advance; I saw no other paper signed by Rees but the receipt - I am positive of that - if Rees had attended at my house at the time the ship was paid, he would have received his money.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you attend before the LordMayor? A. Yes; I was asked if I knew any thing about it, and I said what I have stated - I did not say I knew nothing about it; I have known Pesman and Quixley these three years - they are partners in some transactions, not as slop-sellers that I know of; Forbes is not in their employ to my knowledge - Pesman and Quixley have not applied to my employers for this to my knowledge; the prosecutor is entitled to the one hundred and fortieth share of the net proceeds of the one hundred and fortieth share of the net proceeds of the cargo, but I do not know what they are; I was not at any time in the tap-room; I do not know what passed there: I did not see a hill of sale signed, I think if it had been I should have seen it; I did not see a folded paper given to him to sign; he appeared sober; I do not know that he was in custody; Forbes was there when Pesman and Quixley were - I heard nothing about custody; if it had passed I think I should have heard it; Colvin was there - I heard nothing about 7l. 13s. - I do not know where Pesman and Quixley went to, they parted in Aldgate; Sullivan was there - I did not hear one word about any claim made upon Rees by Colvin - Sergeant was there, I have seen him repeatedly - I did not know what he was; I do not know what a crimp means; I do not know that Colvin is a depuly crimp, he is a waterman; I have been agent to Mr. Smith about twelve years - I do not know what a crimp means, unless it be to follow seamen to take orders from them for clothes; Pesman and Quixley are in partnership as crimps certainly - I do not know that Colvin is a deputy crimp in their service - I do not know that Forbes is a crimp in their service; I have been at their place five hundred times; I have not seen him there twenty times; they have three shops, I never saw Forbes behind Quixley's counter; Mr. Levy supplies Pesman and Quixley with slops - I get no commission when they receive money.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Have you heard the word crimps applied to persons who get recruits for the army? A. Yes; when a bill of sale is given for a man's interest in a cargo, it is usual for a copy of it to be sent in and lodged with the agent - no such copy was sent to Mr. Levy in this instance.

JOHN BATTERSBY
. I am an agent to Mr. Lidiker; he is in the South Sea trade; ships in that line are usually paid three or four weeks after their arrival in the river - the men often have advances; a copy of bills of sale are sent to thein, or the agent would pay the sailor - I have known Pesman twelve years; he has made advances to the crews of our ships - I know Quixley by sight; when I have seen him the men have accompanied him to the office, and they have made a settlement.

JOHN CLARK SPRUE
. I am a ship's husband. I have known Pesman ten or a dozen years; it is the practice of the trade, when a bill of sale is made, to lodge it with the agent - without that the agent takes the money.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. If the sailor does not accompany him, the person does not get paid? A. No.
COURT. Q. Suppose a person produced a receipt on account of so much of a share of oil, would you not pay that? A. Yes certainly; if the sailor desires they frequently leave a note.
Mr. Francis Hobler produced a minute of the depositions taken at the Mansion-house, which corresponded with the evidence which had been given.

MR. LEVY. All I know of this transaction is, that on the 18th of April, on my return from the City, I found a notice from
Charles Isaacs
not to pay Pesman, and threatening me with an action - that is the only notice I have received.

COURT. Q. Then the share is wholly unpaid? A. Mr. Smith paid something in the Court; the whole proceeds of the cargo was 14040l., his share is 100l. 5s. 8l. - the set off is 31l. 12s. 9d.; the amount due to him 68l. 12s. 11d. - Mr. Jacobs afterwards called on me on the part of Mr. Isaacs, and asked if I would pay this balance to the man; I said I was not certain we should have the payment of the ship, but I would recommend the owners to withhold payment of the balance, till this matter was settled - on the 19th of April, Pesman called to know when the ship would be paid; I said what is this occurrence? I have received a notice so and so; he stated that the parties intended to defrand him of a large sum of money, which he had advanced - that was the only reply he made; sometime after they lodged an attachment in the hands of the owner, for the amount of this man's share, which I bailed - then they withdrew that, and commenced an action for his share.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is the action against you settled? A. No, I believe not.
Mr. Clarkson addressed the Jury.

COLVIN -
GUILTY . Aged 49.

PESMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 45.

FORBES -
GUILTY . Aged 43.

QUIXLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined Two Years .

SERJEANT -
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Six Months .
Second Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1838.
JULIA DIAS
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
James Joshua Stevens
, on the 15th of July . putting him in fear, and taking from his person and against his will, 1 watch, value 3l., and 1 ribbon, value 2d, his property .

JAMES JOSHUA STEVENS
. I am a labourer, in the East India Company's service , and live in Pollard's-row, Bethnal-green. I was in Whitechapel-road
, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night - I was sober; there were three men on the pavement - one of them struck me in the chest; the prisoner came up, and drew the watch from my pocket - it was a violent blow, but it did not stagger me; she ran up a passage - I ran, and lost sight of her in a turning in the passage; I came out, saw a watchman, and went up, but could not find her - on the Saturday following I saw her again in Whitechapel; she avoided me, and went up a turning - I saw her again on the Wednesday after, and then gave charge of her to the street-keeper; he refused to take her, saying he knew her - I told Vann, and he took her the next day; I am positive she is the woman - there was a gas-lamp just over us; I have not found my watch.

JOHN VANN
. I am an officer. The witness gave me a description of the prisoner; I gave the description to another officer, who brought her to me on Friday the 24th -I collected eight or ten women together, put the prisoner among them, and then desired the prosecutor to go into the room and see if there was any body there he knew; he went in, and pointed out the prisoner immediately.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I apprehended the prisoner. The prosecutor pointed her out at the watch-house.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the man in my life
NOT GUILTY .

1839.
WILLIAM PATTISON FLANAGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 coat, value 20s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; 1 watch, value 30s.; 1 seal. value 5s.; 1 key, value 2s. 6d., and 11 sovereigns, the property of
Edward Swiney
, in the dwelling-house of
Sarah Mountain
.

EDWARD SWINEY
. I am a coachman , and lodge at Sarah Mountain's, Short's-garden, St. Giles'
. I lost the property stated, from my lodging room, where I slept - the prisoner's wife came to visit me; she is my own sister - I left her in the room, on Wednesday afternoon, the 2nd of September; when I came back the property was gone out of my box - the officer found my watch on the prisoner's person; I believe I lost it all on the 2nd of September; I did not see the prisoner there.
NOT GUILTY .

1840.
ROBERT CROSS
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Rebecca Smith
, on the 15th of August , at St. George, and stealing therein, 2 frocks, value 2s.; 1 bed-gown, value 6s.; 1 pelisse, value 4s.; 9 yards of printed cotton, value 7s.; 1 scarf, value 3s., and 1 shawl, value 5s., her property .

REBECCA SMITH
. I am a widow , and have three children - I live at No. 2, Church-lane, in the parish of St. George
. On Saturday. the 15th of August, I went out at half-past eleven o'clock in the morning - there are no lodgers; it is a small house, with two rooms and a kitchen; I locked my door, and saw two bad boys throwing stones; I turned back, and put my shutters too - my children were at that time at school, and no one was in the house; I locked my door very particularly, and when I came home at a quarter-past twelve o'clock, I met my little boy, who had come home from school; he said to me,"How came you to leave your window open;" I went to the house, and found the window was open, and the curtain torn down; the parlour door was wide open - my drawers were open, and the property stated was gone; the person had got in by pulling open the shutters, and lifting up the window, which was down, and fastened by a latch. I found my property at a pawnbroker's on the Monday - I know the prisoner, and knew his father; they did live three or four doors from my house, but they had moved a short time before; his father is a watchman.

JOHN GEORGE
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in High-street, Shadwell. On the 15th of August the prisoner pawned this gown-piece with me.

JOSEPH THOMPSON
. I am a pawnbroker, in Broad-street, Ratcliff. I have a shawl and a frock, pawned by the prisoner, between twelve and one o'clock on the 15th of August.

HENRY OSMOND
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Broad-street, Ratcliff. On Saturday, the 15th of August, the prisoner pawned a child's coat, for 2s.

JOHN NORRIS
. I am an officer. I was sent for, and took the prisoner - he took me to the pawnbroker's.

REBECCA SMITH
. These articles are my property; I am quite sure my window was shut down - I thought it would not open without breaking, but it did, and he had broken a knife in opening the drawers.

Prisoner's Defence (written.) I have never before, on any occasion, been accused of an offence against the laws of my country, but have lived with my parents, and have at all times maintained a good character with those who knew me. This act I was tempted to commit, at the request of
William Budd
, who opened the window of the house, and asked me to get in, and told me what to do; when I came out he took the bundle and went away with it; afterwards sharing the 10s. This statement is not made with a view of exeulpating myself, by implicating him, but to shew the Court, that although I am guilty of an offence, the commission of it was not contemplated or planned, but accidental, in consequence of meeting with William Budd.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH Aged 13.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, on account of his character and youth, and believing him to be seduced by Budd .

1841.
GEORGE SICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 pair of breaches, value 15s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 shirt, value 5s.; and 1 pair of trousers, value 2s., the goods of
James Cox
; and 2 coats, value 3l. 10s., and 1 gold seal, value 5s., the goods of
George Cox
; and 2 1/2 yards of woollen cloth, value 30s., the goods of
David Callaghan
, in the dwelling-house of
James Cox
.

DAVID CALLAGHAN
. I am a journeyman-tailor , and work at Mr. Cox's, Little Russell-street, Bloomsbury
. The prisoner is a shoemaker , and boarded in the house, but - did not lodge there - I missed this piece of cloth on the 26th of July; the prisoner had been there a good deal before - I left the cloth there on the Saturday night, and it was taken.

JOHN GANT
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in London-street, Tottenham-court-road. I took in this coat on the 27th of July, from Kilerby.

BENJAMIN KILERBY
. I am a tailor, and have known the prisoner about six months; I pawned a piece of cloth and a pair of breeches for him, but not this coat.

GEORGE MACKAY
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Grafton-street, Fitzroy-square. I have a remnant of cloth and a pair of breeches, which were pawned by Kilerby.

BENJAMIN KILERBY
. These are what I pawned, by the desire of the prisoner - I got 25s. for them, and gave it to him.

DAVID CALLAGHAN
. This cloth is my property.

JAMES COX
. This watch and other articles are mine.

GEORGE COX
. These articles are mine.

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the property had been stolen by a boy named
George Weston
, in whose company he was.
GUILTY (of stealing to the value of 25s.) Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
